I had no idea who the Kitty crew was or why anyone would think I of people was part of it. The guy looked down at my feet and shook his head. Not with those shoes on. You gotta take those kicks off immediately. Those mean something around here. What? What's wrong with my shoes? He just walked away, leaving me confused in the hallway. I made it to art class, thinking maybe that guy was just messing with freshman. But when I sat down, missus cook stopped mid sentence and stared at my feet. Young man, do you really think it's appropriate to wear those shoes? Her voice had that teacher tone that meant I was in trouble. I really don't know what you're talking about. I was getting frustrated now because nobody would explain what was happening. Girls sitting behind me started giggling and taking pictures of my shoes with their phones. I could hear them whispering, but couldn't make out what they were saying. One of them leaned forward and tapped my shoulder. You're either really brave or really stupid, she said, before going back to her phone. Throughout the entire class, people kept staring at my feet. When I got up to sharpen my pencil, everyone went silent like they were waiting for something to happen. This is a cook. Kept glancing at my shoes nervously like they might explode. By the time the bell rang, I was paranoid and confused. In the hallway between classes, it got worse. It's would see me coming and move to the other side of the hall. A group of sophomores pointed, and one of them made a slashing their neck motion across his throat. My locker neighbor, who usually said hi every day, grabbed his stuff and practically ran away when he saw me. By lunch, my phone was blowing up with Snapchat notifications. People had posted pictures of my shoes all over their stories with crying emojis and comments I didn't understand. R I P. And he doesn't know, and someone tell him before it's too late. I sat alone at lunch because nobody would come near my table. Even the lunch ladies gave me weird looks when I went through the line. One of them actually blessed herself like she was warding off evil. I tried to eat my sandwich, but my appetite was gone. What was so wrong with my shoes? In chemistry class, my lab partner asked to switch seats. The teacher agreed without even asking why. So I did the experiment alone while everyone whispered and stared. Someone had written brave or stupid on the board with an arrow pointing to my seat. During passing period, I saw a memorial plaque on the wall I'd never noticed before. Someone said the name Matthew and I tried googling it on my phone, but the school Wi-Fi blocked all the results. The few snippets I could see mentioned tragic incident and gang violence, but nothing specific. My hands were shaking as I walked to gym class. During gym class, I thought things would be normal since we all had to wear the same uniform sneakers. But Coach Wiley blew his whistle as soon as I walked in and pointed at me. You step outside in the hall now. I follow.

What made a female patient refuse all the male doctors in the building? The first thing I noticed when I entered the patient's room was her deep sunken eyes and pale cracked lips. I approached her cautiously, remembering how the charge nurse warned the girl refused all male staff. We all knew what that meant. And she looked as broken as I imagined. I pulled up a chair next to her bed instead of standing over her and gently asked if she wanted some water first. She nodded. Sweetie, you're safe here, I said, keeping my voice soft like I do with my anxious patients. Male staff won't come near you, I promise. It's just us girls here. She looked at me for the first time and whispered, he's here. I asked who. And at first she refused to even say his name. I handed her my pen and clipboard. After a second, her hand moved her Percy. My blood boiled at the name. He was my everything, she finally whispered and started showing me photos on her phone of them together at college, confirming that it was the same Percy who is now a resident at the hospital. I did everything for him, everything. Her voice cracked as she swiped to screenshots of assignments, time stamps showing her submitting his biochemistry homework at 3:00am, his pathology essays at 4:00am, his anatomy exams that she taken for him. She showed me his Instagram from those same nights, him doing beer Pong and body shots with other girls while she was writing his thesis on cellular biology. The day after graduation, after I'd spent three years making sure he got into residency, he sent me this, she said, and handed me her phone. The text made me want to throw something. Babe, you're too clingy and it's honestly suffocating. Need to focus on my career without distractions. And honestly, doctors are supposed to date doctors and you're not one. We're done. Please don't contact me again. I waited until she was stable and sleeping before I stormed into the break room where three other nurses were charting. You guys are never going to believe what I just found out about Percy, I said. I told them everything and watched their faces go from confused to furious. And within 10 minutes, we had half the female staff crammed into that tiny. I knew something was off when he asked me to explain what antibiotics were sent. June from pediatrics and Doctor Sydney are attending walked in right as someone said we should report him. And she closed the door behind her. Actually, I've been documenting his knowledge gaps for weeks, she said, pulling out her phone to show us pages of notes. But this explains everything. The room went quiet while we all looked at each other. And then Lita from the I C. U. Said, what we were all thinking, ladies, we don't need to destroy him. We just need to Let him destroy himself while we enjoy every second of it. The plan rolled out so naturally. It was almost beautiful to watch. Percy started getting paid for every.

Make a time capsule. What's a time capsule? We put special things in a box and bury it. Why would we bury our stuff? We'll dig it up in 10 years when we're 18. 10 years? That's forever. It'll be like getting a present from our kids selves. Okay, what should we put in it? Our friendship bracelet. And this photo of us. And my lucky marble. Perfect. Now we need to make a promise. What kind of promise? That no matter what happens, we meet here in 10 years. I promise, Lily. Even if I'm on the moon. Promise. July 15th, 2024. Three PM. Right here. Best friends forever. Forever and always. Jake, I have bad news. What's wrong? My dad got a new job in California. California? But that's so far. I know. We're moving next week. But what about our promise? I'll still come back in 10 years. Just like we said. Promise. I promise, Jake. July 15th, 2024. I'll be here. I'll wait for you. Don't forget about me. Never. You're my best friend. Forever and always. Two years since you left. I wonder if you remember our promise. But I miss having a best friend. Five years now. Still visit our spot. Five more years until our promise. Eight years. Almost there. I bought a shovel. Ready to dig up our time capsule. July 15th, 2024. I'll be there. Today is the day, Lily. July 15th, 2020. Four. Three PM. I'm at our spot with the shovel. Please tell me you remember. It's Four PM. You're late, but I'll wait. I've waited 10 years. I dug up our time capsule. Seeing our childhood photos made me cry. Where are you, Lily? Is this Jake Miller? Yes. Who is this? I'm Sarah. Lily

Parents who have adopted a older child, 5 and up. How has it gone for you? When my wife Rachel and I adopted Devon at six years old, they told us she had mild trust issues. What they didn't tell us was that she'd been returned by three families already. Devon showed up at our house with one tiny suitcase and a backpack that first night. I watched her through the doorway as she carefully laid out all her clothes on the bed. She folded each piece perfectly, put it back in the suitcase, and zipped it up. Then she slept on top of the covers, fully dressed. I thought maybe she was just nervous, but weeks went by, and that suitcase never got unpacked. She'd take out one outfit each morning, wear it all day, then fold it back up at night. Her closet stayed completely empty. Rachel tried everything. New sheets with unicorns on them, a night light shaped like a butterfly. We even let her pick out paint for her room walls. She chose white. Just plain white like before. One morning, I found her in the kitchen at 5 a m. Making her own breakfast. Toast with no butter, just dry bread. When I asked why she was up so early, she said, I didn't want to bother you guys. Sometimes people get mad when kids wake them up. That broke my heart. Rachel and I had been trying for years to have kids. We dreamed About Saturday morning pancakes and bedtime stories. But Devin acted like she was living in a hotel, not a home. The real wake up call came three months later. I got home from work and heard crying upstairs. Found Devin sitting on her bed, holding that stupid suitcase in her lap. What's wrong, sweetheart? She looked up at me with these huge brown eyes and said, I heard you and Rachel fighting last night about money. I know kids cost a lot. I can go back to Miss Janet tomorrow if you want. Miss Janet was her social worker. My throat got tight. Rachel and I had been arguing about our car payment. Nothing to do with Devon at all. Devon, we weren't fighting about you. We love having you here. She just shrugged. That's what the Johnson said, too. And the Millers. They all said I was special. Until I wasn't anymore. That night, Rachel and I sat up talking until 3 a m. We realized Devon wasn't just scared of us leaving her. She was waiting for us to leave her. She'd been through this routine before. Nice family, happy faces. Then back to foster care. When things got tough the next day, I had an idea. I went to the hardware store and bought the biggest picture frame they had, like three feet wide. Then Rachel and I spent the whole weekend taking photos. Devon at breakfast, Devon watching TV, Devon playing with our dog Charlie. Just Normal, boring family stuff. We printed out all the pictures and arranged them in the frame. Beach trips we took her on. Movie nights on the couch. Devon's first day at her new school. Even the bad pictures where someone was making a weird face. When Devon got home from school Monday, we called her into the living room.
NA

Have you ever had to block someone all because your parents said so? My parents were so worried about me dating a skater boy. They couldn't imagine he'd be the reason I'm still alive today. A few nights ago, my parents found out about my skater boyfriend, Gregus, when his message popped up on my screen at dinner. I love you, too. Who the heck are you talking to? My mom shouted, glaring the screen of my phone. You're 14. No dating until you're 30. We were very clear. Dad pulled up Gregus's Instagram on his own phone. A skateboarder? Really? This is who you're risking your future for? I tried to reason with them, but they refused to listen and forced me to block him everywhere, right there, over dinner. You'll thank us when you're in college, mom said while I sobbed. My friends tried passing messages between us at school, but my parents found out and threatened to call their parents. Eventually, everyone gave up, except for Gregus. Gregus showed up mysteriously in my valorant. Hey, Mel. It's been a while, he said, his voice breaking. I miss you, Mel. I know we're not supposed to talk, but let's at least play like we used to. We started meeting in the lobbies every day after that, just playing and chatting about normal things. School friends, my strict parents. He never once tried to convince me to sneak around or meet up in person. He never complained about my Parents or tried to turn me against them. When I vent about how unfair they were being, he'd actually defend them. Sometimes they're just scared, Once my older sister got mixed up with some bad people in high school. Parents get paranoid. He still cared about me in all the ways that mattered. When I failed my chemistry test because I couldn't focus, he spent three hours teaching me balancing equations over discord. When my grandmother got sick, he stayed up until 3:00am just listening to me cry. You can always reach me here, he promised. I don't care what time it is. Mom almost got us once when she walked by while discord was open. I clicked to my game lobby just in time. Homework break? She asked. I nodded and switched back to my essay, my heart pounding so hard I thought she'd hear it after she left Greg's message. Maybe we should stop. I don't want to get you in trouble. But I couldn't lose him again. He was the only person who I could rely on. And thank god I didn't lose him, because a couple of days later, my friend Sarah and I got caught up in some shady business. It was supposed to be a normal Saturday night sleepover. Her parents went out for their anniversary, leaving us to watch movies and eat junk food. I was on the phone messaging Gregus on discord when Sarah's older brother Joshua came home from College, completely wasted with two other friends, Sarah immediately tensed up. baby sis and baby girl, he winked. Disgusting. He and his friends sat beside us on the sofa, placing his arm over my shoulder, constantly whispering things like, I know you're not as innocent as you act, and your parents don't have to know. I pushed his face away and stood up, glaring. Can you stop? Sarah was almost crying, begging me not to make him mad. He gets mean when he's drunk. She was just ignore him and he'll pass out soon. But when Joshua grabbed my waist and tried to pull me onto his lap, I grabbed Sarah's arm and ran to the bathroom, quickly locking the door. He started pounding on it, laughing with his friends about how I was playing hard to get and needed to loosen up. Sarah hopped into the tub, hugging her knees to her chest. I. I patted my pockets, realizing I had left my phone in the living room. Soon the knocks on the door became angrier. Hitting the door harder, jiggling the handle aggressively, Sarah meekly handed me her phone.
NA

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20 and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude, maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, I figured why not? My little sister Mia is 15 and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for like an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. Then Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I Found my sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what happened and she could barely get the words out between sobs. She said Ethan had walked into her room, even though her door was only cracked open a little. She thought maybe he was lost looking for the bathroom. So she tried to be.

The rudest thing that a guest did to your pet in your home. My boyfriend brought his new coworker Dave, to our housewarming party last weekend. I have a 13 year old beagle named Murphy who's blind in one eye from an accident years ago and moves pretty slowly these days. He's the sweetest old guy, never bothers anyone, just likes to find a cozy spot and watch the world go by. I'd invited about 20 people over to show off our new place. Everyone was having a great time, music playing, people mingling between the kitchen and living room. Murphy had claimed his usual spot by the fireplace, occasionally getting gentle pets from guests who thought he was adorable. About an hour into the party, I realized I hadn't seen Murphy in a while. That's unusual because he never wanders far from wherever the action is. Started looking around, calling his name softly so I wouldn't alarm anyone. Finally found him locked in the laundry room, whimpering and scratching at the door. The moment I opened it, he practically collapsed into my arms, shaking. When I helped him stand, he was limping badly on his back right leg. My heart immediately started racing. Murphy's old and fragile. Any injury could be serious. I carried him back to the living room and asked everyone what happened, trying to keep my voice calm but probably failing. Most of my guests looked genuinely concerned and confused. A few people mentioned seeing him Earlier, but nothing seemed wrong. That's when Dave, who'd been standing by the beer cooler looking completely unbothered, started laughing. Oh yeah, that old dog kept get getting in my way while I was grabbing another beer, he said casually like he was talking about the weather. Kept bumping into my legs. So I gave him a little kick to move him along. No big deal. The entire room went silent. I stared at him in complete shock, not sure I'd heard correctly. You kicked my 13 year old blind dog, I asked. My voice probably getting louder than I intended. Dave just shrugged with this annoying smirk, barely touched him. He's fine. Obviously dogs need to learn boundaries anyway. Can't just let them walk all over you. My boyfriend's face went completely pale and he immediately started apologizing, clearly mortified. But I was already seeing red. Murphy was now hiding behind my legs, trembling and refusing to put weight on his injured paw. Everyone needs to leave right now, I announced to the room. Everyone except you. I pointed directly at Dave. You're staying to explain this to someone special. My guests filed out quickly, many of them shooting disgusted looks at Dave and offering to help with Murphy. My boyfriend hesitated, but I told him he needed to leave too and think about the kind and of people he brings around. Once the house cleared, I called my neighbor Jim. He's a retired police officer who absolutely adores Murphy and has a spare key to check on him when I travel for work. Jim treats Murphy like his own grand dog. Jim arrived within five minutes, still in his weak.
NA

Brother got me kicked out. Now my, he wants my house. When I was 16, my gaming obsessed brother Tyler convinced my parents I was taking up too much space in our cramped three bedroom apartment. He'd been complaining for months that he needed my room for his elaborate gaming setup. My parents sat me down one evening and basically said I had two weeks to find alternative living arrangements. The reasoning, I was almost 17, practically an adult and Tyler needed space to pursue his passion in gaming and they genuinely believed he was going to become the next big twitch star. I was devastated but had nowhere to go. My girlfriend Emma's parents noticed I'd been spending more time at their house and eventually asked what was going on. When I explained the situation, her mom immediately said I could stay stay with them as long as I needed, no questions asked. Emma and I got serious fast. Living under the same roof will do that to a relationship. When we turned 19, I proposed with a ring. I'd saved six months for working overtime every weekend. Parents were thrilled. They basically raised me for two years anyway and considered me their son. At 23, we finally had enough saved for a down payment on a small two bedroom house, nothing fancy. We spent every weekend renovating, learning YouTube tutorials, making mistakes and fixing them. Meanwhile, Tyler was still living with my parents in his gaming paradise. He Dropped out of community college after one semester, claiming his streaming career was about to take off. College was just holding him back. Three years later, he was still grinding away at maybe five viewers on a good day, sleeping until two PM, gaming until 4:00am, ordering Doordash with my parents money. My parents occasionally texted generic holiday messages or shared Facebook posts about family, but otherwise, we had zero relationship. Last month, my mom showed up at my house completely unannounced. I hadn't seen her.
NA

Driving instructor told me to never turn unless he said so, so I drove him straight into another state while he slept. Maya was the kind of teacher who got off on making students miserable. In AP history, he'd lean over your desk during tests, breathing coffee breath down your neck while tapping his pen on your paper, just to throw you off. And when he handed back essays drowned in red ink, he'd always had his favourite line in the real world, this wouldn't fly. I spent all junior year counting down to summer, marking days off my calendar like a prisoner, thinking I'd finally be free of his polyester blazers and power trips. So when I walked into the driver's ed two weeks later and saw him sitting behind the instructor's desk, my stomach dropped like a stone. Where do I turn? I asked during our first lesson, gripping the wheel nervously. You don't turn unless I say to, he barked, making me swerve slightly. Just assume you're going straight until I say otherwise. Though with your steering, straight is a pretty loose term. The two other girls in the backseat exchanged looks through the rearview mirror. When Sophia gripped the wheel too tight, he chuckled. Death grip won't help you drive better, sweetheart. This isn't a strength test. Emily stalled at a stop sign and he slapped his knee, laughing. And this is why I keep my seatbelt extra tight with you girls. Never know when We're gonna stop or if we're gonna stop. By the third lesson, we discovered his pattern. He'd make his nasty jokes for 20 minutes, then use the afternoon drives as nap time while we practiced highway driving. Don't worry about that curb you just kissed, said when I beard slightly. I'm sure it'll recover from the trauma. Unlike my neck. When Sophia asked about parallel parking, he laughed. You can barely handle forward parking and you wanna try parallel? That's adorable. He spent the entire next lesson bragging about his important dinner plans with his wife. If we survive today's lesson, that is three teenage girls driving. I should update my will. One afternoon, Sophia slightly veered and he exploded. Jesus, are you trying to collect mailboxes? Cause you're doing great. He wiped tears from laughing so hard. You know, girls like you three are why insurance rates are so high. And why driving instructors need hazard pay. It's funny because it's true. Then he made his final comparison. My five year old nephew has better control of his big wheel than you girls have of this car. He was still chuckling when he added, just try not to kill us while I. And then he was snoring, head tilted back against the headrest. I looked at Emily and Sophia in the rearview mirror and something passed between us. That's when I realised he told me to never turn unless he said so. The interstate entrance was coming up on The right, and I could see the big green sign marking I ninety five north hanging over the highway like a dare. I tilted my head slightly toward it and Emily caught my glance, following my eyes to the sign before whispering, I didn't hear him say turn, while Sophia nodded slowly and added me neither. I glanced down at the fuel gauge showing a full tank. Back at the sleeping Mister Maya, and as we approached the on ramp and I felt the car naturally wanting to continue straight onto the interstate, I took a deep breath and tightened my grip on the wheel. Well, he did say to follow his instructions exactly. The merge onto the interstate was smooth, and Mister Maya kept snoring while the highway stretched endlessly ahead. 30 minutes passed, then an hour, and his phone started buzzing in the cup holder with increasing frequency. We passed the welcome to New Jersey sign after two hours, making Emily stifle a nervous giggle as his phone lit up.

My neighbor kept calling the cops on my kids, so I made her house unsealable. My neighbor, Mrs. Daniels, called 9 1 1 like it was her personal hotline. Monday, she reported my kids for trespassing because their ball went in her yard. Wednesday, she called the cops because my autistic son was making noise in our own backyard. Friday, she called saying the kids were in danger because they were playing tag. The 9 1 1 operator probably recognized her voice better than her own family did. Things got worse as spring turned into summer and her calls went from annoying to actually dangerous. First, she called CPS and said we left our kids alone outside. I was sitting right there on the porch with a book when the social worker showed up. They close the case right away, but people had already started talking about us. Two weeks later, during my daughter's birthday party, she called the fire department about a gas leak. Five fire trucks showed up with their sirens going and scared all 12 kids at the party. The firefighters didn't find anything, but she went on Facebook saying we were probably making drugs. The worst thing happened in July when my autistic son had a meltdown in our yard. She called 9 1 1 and said a child was being beaten. The cop showed up ready for a domestic violence call and found me hugging my upset kid. Officer Martinez said something about her false Reports but nothing happened to her. She started calling during my work zoom meetings on purpose. Other neighbors told me she kept notebooks full of made up complaints with dates and everything. She actually brag to people about making families like ours want to move away. Everything went crazy on a Tuesday in August when I got a letter from her lawyer wanting $15,000. She said we cause her emotional distress even though she was the one who called 9 1 1 53 times. I tried to talk to her like a normal person, but she said she'd add harassment to the lawsuit. That same day, my autistic son had his first friend from therapy come over to play. While the two kids were quietly playing with Legos, she called about suspicious people in my yard. Police cars surrounded my house and both seven year olds were terrified.
NA
NA

Does anyone else think it's suspicious when your boyfriend suddenly starts working out after years of being lazy? My boyfriend, Jake, had been the same couch potato for three years. The guy who needed me to open pickle jars was suddenly doing push UPS at 6:00am. When I asked what sparked this change, he just shrugged and said he wanted to get healthy, but something felt wrong. It started small. He bought protein powder and left it on the kitchen counter like some kind of trophy. Then he got a gym membership to this fancy place across town instead of the Planet Fitness two blocks away. When I suggested we work out together, he got weird and said he preferred going alone to focus. Red flags kept piling up. He started showering immediately after coming home from the gym, which seemed normal until I realised he never smelled like sweat. His gym clothes were always perfectly clean, too. One day I decided to surprise him with lunch at his gym. The guy at the front desk looked confused when I asked for Jake. Turns out he hadn't been there in weeks. I confronted him that night. He got defensive and said he switched gyms because the other one was too crowded. When I asked which gym, he stuttered and said some random name I'd never heard of. That's when I knew he was lying. So I did what any suspicious girlfriend would do. I followed him the next Tuesday. I Watched him drive past three different gyms and pull into the parking lot of a Starbucks. Through the window, I saw him sitting across from this blonde girl who definitely wasn't just a workout buddy. She was laughing at everything he said and touching his arm constantly. My heart was pounding as I watched them for 20 minutes. When she got up to leave, he grabbed her hand and kissed it. I wanted to storm in there and cause a scene, but instead I waited. He came home an hour later with this fake exhausted look, complaining about how intense his workout was. I played along for two more weeks watching him lie to my face every single day. He even started buying workout supplements and leaving them around the apartment as props. Worst part was when he'd flex his non existent new muscles and ask if I noticed any changes. Then I got clever. I told him my friend Emma was looking for a new gym and asked for his recommendation. He panicked and said his gym was full and not taking new members. When I offered to call and check, he quickly said they had a waiting list and it wouldn't be worth it. That weekend, Jake said he was going to a special Saturday morning workout class. Instead, I followed him to the same Starbucks. This time they were holding hands across the table and looking at something on her phone together when he leaned over and Kissed her forehead. I knew I had enough evidence, but I didn't confront him yet. I had a better plan. I went home and researched the girl on social media, found her Instagram through the Starbucks location tag. Her name was Ashley. And according to her posts, she'd been seeing someone new for the past month. The timeline matched perfectly with Jake's sudden fitness obsession. Monday night, I casually mentioned that I'd signed up for a trial at his gym and would love to work out together.

The dumbest advice you followed that actually worked. Marry him anyway, my grandmother told me when I showed her the prenup my fiance's lawyer had drawn up. But first become exactly what they think you are. Everyone else said to run. My friends were horrified. My sister called me pathetic. The prenup basically said if we divorced, I'd get nothing. No alimony, no assets, no claim to anything acquired during marriage. Brian came from old money. His family was convinced I was a gold digger, a nurse marrying a tech CEO for his bank account. The prenup was their idea, protecting their precious son from the calculating poor girl. Sign it, grandma said, then go back to school. With what money? His. She was right. The prenup said nothing about education expenses during marriage, thing about him paying for my life while married. It only protected assets and divorce. So I signed it. His family celebrated. His mother actually said, so glad you understand your place. The day after our wedding, I enrolled in law school. Ryan thought it was cute. My little wife wants to be a lawyer. His friends laughed about how I'd never finish. I finished top of my class, law review, passed the bar, first try. His mother sneered at graduation. Such a waste. You'll be having babies soon. Anyway, I started my MBA next. Ryan paid for everything. We were married, shared finances. The prenup couldn't touch that. His family rolled their eyes at family Dinners while I discussed international business law. Seven years in, I had a law degree, an MBA and had started a consulting firm with the money Ryan gave me for shopping. Built it from nothing to six figures while being the perfect trophy wife at his events. His family still treated me like trash, still made jokes about the prenup protecting them from me. Ryan started believing them, getting cocky, cheating because what was I going to do, leave with nothing? Year 10, I filed for divorce. Ryan laughed. You get nothing. Remember that prenup you signed? Actually, I said I get everything I built. While the prenup protected his pre marriage assets and his income, it said nothing about businesses started during marriage with marital funds. My law degree taught me that. My MBA helped me build it. My consulting firm was worth $2 million. Started with his money? Yes, but legally mine. That's fraud, his mother screamed at mediation. That's marriage. My lawyer, my study partner from law school replied she used marital assets to build her own career. Completely legal. They tried to fight it at $300,000 on lawyers trying to break my business claim. But I documented everything perfectly, every dollar traced, every paper filed correctly. My grandmother's advice that everyone thought was stupid, become exactly what they think you are, then become something they never imagined. I thought I was a gold digger. Fine. I dug through their legal gold mine and found my own treasure. The best part was during the divorce proceedings, Ryan's lawyer tried to argue, I'd planned this all along.

What's something a family member expected you to do that actually changed your life? My little sister demanded I teach my study partner how to braid hair because she was convinced we were secretly in love. Emily was eight and had this weird obsession with my chemistry study partner, Conrad. Every Tuesday and Thursday when he'd come over, she'd magically appear with some urgent eight year old business. Can I show you my rock collection? Do you wanna see me do a cartwheel? Did you know I lost a tooth yesterday? Conrad was incredibly patient with her, always stopping whatever we were doing to admire her latest drawing or listen to her explain why unicorns were scientifically possible. I kept apologizing, but he just laugh and say she reminded him of his little cousins back home. He actually seemed to enjoy her interruptions, which made me like him even more. One Thursday, Emily cornered me in the kitchen while Conrad was in the bathroom. You need to teach Conrad how to braid hair, she whispered urgently. Why would I do that, M? Because when you guys get married and have daughters, he'll need to know how to do their hair for school. It's basic dad requirements. I nearly choked on my water. We're not getting married. We're just study partners. She rolled her eyes. He looks at you funny when you're working on equations. Like how dad looks at mom when she's making pancakes. Trust me, I'm very observant about Romance things. The next week, she orchestrated her master plan. Right before Conrad arrived, she accidentally left her favorite doll, Bella, in the living room, hair completely tangled. When Conrad walked in, Emily gasped dramatically, oh, no!

The troubled children. What was your breaking point? Ever since my son Leo was a little kid, he was just awful to other children. At 5 years old, he was kicked out of kindergarten for backing other kids into corners just to watch them cry. When our daughter Mia was born, keeping Leo away from her was a full time job. We had to move her crib into our bedroom and lock the door just to keep her secure. Later, when Mia was old enough to start losing her baby teeth, we did the whole tooth fairy thing. She put a tooth under her pillow and wake up to a few dollars. But every single morning, after showing us the money, she'd tell us the tooth itself was missing. My husband and I never touched them. Around that same time, Leo claimed the old shed in our backyard as his clubhouse and told us to stay out. But I'm his mother. So one day, I went in to see what he was up to. I found all of Mia's missing teeth laid out in a neat little row on his workbench. A cold feeling wash over me. When we confronted him about it, he just lost it. He screamed horrible things at us before locking himself in his room for three straight days. Over the years, we tried therapy, and he was kicked out of several schools. It wasn't until high school that we saw just how risky he was. One afternoon, a girl from his class knocked on our door. She looked terrified. She told me Leo had been following her home from school every day. She said she was scared for her life and didn't know who else to turn to because no one would listen. My stomach sank. I heard the real fear in her voice, and I apologized over and over. I promised I would talk to him, but deep down I knew it wouldn't do any good. Nothing I said ever did. That afternoon, when I mentioned the girl, he exploded. He started flipping chairs and throwing things across the kitchen. I had to run and lock myself in our bedroom to get away from him. The last thing I heard was him screaming, you'll all pay for this! Before he slammed the back door and went to the shed. I stayed in my room until my husband got home. He saw the broken kitchen window and the mess from Leo's fit and got mad. I'll go talk to him, said. Maybe he'll listen to his father. Then he walked out to the shed. A minute later, I heard a scream that I will never forget. I ran outside and found my husband on his knees in the grass, just crying. He looked up at me and whispered, don't go in there, but I had to see. I ran right past him. When I opened the shed door, I saw him.

Thing you only found out guys do when you started dating. 1 1 I didn't know guys will just stand in the shower for 10 minutes doing nothing. No water running, just standing there like they're waiting for a download to finish. The first time I walked in on it, I thought something was wrong. He looked at me all calm and said I'm just mentally preparing. I've never looked at showers the same way. Two. I found out men treat fridges like treasure hunts. He'll open it five times in a row, stare like something new is going to spawn, side dramatically, and then eat plain cheese straight from the block. I once asked why he keeps checking. He said in case a snack magically appears. Three I didn't know guys hum to themselves during the most random tasks. My boyfriend will be cleaning the sink, humming what sounds like boss battle music, then suddenly switch to singing about how this sponge is my sword. I caught it on video once and he begged me not to post it. 4. They'll wear the same hoodie for a month straight like it's a second skin. When I suggested washing it, he looked genuinely confused and said but it still smells like me, so it's fine. 5. They will absolutely keep random screws or wires in a just in case drawer. I asked why. He said because you never know when you'll need this. It was a bent nail. 6 point 10. They make sound effects for everything. Opening jars, throwing socks in the laundry, even getting up from the couch. Suddenly he's making rocket launch noises. 7. They'll stand in front of the mirror flexing, not realizing you can see them. The second they notice, they pretend they were checking their posture. 8. They'll eat an entire meal over the sink just to save dishes, and apparently that's normal to them. 9. They'll absolutely risk breaking a limb before making two trips from the car. Groceries stacked to their chin, wobbling like a Jenga tower, but proud. 10. They can sit in total silence for an hour staring at the wall, and when you ask what they're thinking about, they say nothing. And somehow they really mean nothing.

Left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I'd divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years, Max. Don't change the locks. He left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation. To our eight year olds, that first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home, and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. Taught Walter to throw a curveball in our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year two brought unexpected changes. Without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I'd been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually, she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her bonus mom. Their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes, and tucked them in at night. Year five was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year six, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward. After three years of zero Contact court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from in the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the place. Eleanor was packing the twins lunches for

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife Stephanie waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said, and I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked, because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping. We date each other's spouses. She said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered, room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie, and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said. Let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something. But then I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. Should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. She put on this red Dress I've never seen before. That she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul? Never. She started, then stopped. At dinner, she pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly. For months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand. Before what? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name, and she turned it face down immediately. When I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How was Cassie? Good. How was Paul? Then she started telling me everything they did. The hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you want to know? No. Her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere, and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down. Out of nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner. She had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked, and her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons. That's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom noticed it right away and her face changed. Is that men's Cologne? The whole table went quiet. We're sharing partners with Cassie and Paul, I said. Every week. Her dad dropped his fork and it made this loud sound. Sharing? Taking turns dating each other's spouses. Stephanie's idea. Her mom stood up from the table in my house, she said, and her voice was shaking. Stephanie tried to explain, but everyone had already smelled the Cologne and knew what was happening. That night Cassie called me. I know about Tuesday afternoons. I felt sick to my stomach about them. I followed Paul once four months ago to the hotel. She sounded drunk. I saw everything. By week five, everything fell apart. It was Cassie's birthday and I threw her a surprise party. I made a video of all her artwork and gave the speech about how talented and kind she Was. I forgot it was her birthday completely. I watched Stephanie watch Cassie cry happy tears and hold on to me like she didn't want to let go. That night, Stephanie came home from Paul's and started telling me what they did in graphic detail again. Stop. I don't want to hear it. She got mad. But I'm telling you everything. I didn't ask. Then she demanded to know what Cassie and I did together.

I tell my crush I fell in love with her kids. I found my work crush share crying in the break room, looking completely stressed. My dad's in the hospital, and I need to fly out tonight, but I can't find anyone to watch my kids. My ex won't answer, the babysitter I hired bailed, and I just. I can't afford to miss this flight, but I can't afford anything else either. She leaned against my shoulder, crying even harder. I volunteered without thinking. I'll watch them, I said, heart racing from how close she was to me. Are you serious? It's three kids. Three for at least two weeks. I waved my hand around like a lovesick fool. How hard can it be? The kids showed up at my apartment that night with tons of suitcases. The oldest, around 14, looked at her mom and said, really? Another boyfriend? Cher's face went red. He's just a friend from work, Camilla. The middle one, 10, rolled his eyes. The youngest, Kevin, wouldn't even look at me. They stood in my doorway like they were being sentenced to prison. Cher hugged them quickly, told them to be good, and left for the airport. I stood there with three kids who clearly hated me and realized I was in way over my head. The first morning, I woke up early to make them pancakes. When the oldest one, Camilla, laughed. She's not here, you know. You can stop trying, she said. Besides, You're not her type. Mom doesn't date guys without kids. We seen this a dozen times already. It hurt, but it wasn't a lie. Shares, co workers, guys from her gym, men from dating apps. Everyone wanted to play dad until they realized three kids meant actual work. And the kids really didn't make it any easier. From spilling drinks on my laptop to turning the TV up during important zoom meetings, they hated every second with me. Dude, just survive until she gets back, then ask her out. My friend told me that became the plan. Survive two weeks, do whatever to keep the kids happy. Be the hero, finally land a date with share. But like most things, it doesn't always happen the way you want it to. Sometime within the second week, the middle kid, Murph, came home from school trying to hide a black eye. Before I could even ask, Camilla grabbed ice from the freezer and held it against his face. Just pretend you didn't see anything, she told me coldly. I bent down beside them and asked in a kind but stern voice, tell me what happened. Leave me alone, he said, turning away. I shook my head. I'm not here to lecture you or get mad at you or do anything without your permission. Not even tell your mom. But I need to know what happened. Murph blinked at me and frowned. Someone called me an orphan because I don't have a dad. I patted his head and thanked him, walking away as calm as I could, even though all the blood in my body was boiling with anger. Next afternoon, I took a half day at work and showed up at their school in a rented GTR, strikingly white engine, purring like a monster. I rolled down the window and waved, wearing sunglasses and a black polo. Who's got the coolest dad now? I said loudly, as Murph and his friends ran over excitedly. Murph watched his bully's jaw drop and quickly hopped in. He rolled down the window and flipped him off, which was my signal to immediately drive off the middle school campus. Okay, I like the enthusiasm, but let's never tell your mother about this, I said, grinning. I picked up the other two kids and took them to in N out for a quick afternoon snack, then surprised them with a baseball game. Murph ate in a handful of nachos and I managed to snag a foul ball for little Celia. A bad old man, Camilla said, watching her siblings enjoy the game. We made sure to take pics with the car and at the stadium, all covered in ketchup and mustard. I sent everything to their mom with a caption we wish you were here. After that, things between me and the kids sort of changed. When the youngest, Celia, had a nightmare and called for her mom, I sat beside her bed reading out fairy tales. Until she fell asleep, I made the kids meals and lunch box

What's something your parents did out of love that you'll never forgive them for? When I was 15, my mom discovered my journal where I'd written about kissing a girl from my class. She didn't knock when she barged into my room that night. Just stood in the doorway, clutching my journal with white knuckles. This ends now, she said, her voice terrifyingly calm. No daughter of mine will be this. She couldn't even say the word lesbian. I tried explaining that I was still figuring things out, that it wasn't a big deal. But mom called dad in, showed him the pages. He looked more disappointed than angry, which somehow hurt worse. They scheduled an emergency appointment with Pastor Williams the next morning. Not a therapist, not someone trained in adolescent development. Their church pastor, who believed homosexuality was a choice. Listen. For three hours, I sat in his office while he explained how I was confused, how Satan was testing me. My parents nodded along to everything he said. Mom kept squeezing my hand when I tried to speak. The following week, they announced I was being sent to my aunt for the summer. For your spiritual health, mom said. What she didn't say was that my aunt ran a church camp specifically designed to fix kids like me. Camp restoration was nothing like the name suggested. No crafts or swimming or campfires. Just daily air sessions and one on one counseling that felt more like interrogations. We Were constantly monitored. No privacy in bathrooms, no unsupervised conversations with other campers. One. One night, a girl named Tara tried to run away. They caught her at the fence and made us all watch as they prayed over her for hours, calling out the demons of rebellion and perversion. Two weeks in, I developed a fever. Not just a slight temperature. I was burning up, delirious. The camp nurse gave me some painkillers and sent me back to group sessions. When I collapsed during prayer, they finally called my parents. Mom and dad drove eight hours to get me in the hospital.

I went to court over a parking ticket and the judge recognized me as the kid he'd expelled 20 years ago, except he wasn't my principal. He was my high school bully, Sam, who used to steal my lunch money every single day. I'm standing there with my wrinkled ticket, ready to fight this stupid 50 dollar fine when I see him squinting at me from the bench, same beady eyes, same cruel smirk starting to form. Well, well, well, if it isn't little Tommy the loser, he says into his microphone. The whole courtroom turns to stare at me. My face burns with embarrassment. Harassment 20 years later, and he's still humiliating me in front of everyone. But this time something different happens. Instead of shrinking away like I used to, I feel this wave of anger mixed with something else. I look at him sitting there in his black robe trying to intimidate me, and suddenly I see him for what he really is, a grown man who peaked in high school and never Learned how to stop being cruel. Sam, I say quietly, do you even remember why you used to pick on me? His smirk falters for just a second. That's your honor to you. No, seriously, do you remember? Because I do. I remember everything. My voice is steady now, stronger than it's ever been. I remember how you'd corner me by the lockers every morning, how you'd take my $5 and tell everyone I Was too poor to fight back. Courtroom is getting uncomfortable. People are shifting in their seats, but I can't stop. Now 20 years of silence is finally breaking. I remember going home hungry every day because of you. I remember my mom crying when she found out, thinking she'd failed as a parent because she couldn't afford to give me more lunch money. She worked two jobs, Sam, two jobs just to keep us afloat. And you made her feel like it wasn't enough. Sam's face is changing. The smugness is cracking, replaced by something that looks almost like recognition. You know what the worst part was, Sam? It wasn't the hunger. It wasn't even the humiliation. It was how you made me believe I deserved it. How you convinced a 12 year old kid that he was worthless. My hands are shaking now, but not from fear, from 20 years of buried rage finally finding its voice. I spent years in therapy because of you. Years thinking I wasn't good enough for anything. I couldn't make friends without wondering if they secretly thought I was pathetic. I couldn't date without hearing your voice calling me a loser. You didn't just steal my lunch money, Sam. You stole pieces of my childhood, my confidence, my ability to trust people. The courtroom is dead silent. Even the court reporter has stopped type. I had panic attacks in college because of you, because some part of me was still that terrified kid Hiding in the bathroom stall, praying you wouldn't find me. Do you understand what you did to another human being? Sam is staring at me now. And for the first time I see something human in his eyes, shame maybe, or recognition of the damage he caused. His mouth opens slightly like he wants to say something, but no words come out. My therapist asked me once what I'd say to you if I ever saw you again. I told her I'd probably just run. But standing here now, looking at you, I pause, wiping away a tear I didn't realize had fallen. I realize you're just as broken as you made me feel. And now here you are. I continue, still trying to make people feel small, still that same scared kid who thought making others suffer would somehow make you feel better about yourself. But it didn't work, did it, Sam? You're still miserable. I see him swallow hard for a moment. I think he might actually apologize, but then something snaps inside me. I'm not that scared kid anymore, your honor, I say, pulling out.

Sneaking out go way too far. My brother and I used to sneak out all the time. Not for anything wild, just dumb, harmless stuff. Late night 7, 11 runs, laying on the trampoline to watch for meteors. One time we snuck out just to see if the new Taco Bell was open 24 hours. We weren't rebels, just bored kids who liked feeling like we were getting away with something. Started when I was 11 and he was 14. He'd tap three times on my wall around midnight, our signal. I tiptoe past our parents room in my socks, meet him by the laundry door and we'd sneak out like little burglars in pajamas. He always carried a backpack with snacks, flashlights and a notebook he pretended was mission logs. I think he just liked pretending we were spies. It became our tradition. Even when we weren't talking much during the day, we'd still sneak out. One time I fell asleep and missed the signal. The next morning he left a granola bar and a sticky note in my sock drawer that said, rookie Mistake, you're on thin ice, Agent B. But as we got older, things changed, got busier with school, started driving, started dating. I assumed we just outgrown it. No more nightly missions, no more late Taco Bell disappointments. I tap on the wall sometimes just to see. But he never knocked back. Then one night, about a year after our last mission, I couldn't sleep too much. Energy. I tapped on the wall knowing it was pointless, but out of habit, I crept to the laundry room anyway and the back door was already open. I stepped outside. It was cold. Damn, the kind of quiet where even your own footsteps too loud. I walked to the side gate and that's when I saw him sitting in the driveway, hoodie up, facing away from me. His backpack. The backpack was next to him. I almost called out, but something about the way he was sitting stopped me. Shoulders hunched, arms on his knees like he was holding something back. I moved closer and heard it. Quiet, shaky breathing, then a, he was crying. I crouched down beside the car, not sure if I should say anything, but then I heard him mumble something under his breath. I can't do it anymore. He wiped his face on his sleeve and pulled out his phone. I peeked around the car just enough to see the screen. It was a message thread with someone in it.

Something your family did that you'll never forgive them for. When I was 13, my sister disappeared. Not like missing, not like kidnapped, just gone out the door one night and never came back. She was 17, wild but not stupid. She fought with my mom that night. I remember that part. Something about coming home late or the way she dressed. I don't know. Mom screamed, called her names I won't repeat. And then she left. No note, no bag, just her phone and jacket. I thought she'd be back in a day or two. It wasn't. Cops came, took a report. Mom acted all worried in front of them. But as soon as they left, she lit a cigarette and said she'll come crawling back. She didn't. Weeks passed. I waited. I cried. I watched the door every night. My dad didn't say much. He just sat on the porch and drank every now and then. He'd. Mother should have handled it better. But nothing changed. No flyers, no searching, no news. And after a while, they stopped talking about her at all, like she never existed. They even maybe take her photos down, said it was too depressing, said I was being dramatic. I wasn't even allowed to say her name. So I started whispering it to myself at night like some kind of secret prayer. Nina, Nina with her chipped black nails and loud music. Nina who used to sneak me candy when I cried. I Waited for her birthday that year. I made a little card, even baked a stupid the cake. Nobody touched it. Mom rolled her eyes and dumped it in the trash. Get over it, she said. You still have a family. Did I? Because it didn't feel like it. I started saving screenshots of missing person forums of girls who looked like her. I stayed up late reading horror stories online thinking maybe one of them was her. Maybe I'd find her name in some Jane Doe report. Didn't I? Never did. By high school, I'd stopped asking questions. They made me feel crazy for even bringing her up. One time I asked mom if she ever missed her. She looked at me like I slapped her. She made her choice, she said. Don't make me regret keeping you, too. That one stayed with me. I started hiding things, money, mostly, little bits from lunch or birthday cards. I kept it in an old shoebox under my bed. I didn't know why.

My teacher announced to the class that we were going to play Kahoot! I threw my bag of chips in the air and screamed because I was so excited. I knew I was going to win. Everyone else looked at me like I was crazy, but they all knew I had never lost a game before. The game started, and of course, I was the first to join. My username Kahoot King 2, 3, 5. Most people joined, but some didn't even bother because they knew I was unbeatable. There were 15 questions and I was dominating until I saw the leaderboard. Someone with the username you're gonna lose Sophie 8 9 was right behind me. Suddenly the whole class was cheering for them, hoping I'd finally lose. I was like, oh, heck no, that's not happening. But then disaster struck. I got the 10th question wrong, and you're gonna lose Sophie 8 9 got it right, taking first place, while I dropped to second. I fought hard for the rest of the game, but when the winners were announced, I was in second place. Second place! Meanwhile, the new champion stood there like they just won an Olympic gold medal. Turns out it was Becky. Becky! Everyone was laughing at me, so I did what any reasonable person would do. I. I let out the ha! Most powerful, earth shaking, reality bending fart of all time! It was so intense that the fire alarms went off and the School had to evacuate. In the end everyone apologized for laughing at me. But plot twist I had to go to the doctor because apparently my butt had third degree burns.

I get used to this. So, yeah, I'll take door number three. The devil says, alright, Monica, you're free to go.

Show anyone that photo. What photo? The one I just sent you. Don't show anyone. I didn't get the photo. Yes, you did. It says you opened it and took a screenshot. Did you text it to me? No, I sent it to your Snapchat. What? Just like you asked, babe, what's wrong? I don't have a Snapchat. Yes, you do. Well, well, no, I don't. I deleted my Snapchat like 3 days ago. I told you that. I know, babe. I sent it to your new account. What new account? The one you made today. You just added me and asked for a picture that wasn't me. What? I didn't make a new account. You didn't? No, babe. But you said it was you. When on Snapchat, what did I say? Hey, babe, I got a new account that wasn't me. Then who was that? I don't know. Did you just get a snap from me? Nope. I just sent a humiliating photo to one of my enemies. It was probably my ex. I don't think it was your ex or one of your enemies. How do you know? Because whoever did this had to know I deleted my account. That's true. Who did you tell that I deleted my Snapchat? No one. Who did you tell? I only told my girlfriends. You think it was your friends? Like as a prank? I will find out. But in the meantime, no more asking or sending inappropriate photos. I totally agree. Perfect. Why did you get a new Snapchat? Rizz app says reply with to get my boyfriend to.

Without telling my parents. I was 18 and technically an adult, but my parents still treated me like I was 12. My mom would go through my backpack every single day when I got home from school, checking my homework like I was in third grade. She'd read my text messages whenever she felt like it. And if I complained, she'd take my phone away for a week. My dad wasn't much better. He had this rule where I couldn't leave the house after six PM even on weekends. If I wanted to hang out with friends, I had to give them a full essay about where I was going, who would be there and when I'd be back. The final straw was when they installed one of those tracking apps on my phone without telling me. I only found out because my friend Jake mentioned seeing my location pop up when he was trying to text me. I confronted them about it that night and my mom just shrugged and said it was for my safety. My dad backed her up, saying as long as I lived under their roof, I followed their rules. Been working at this pizza place since I turned 16, saving up every paycheck except for what I needed for gas and lunch money. By the time I graduated high school, I had almost $4,000 saved up. I started looking at apartments online during my lunch breaks, telling myself I was just browsing. But the More I thought about it, the more I realized I could actually do this. Found this tiny studio apartment about 20 minutes from my job. The rent was only 600 a month and the landlord said if I could prove I had a steady income and pay first month plus deposit, he'd rent to me. I went to look at it on a day my parents thought I was at work. It was small and kind of dingy, but it was mine. I filled out the application that same day. Two weeks later, he called and said I was approved. I could move in the following weekend. That's when it hit me that I was actually doing this. I felt sick to my stomach but also kind of excited. I started slowly moving my stuff out. Every day after work, I'd grab a backpack full of clothes or books and stash them in my car. I told my parents I was staying late to help close the restaurant, which wasn't totally a lie since I was picking up extra shifts to make sure I could afford everything. The hardest part was getting my bigger stuff out. I waited until they went to my aunt's house for Sunday dinner, something I'd gotten out of by saying I had to work. I loaded up my car with my dresser, my desk and my TV, left most of the furniture since it wasn't really mine anyway, but I took the stuff that mattered. I left them a note on the kitchen counter. I kept it simple, told them I'd moved out, that I was safe and that I'd call them in a few days when I was settled. I said I needed space to figure out who I was as an adult and that I hoped they'd understand eventually. I left my house key next to the note. My phone started blowing up around 8 that night. Missed calls, texts, voice mails. My mom was crying in half of them. My dad was yelling in the others. They wanted to know where I was, if I was okay, why I didn't talk to them first. They said they'd always supported me and couldn't understand why I do this to them. I turned my phone off and didn't turn it back on until the next morning. I had 37 missed calls and way too many texts to read through. I called them back and told them I was fine, gave them my address and said they could come see my place if they wanted. My mom showed up.

I think we should break up a week before my birthday. Fine. You're right. That would be mean. How about next month? October, we have that trip planned. Okay. November, that's our anniversary. December, I already got your Christmas gift. January, Happy New Year to no one. February, Valentine's Day. March, Saint Patrick's Day. April, that's when we're putting my dog down. May disrespect the men and women who fought for our freedom. June, Flag Day. July, Independence Day. August, we have no trips planned, no birthdays and no holidays. Okay. Haha. Yes, I mean, I'm so sorry babe, but I think it's for the best. Alright, I'm gonna go on the internet and see if anything's happening related to the sentence I just said. Cancel August. What are the chances this means we can stay together? Yay! You're right, babe. We have to stay together now. I just wanted to break up with my girlfriend of five years so I could have an 11 person orgy. Is that that's so much to ask for baby. I've always wanted to do that. Oh my God, babe. I had no idea. Let me just check the internet and oh damn it, Orgy's got banned now too.

Do you have some water I could drink? No, we don't have any water in the entire house. Wow, really? Are you guys having, like, a plumbing issue or something? That sounds really bad. What? No, I was joking. I'll go get you a glass of water. Oh, okay. Weird. I think I'm gonna try running a Marathon. Yeah, right. And I'm an astronaut. Really? You never told me that. That is so cool. Have you been to the moon? Did you have to go to school for that? Huh? Did I have to go to school for what? To be an astronaut, duh. Do you not understand sarcasm? I was literally joking. Okay, but I was serious about running the Marathon. You get winded going up one flight of stairs. Do you think this shirt looks good on me? Yes, girl. Like, is the sky blue? I mean, yeah, on a normal day, but it was a little bit cloudy today, so I think it's more of, like, a grayish brown. No, dude, I didn't mean it literally. It's like an expression when something's really obvious. Hey, but does it look good on me or not? Wow, it's raining cats and dogs out there. Oh, my god. Are they okay? Uh, is who okay? The cats and the dogs. It must hurt falling onto the ground like that. Okay, I'm going home. I actually cannot stand hanging out with you anymore. Oh, was that one sarcasm? No.

My chronically late wife miss an event she was looking forward to by not rushing her because I wanted her to face consequences. My wife Jenna has this thing where she's always late, not just fashionably late, but like 30 to 45 minutes late to everything, dinner with friends, movies, work meetings, family gatherings, you name it, she's gonna be late for it. It drives me absolutely insane. The worst part is how she acts about it like it's no big deal. She'll roll her eyes when I tell her we need to leave, say, relax, babe, we have time, when we absolutely don't, and then get mad at me for being stressed about it. I've started telling her events start an hour earlier than they actually do, but she caught on and now just shows up even later. Last month was the breaking point. We were supposed to meet my parents for my dad's birthday dinner at this nice restaurant. I told her we needed to leave by 6:30 to get there on time. At 7:15, she's still doing her makeup, telling me to chill out because they'll wait for us. We showed up at 8:20. My parents had already ordered appetizers and were halfway through their main course. My dad looked hurt, my mom was pissed, and I wanted to disappear. But two weeks ago, something happened that Jenna had been talking about for months. Her favourite singer was doing this acoustic set at a tiny venue downtown She'd been refreshing the ticket page for weeks trying to get seats and somehow managed to snag two tickets when someone cancelled last minute. She was beyond excited, posting about it on Instagram every day, telling everyone at work about it. The show was at eight PM on a Saturday. The venue was small, maybe 50 people max, and they were super strict about their no late entry policy.

When did faking it actually work out for you? I pretended to be my cousin, the substitute teacher for a day and accidentally got my dream job. I was 19, broke as hell and still waiting to hear back from community college. My cousin Tyler was a substitute teacher who sometimes paid me to drive him around since his car was trash. One Tuesday morning he calls me freaking out, dude, I just rear ended someone. I'm supposed to be at Westbrook Middle School in 20 minutes. If I miss another day, they'll cut me from their sublist. I was eating cereal in my pajamas. That sucks, man. Wait, he said, you still have my school ID from when you helped me move those boxes last month? Yeah. Why? I'm serious. Let's go. Pretend to be me. Take attendance. Keep them quiet. It's just study hall. I laughed. You're insane. Please. They won't even check. Most subs just sit there anyway. It's one period. Something about the desperation in his voice got to me, plus I needed money. I threw on Tyler's spare button down shirt that was way too big and drove to the school with his laminated badge. The front desk lady barely looked up. You must be the sub for Miss Peterson's class, room 2, 13. Here's your clipboard. I walked down that hallway trying to look confident while my heart was pounding. The kids were loud but not crazy. I took attendance, reading names off the Roster, when they asked where their teacher was, I said she had a family emergency and today was independent study. Can we work on homework, this girl asked. Absolutely, I said. Having no clue what else to tell them. For an hour, I just walked around pretending to supervise while they did whatever. Some kid asked me about math and I said I'd get back to him. Another wanted to use the bathroom and I let like five kids go because I didn't know the rules. The bell rang and a whole new group of kids walked in. Nobody had told me there were multiple periods. I panicked but tried to play it cool. Same routine, independent study day. The projector wasn't working, so sorry, no video today. I made them read silently and told them I'd be grading papers instead. I just stared at Tyler's lesson plan book trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Third period came, then fourth. I was making it up as I went. When kids got too loud, I'd say stuff like, remember, this affects your participation grade, even though I had no idea how grading worked. During lunch, I hid in an empty classroom and texted Tyler updates, kept saying, you're doing great, just get through the day. Fifth period, this kid asked me about the Revolutionary War assignment. I panicked and said, what do you think the most important battle was? Then I made them debate it while I googled stuff on my phone under the desk. By 6th period, I was actually getting comfortable.
