Wife lost 80 pounds to impress her co worker. And I found out in the worst way possible. My wife Michelle gained about 80 pounds after our twins were born. Honestly, I didn't care. I still found her beautiful and told her so constantly. She seemed okay with it too, always saying she'd get back in shape eventually, but never really trying. Then last year, something changed. Out of nowhere, she joined this expensive Crossfit gym and started obsessing over fitness. She'd wake up at 5:00am for workouts, meal prep every Sunday and constantly talk about her fitness journey and her new gym buddy, Adam from her accounting department. I was genuinely proud of her transformation. In six months, she looked better than she had in our wedding photos. But weird things started happening. She volunteered for every company retreat, conference and team building event, always mentioning how Adam would be there too. She bought new clothes, constantly started wearing makeup to the gym and was always texting during family dinners. The breaking point came during our daughter Leah's take your kid to work day. Leah had been excited for weeks to see Mommy's office, but when she came home, she was acting strange and quiet. How was Mommy's work, I asked while making dinner. Leah looked confused and said, why does Mommy have a different name there? My heart stopped. What do you mean, sweetheart? Everyone kept calling her Adam's girlfriend and asking when they were getting married and Mommy sat on Adam's lap during the meeting instead of her own chair. I felt sick. That evening, I casually brought up Adam, asking how their workout partnership was going. Michelle immediately got defensive, her face flushing red. We're just fitness buddies, Robert. God, you're so paranoid and insecure. Or maybe if you actually supported my health journey instead of being jealous, you'd understand. But something didn't add up. I started paying attention to details I previously ignored. She was coming home from gym sessions smelling like expensive Cologne. Her workout clothes were always pristine, no sweat stains or wrinkles. And.

Awkward favor someone has ever called in. My phone buzzed at 2:00am with a text that made me sit straight up in bed. Remember that favor you owe me? I need you to be my boyfriend at my sister's wedding this Saturday. Pick me up at four PM. Where? Navy. It was from Poppy, the girl who saved my entire college career three years ago. I hadn't spoken to her since graduation, when I drunkenly promised her anything, anytime after she spent an entire semester tutoring me through chemistry for free. Without her, I would have lost my scholarship and dropped out. Now she was calling in that favor. Honestly, being someone's fake boyfriend for a day seemed like a small price to pay. Plus, if I was being honest with myself, I'd always wondered what it would have been like to actually date her. When I picked her up that Saturday, Poppy answered the door looking absolutely stunning in an emerald dress that made her green eyes even brighter. But her expression was all business. She handed me a typed sheet of paper titled Our Relationship Details, with bullet points about our first date, how long we've been together, and my supposed favorite things about her. Eight months, she said, adjusting my tie without making eye contact. We've been dating eight months. You call me pop sometimes. We met at a coffee shop. Her voice was mechanical, like she was reading a grocery list. During the drive, she explained The situation? My parents keep trying to set me up with their business partner's son at every family event. He's perfectly nice, but I'm just not interested. This will shut them up for a while. The whole ride she was silent. Then when we arrived at the venue, she took a deep breath, grabbed my hand, and suddenly transformed into a completely different person. Ready, babe? She said with a bright smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. The ceremony was beautiful. I caught Poppy wiping her eyes during the vows, and without thinking, I handed her my pocket square. She looked surprised, but took it, whispering thanks so quietly I almost missed it. During the reception, I found myself forgetting this was an act. When her uncle made a toast, I instinctively put my arm around her shoulders. When the music was too loud to hear her cousin's story, I leaned down so she could whisper it in my ear, her breath warm against my neck. Her grandmother cornered us by the dessert table, pinching my cheeks and telling Poppy in a stage whisper, this one's much better than Adrian. Poppy went rigid at the name, but I squeezed her hand and smoothly changed the subject to Grandma's famous apple pie recipe. Couple's dance was when everything shifted. Poppy was stiff in my arms, counting steps under her breath like she was solving an equation. Hey, I whispered, pulling her closer, just follow me. Stop thinking so hard. She Looked up at me, and for a moment, her guard completely dropped. She melted into me, her head finding that perfect spot against my shoulder. We swayed together as the song played, and I found myself hoping it would never end. Then, during the bouquet toss, she caught it by accident when it bounced off another girl's hands. The crowd cheered, but Poppy immediately handed it to the girl beside her, laughing it off. Just superstition, anyway, she said. But I noticed her looking at the flowers longingly as the other girl walked away. Her sister pulled me aside while Poppy was in the bathroom. Thank you, she said, squeezing my arm, for making her happy, even if it's just for tonight. The words stuck with me. As the night wound down, I realized I wasn't acting anymore. When I looked at her laughing with her cousins, I felt a pull in my chest. That had nothing to do with owing her a favor, driving her home. I couldn't keep it in anymore. Poppy, I know this was just repaying a debt, but tonight felt real to me. Really real. She went completely still in the passenger seat. When I pulled up to her apartment. She practically jumped out of the car. You did great. Perfect fake boyfriend. We're even now. The words came out rushed and cold. She was already at her building's door before I could respond. I sat there for five minutes, feeling like an idiot before Driving home the next morning, Poppy's sister texted me. You left your jacket. Coffee shop on Fifth Street. When I arrived, she was sitting with Poppy's old chemistry notebook from college. He's going to kill me for this, the sister said, sliding it across the table. The margins were filled with notes about me, not chemistry notes. He remembered my coffee order, his smile when he finally understood Ionic bonds. An extra hour to help me with my own exam. Page after page of moments I completely missed. The sister explained everything. The parents never tried to set her up with anyone. Adrian was a high school boyfriend who told her she was too much when she confessed her feelings. Poppy never dated anyone after college, convinced she misread every signal. She was moving to Chicago next month for her dream job and called in the favor as a last shot to spend time with me before giving up forever. I drove straight to her apartment. She opened the door in pajamas, eyes puffy from crying before. Before she could speak, I held up a notebook. Your sister showed me this. Her face went pale. That's so embarrassing, I. I kissed her, cutting off whatever self deprecating thing she was about to say. When we pulled apart, I kept her face in my hands. I'm an idiot who needed chemistry help in more ways than one. I should have seen it three years ago. She started crying again, but this time, She was smiling. So what about Chicago? She asked. I pulled her closer. I hear it's beautiful this time of year. Plus, I still owe you the favor. Was being your boyfriend for a day, falling in love with you? That's just interest.

What's something your parents did out of love that you'll never forgive them for? When I was 15, my mom discovered my journal where I'd written about kissing a girl from my class. She didn't knock when she barged into my room that night. Just stood in the doorway, clutching my journal with white knuckles. This ends now, she said, her voice terrifyingly calm. No daughter of mine will be this. She couldn't even say the word lesbian. I tried explaining that I was still figuring things out, that it wasn't a big deal. But mom called dad in, showed him the pages. He looked more disappointed than angry, which somehow hurt worse. They scheduled an emergency appointment with Pastor Williams the next morning. Not a therapist, not someone trained in adolescent development. Their church pastor, who believed homosexuality was a choice. Listen. For three hours, I sat in his office while he explained how I was confused, how Satan was testing me. My parents nodded along to everything he said. Mom kept squeezing my hand when I tried to speak. The following week, they announced I was being sent to my aunt for the summer. For your spiritual health, mom said. What she didn't say was that my aunt ran a church camp specifically designed to fix kids like me. Camp restoration was nothing like the name suggested. No crafts or swimming or campfires. Just daily air sessions and one on one counseling that felt more like interrogations. We Were constantly monitored. No privacy in bathrooms, no unsupervised conversations with other campers. One. One night, a girl named Tara tried to run away. They caught her at the fence and made us all watch as they prayed over her for hours, calling out the demons of rebellion and perversion. Two weeks in, I developed a fever. Not just a slight temperature. I was burning up, delirious. The camp nurse gave me some painkillers and sent me back to group sessions. When I collapsed during prayer, they finally called my parents. Mom and dad drove eight hours to get me in the hospital.

I lost weight before my sister's wedding. My sister Emma had been planning her wedding for two years and I was supposed to be her maid of honour. She kept dropping hints about how all the bridesmaids needed to look cohesive in the photos and how important it was for everyone to put their best foot forward for her big day. Look, I'm not stupid. I knew what she was getting at. I gained about 40 pounds over the past few years since I started working from home. Emma never said it directly, but every time we talked about the wedding, she'd mention some diet she saw on Instagram or ask if I was getting ready for the wedding season. The breaking point came three months before the wedding when we went dress shopping. I tried on the bridesmaid dress in my size and Emma just stared at me in the mirror with this tight smile. She asked if maybe we should size up for comfort and then suggested I might wanna start doing some pre wedding prep with her. That weekend she texted me a link to some fitness app and said, thought this might help with your confidence for the big day. I screenshot that text and sent it to my boyfriend Tyler who said she was being a total bitch. I decided I'd show her. I downloaded my fitness pal that night and started tracking everything. I cut out all the late night snacking, stopped getting coffee With extra syrup and started walking to the grocery store instead of driving. I wasn't trying to do anything extreme. I just wanted to lose enough weight that Emma couldn't make her little comments anymore. The first month, I lost 12 pounds. Emma noticed right away when we met for brunch and kept asking what I was doing differently. I told her I was just eating better. And she got this weird look on her face like she didn't expect me to actually do anything about it. By month two, I was down 25 pounds and feeling amazing. I bought new jeans that actually fit.

What's the smartest way you've ever tricked your parents? As a kid? When I was 12, my parents had a strict rule, no video games during the week, only weekends. But my friends would get online every night after homework and I was missing out on everything. My bedroom was directly above the living room so they could hear every footstep. The PlayStation was in my room, but the second they heard any controller clicking or game sounds, I'd be busted. That's when I discovered something brilliant, the closed captioning setting. I realized I could play games completely silent with subtitles on, no sound effects, no music, no voice acting, just pure visual gaming with text at the bottom. For two months, I played every night for about an hour after my parents thought I was asleep. I became a master of elf gaming. I wait until I heard their TV turn on downstairs, then carefully power up my PlayStation with the volume at zero. I was living my best secret life until the night my dad decided to check on me. I heard his footsteps on the stairs and had maybe 10 seconds and just turn off the PlayStation. It made noise and took too long. So I did the only thing I could. I dove into bed, pulled the covers over my head and left the game running. He opened my door and I held my breath pretending to be asleep. Through my blanket, I can see the Light from my TV screen still flickering. That's weird. I heard him mumble, he walked over to my tea. I was dead. Caught red handed, game over. But then I heard him say, honey, come look at this. My mom's footsteps came up the stairs. I was.

Parents of troubled children, what was your breaking point? Ever since my son Leo was a little kid, he was just awful to other children. At 5 years old, he was kicked out of kindergarten for backing other kids into corners just to watch them cry. When our daughter Mia was born, keeping Leo away from her was a full time job. We had to move her crib into our bedroom and lock the door just to keep her secure. Later, when Mia was old enough to start losing her baby teeth, we did the whole tooth fairy thing. She put a tooth under her pillow and wake up to a few dollars. But every single morning after showing us the money, she'd tell us the tooth itself was missing. My husband and I never touched them. Around that same time, Leo claimed the old shed in our backyard as his clubhouse and told us to stay out. But I'm his mother, so one day I went in to see what he was up to. I found all of Mia's missing teeth laid out in a neat little row on his workbench. A cold feeling washed over me. When we confronted him about it, he just lost it. He screamed horrible things at us before locking himself in his room for three straight days. Over the years, we tried therapy and he was kicked out of several schools. It wasn't until high school that we saw just how risky he Was one afternoon a girl from his class knocked on our door. She looked terrified. She told me Leo had been following her home from school every day. She said she was scared for her life and didn't know who else to turn to because no one would listen. My stomach sank. I heard the real fear in her voice and I apologized over and over. I promised I would talk to him, but deep down I knew it wouldn't do any good. Nothing I said ever did. That afternoon when I mentioned the girl, he exploded. He started flipping chairs and throwing things across the kitchen. I had to run and lock myself in our bedroom to get away from him. The last thing I heard was him screaming, you'll all pay for this, before he slammed the back door and went to the shed. I stayed in my room until my husband got home. He saw the broken kitchen window and the mess from Leo's Fit and got mad. I'll go talk to him, he said. Maybe he'll listen to his father. Then he walked out to the shed. A minute later, I heard a scream that I will never forget. I ran outside and found my husband on his knees in the grass just crying. He looked up at me and whispered, don't go in there. But I had to see. I ran right past him. When I opened the shed door, I saw him.

Did your family finally stop calling you chunky? My family still makes me weigh myself before holiday dinners. Not joking. My Aunt Rose keeps a scale by her front door specifically for me. Growing up as the fat cousin shaped everything about family gatherings. Even though I lost 140 pounds three years ago, they refuse to see it. I wear oversized hoodies to every family event now. The baggy clothes hide my body because years of their comments train me to cover up. They make me enter through the garage because they claim the front steps can't support me. My cousin Derek still calls me Big Mac and makes earthquake sound effects when I walk. Last Christmas, they gave me a group gift of weight loss surgery pamphlets and a biggest loser DVD set. Thanksgiving this year was what revealed everything. The entire extended family was there, aunts, uncles, cousins, grandparents, second cousins, everyone. My grandmother had rented a huge cabin for the weekend. The torture started immediately when I walked in. Uncle Edward yelled across the room that they'd reinforced the deck chairs. Don't want another incident like the fourth of July. He laughed. There was no incident on the fourth of July. The whole room erupted in laughter. My cousin Marissa grabbed my plate at dinner before I could. I'll serve you. She announced. Portion control is important. She put three green beans and a spoonful of Turkey on my plate. Nothing else. When I reached for the Mashed potatoes. She slapped my hand. Those aren't for you. My teenage cousins started a betting pool on whether I'd sneak food later. They used a whiteboard in the living room to track their bets where everyone could see. Twenty dollars. Said I'd raid the fridge by midnight. 30 said I'd eat a whole pie. After dinner, they made me sit on the floor. The couch has a weight limit, Aunt Rose explained to her new boyfriend. We have to be careful. She said it like I wasn't even there, like I was some kind of safety hazard. I tried to tell them about my transformation. I've lost a lot of weight. I started. Derek burst out laughing so hard he spit out his drink. Sure, you have Big Mac. What did you lose? Five pounds. The room exploded. Even my mom was giggling. Honey, stop making things up, she said. It's okay to be who you are. The worst part came during family photos. They made me stand in the back corner for balance, the photographer said, after my aunt whispered something to him. Then my Uncle Edward announced I should probably skip the group jump photo. Safety first, he said, patting his stomach and winking at everyone. My cousin filmed the whole thing for her Instagram story. The caption read, Chunky's still dreaming of being skinny with crying, laughing emojis. That's when the cabin owner walked in with his son to say hi to everyone. The son stopped. Dead in his tracks staring at me. He was this athletic guy in his 30s. Looked like he lived at the gym. No way, he said. His voice cutting through the chatter. Are you Benson Clark, the gym trainer? My Aunt Rose laughed him. He can barely transform himself to the couch. The man ignored her completely. His excitement was building. This is insane, dad. This is the guy I told you about. He saved my life. The room went quiet. My Uncle Edward snorted. Chunky saved your life? What did he do? Eat all the donuts before you could get diabetes? The man's face went serious. Two years ago, I weighed 300 pounds. I found his program when I was planning to end everything. He runs one of the best transformation programs out there. I lost 100 pounds. Pulled out his phone, showing before and after photos. This man owns a chain of successful gyms. Major companies pay him massive sponsorships. He's transformed thousands of lives. My Aunt Rose's smile froze. That's, that's impossible. He works at a fast food place. The man looked confused. Fast food? He just bought the entire.

What's your most bittersweet childhood memory? When I was eight, my cousin Tiffany came to live with us for six months while her parents sorted out their divorce. I'd always wanted a sister, and suddenly having a 12 year old girl in the house who knew about makeup and had actual opinions about music seems like winning the lottery. My mom set up the guest room for her with new curtains and cleared out half the closet. Dad built an extra shelf for her books. My little brother Sean, who was only five then, followed her everywhere until she taught him a secret handshake that made him feel special. The first weekend Tiffany was with us, she suggested we build a time capsule. We collected items all week. I contributed my favourite marble, Sean added a plastic Dinosaur, mom put in a recipe card, and dad included a baseball card. Tiffany added something wrapped in tissue paper that she wouldn't show anyone. This stays sealed until exactly 10 years from now, Tiffany said. As we buried it under the old maple tree in the backyard. We marked the spot with rocks arranged in a circle. Every Sunday became capsule checking day, where we'd go out to make sure the rocks hadn't been disturbed. Sometimes Tiffany would press her ear to the ground and claim she could hear our treasures talking to each other. Sean believed her completely. I pretended to believe, but secretly knew. Better still, I played along. In Month four, our neighbours Adrian and Yasmin, invited us to their daughter Molly's birthday party. Molly was Tiffany's age and they become friends at school. The day before the party, I overheard mom on the phone. I know it's difficult, but you need to make a decision soon, mom said. She's doing well here, but she asks about you everyday. That night, Tiffany taught me to braid my hair. Her fingers worked quickly and I sat perfectly still, afraid any movement might make her stop. When she finished, she took a picture with her disposable camera. This is how I'll remember you, she said. At Molly's party, the adults gathered in the kitchen while us kids played games in the basement. I noticed Tiffany kept checking the stairs. Molly's mom called everyone up for cake. Tiffany pulled me aside. I have to tell you something, she whispered. I'm going back home next week. The cake tasted like nothing. After that. I watched Tiffany laugh with Molly and the other older girls. She seemed happy, not like someone about to leave everything behind on her last night with us. We had pizza, Tiffany's favorite, with extra cheese. Dad made ice cream sundaes, and mom gave Tiffany a necklace with a tiny silver heart. Sean cried when he found out she was leaving and refused to do their secret handshake. It won't be special anymore if we do it when I'm leaving, Tiffany explained. After Sean went to bed, Tiffany and I Sat on the porch swing. I wanted to ask her why she had to go, why she couldn't just stay with us forever. But instead, I asked about the time capsule. What did you put in there that you wouldn't show us? A letter to you, she said. About why I really came to stay here. The next morning, her dad picked her up in a car I'd never seen before. Mom hugged him. For a long time, Tiffany hugged each of us. But when she got to me, she whispered, remember 10 years? We got two postcards from her that summer. Then Christmas cards for a few years. Then nothing. Mom said, people get busy. Dad said, that's just how life works sometimes. When I was 13, Sean wanted to dig up the time capsule early. I wouldn't let him. I promised Tiffany we'd wait the full 10 years. Last month marked exactly 10 years. I came home from college for the weekend and went straight to the maple tree. The rocks were gone. Landscapers had redone the yard years ago. I dug where I thought the capsule should be. Nothing. I tried another spot. Nothing again. I was about to give up when my shovel hit something.

When did your biggest critic realise they owed you everything? My son turned eight last Saturday and his mom threw him this huge party at her parents house with bouncy castles and a magician, probably 50 people there. I showed up with my gift wrapped in newspaper because I couldn't afford wrapping paper. And my ex wife's sister actually laughed out loud when she saw it. Her husband pulled me aside and said I should be embarrassed showing my face here when everyone knows I'm three months behind on child support and asked if I even knew what grade he was in. I wanted to tell him that I actually knew his teacher personally because I've been volunteering at his school every lunch hour. But instead I just stood there and took it because arguing would just make everything worse for my boy. The whole party was basically two hours of my ex wife's family taking turns humiliating me while I tried to stay invisible near the fence. Her mom kept making these loud comments about how some fathers actually provide for their children. And her dad walked past me carrying my son's new bike and said maybe someday I could afford to buy my child something that didn't come from a thrift store. When they brought out the cake and my son wanted me to stand next to him for photos, his grandmother literally stepped in front of me and said they wanted pictures with people who were actually Part of his life. I watched my boy's face fall and it took everything in me not to say something, but I knew they'd just use it against me. Court, my ex wife's aunt asked me directly in front of everyone if I was still working that pathetic warehouse job or if I've been fired from that too. And when I said I was still there, she said at least my son would learn what not to become. My ex wife stood there telling her cousins that I lived in some disgusting studio apartment and probably spent my child support money on beer while her sister nodded along and said some people just aren't meant to be fathers and that's okay. That's when a Grace Dan pulled up and this exhausted looking woman got out carrying a thick folder and walking straight through the party toward me like everyone else was invisible. She looked distressed and said she was sorry but this couldn't wait another day because the state was threatening to pull the placement if she didn't get the inspection done immediately. My ex wife's mom immediately stepped forward and demanded to know who this woman was and what the hell she was talking about. The woman said she was from Child Protective Services and she needed to inspect my home for the foster placement renewal and verify the twins were still thriving. My ex wife's sister went completely white and whispered, what twins? The social worker flipped through Her papers and said she was talk.

Sister in law snooped and stole our baby's name, then announced it right after she gave birth. But her face immediately dropped when she realized that we tricked her. My sister in law, Maya, has always been competitive with me since the day I married her brother, Jake. He couldn't handle that someone else was getting attention and what she considered her family. When Jake and I got engaged, she tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. So when we both ended up pregnant at the same time, I knew the competition was about to get intense. Maya was due just two weeks before me. And from the moment we announced, she became absolutely obsessed with finding out our baby name choice. At first it started innocently enough. She'd casually ask during family dinners, have you guys thought about names yet? When we'd de flesh, she'd push harder. Come on, just give me a hint. But then it escalated. Maya started showing up at our house unannounced, trying to peek at any baby books we had lying around. She'd walk through our nursery and comment on everything, clearly fishing for clues. She even asked my mother in law to pressure us into sharing our choice. The breaking point came when I caught her literally going through our mail when she thought we weren't looking. She was flipping through baby magazines and packages desperately searching for any Evidence of our name decision. My husband thought I was being paranoid when I told him I suspected Maya wanted to steal our name and use first. She wouldn't do that, he said, but I knew better. This was exactly the kind of petty move Maya would pull. That's when I decided to set a trap. I created a blanket, trust boards filled with names I'd never actually consider using. I strategically left a notebook open on our kitchen counter with Final Decision written in big letters next to the name Aurora Rose. When Maya came over for dinner, I even coordinated with my mom to call me while Maya was within earshot, having a completely fake conversation about how Aurora fits so perfectly with your family naming tradition and I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait. Com. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think, she'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it, like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. Within an hour of giving birth, she posted on Facebook, welcome to the world, Baby Aurora Rose. Our little princess has finally arrived. The whole family flooded the comments with congratulations, but I noticed Maya kept checking to see if I'd responded. She was clearly waiting for my reaction to Her surprise, the next day at the hospital. Maya was practically glowing with smugness. When I walked.

Worst nightmare a burglar could ever face. My roommate Lisa was doing her nightly skincare routine when we heard glass breaking downstairs. She just applied a thick green face mask and was wearing her ratty bathrobe with hair and rollers. Did you hear that? I whispered. Lisa grabbed her phone to call 9 1 1, but then got this evil grin. Wait, I have a better idea. She crept to the top of the stairs and let out the most blood curdling scream I've ever heard, then started speaking in tongues. Literally just gibberish that sounded vaguely Latin. Spiritus Malum, enter this vessel. I heard the burglar drop something and curse. Lisa crawled down the stairs backwards like the girl from the Exorcist, still screaming in her made up demon language. The green face mask was cracking, making her look legitimately terrifying. The burglar was backing toward the window when our other roommate, Ben, emerged from his room. He immediately caught on. The possession is spreading! He yelled. Everyone get the salt! Ben started throwing table salt everywhere while chanting the Pokemon theme song in a deep, ominous voice. The burglar was now pressed against the wall. Our TV forgotten on the floor. Please, he begged. I'll leave. I'm sorry. Lisa's head snapped toward him. She put in her glow in the dark Halloween contacts. In the dim light, her eyes were literally glowing green. You disturbed the ritual, she growled. That's when our fourth roommate, Kevin, joined in. He Emerged, playing his violin badly, just screeching notes while swaying like he was in a trance. The demons need music! Ben shouted, now drawing symbols on the wall with ketchup. Play louder! The burglar tried to run, but Lisa's spider walked toward him at surprising speed. He actually screamed. I need an old priest and a young priest, I yelled, getting into it. I'm Protestant! The burglar cried. I don't know any priests! Lisa stood up suddenly, did a perfect backbend and whispered, then you're screwed! The man literally wet himself. I saw the stain spreading on his jeans. Kevin's violence screeching intensified. Ben was now speaking in Klingon. Lisa started doing that creepy clicking sound from the grudge. The burglar fell to his knees. What do you want from me? Your soul, Lisa hissed. Or your confession? I'll confess. I've robbed 12 houses. I'll tell you everything! He started listing addresses, eightes where he'd sold stuff. Ben was frantically taking notes while still pretending to be possessed. When the cops arrived, they found a burglar in tears, begging for an exorcist. Lisa, still in full green face mask and glowing contacts. Catch up! Demon symbols on our walls. Kevin playing my heart will go on badly on violin, Ben reading the burglar his rights in Klingon. The burglar immediately confessed to everything. Begged the cops to take him to a church instead of jail. Kept asking if we were really human. The officer looked at Lisa. Ma'am, what exactly Happened here. Skincare night, she said sweetly. Very important for your pores. They took the burglar away. I was muttering about the green demon and violent of the damned. Cops came back later for our statements. One of them finally cracked. In 20 years on the force, I've never had a purse bag for holy water in the squad car. Turns out the burglar had been hitting houses in our area for months. His full confession cleared over a dozen cases. The detective said whatever you did probably saved him from years more crime. He found religion real quick. Already signed up for seminary school. Lisa's review of her fake

50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating. Drunk guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just. Trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her. Eating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height. Told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson real fighters don't fight in bars. Much liability. Too much to lose. My instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements. He slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch. Told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice. The brunette pulled Away from his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now, some people whispering, shooting me, suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years, was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly, holding it up for the bar to see, while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly, spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up, then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there, doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist, immediately, insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't Safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now, panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these baby little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing in her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, Mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. Mom would tell anyone who'd listen. Her sister has blessed three families, while this one hordes her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy. No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

Off my toxic friend group by creating a fake emergency to see who would actually show up. So I've been feeling like the backup friend for months. It started when I got really sick with the flu last winter. I'm talking fever, can't get out of bed sick. I texted our group chat asking if someone could bring me soup or medicine from the store. Radio silence for 3 hours. And finally Emma responds with, Oof, feel better. And that's it. But two days later, when Brad wanted people to come help him move his couch, four of them showed up immediately. I started paying attention after that. When I'd suggest hanging out, I'd get excuses. When anyone else suggested something, suddenly everyone was free. During conversations, they talk over me or just ignore what I said completely. At restaurants, they'd split the Bill evenly, even though I always ordered the cheapest thing because I was broke from college. The final straw was my birthday last month. I planned this whole thing at Dave and Buster's and invites two weeks early. The day of, I'm sitting there alone at a table for seven. One by one, the cancellations rolled in. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work, just said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story later that night. He was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no, hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help. Tyler hearted the message. That's it. Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything, called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up, showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that, stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times and got shut down. There they were, all six of them posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating drunk. Guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just, trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her, creating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I, I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height, told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson, real fighters don't fight in bars. Too much liability, too much to lose my instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements, slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school, grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about 12. The brunette pulled away. From his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now. Some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly holding it up for the bar to see while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up. Then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist immediately insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now. Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.
NA

Have a friend who used to be your everything. Y'all were always talking, laughing at dumb stuff, venting, being weird together, making the most unhinged inside jokes that nobody else would get. And now they're just gone. Not even gone like we grew apart, but, like, replaced. Like they found a new group and suddenly forgot you existed. And they swear they still care. But the I'm going to sleep early is getting old. Especially when I see you online, in games, in calls with your new little friend group. Like, bro, I'm not stupid. I see the green dot. I see the whole friend list active. Don't lie to me and say it's nothing. You just stopped choosing me. And what hurts more is feeling like I'm just a backup now. Like I'm being kept around just in case the new group drops you or switches up. Like I'm the in case of emergency friend. I'm not a fostering safety net. You used to need me. Now I'm just convenient when you're bored. And I see it, I feel it, and it sucks. But you know what? I'm done begging for space in your life. I'm done waiting for a text back just to see you on Facetime with the new crew. I'm done being loyal to someone who already left me without saying a word. So, yeah, it hurts. It hurts like hell. But I'm not gonna sit here and cry over someone who doesn't miss me. I'm Gonna wipe my tears, put on lip gloss or chapstick, whatever. And remind myself I'm not the problem you fumbled. I was a real one. And when that new group starts acting funny, when you remember what it felt like to have someone who actually cared, just know this friendship doesn't do returns.

What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these creep be little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. I would tell anyone who'd listen her sister has blessed three families, while this one hoards her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.
NA

Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

Have a friend who used to be your everything. Y'all were always talking, laughing at dumb stuff, venting, being weird together, making the most unhinged inside jokes that nobody else would get. And now they're just gone. Not even gone like we grew apart, but, like, replaced. Like they found a new group and suddenly forgot you existed. And they swear they still care. But the I'm going to sleep early is getting old. Especially when I see you online, in games, in calls with your new little friend group. Like, bro, I'm not stupid. I see the green dot. I see the whole friend list active. Don't lie to me and say it's nothing. You just stopped choosing me. And what hurts more is feeling like I'm just a backup now. Like I'm being kept around just in case the new group drops you or switches up. Like I'm the in case of emergency friend. I'm not a fostering safety net. You used to need me. Now I'm just convenient when you're bored. And I see it, I feel it, and it sucks. But you know what? I'm done begging for space in your life. I'm done waiting for a text back just to see you on Facetime with the new crew. I'm done being loyal to someone who already left me without saying a word. So, yeah, it hurts. It hurts like hell. But I'm not gonna sit here and cry over someone who doesn't miss me. I'm Gonna wipe my tears, put on lip gloss or chapstick, whatever. And remind myself I'm not the problem you fumbled. I was a real one. And when that new group starts acting funny, when you remember what it felt like to have someone who actually cared, just know this friendship doesn't do returns.
NA

School thought they were geniuses when they made the Wi-Fi password impossible to crack. They didn't realize they just declared war on 2,000 bored teenagers with nothing but time and spite. It started when Principal Morrison announced the new policy. Students caught sharing the school Wi-Fi password will face immediate suspension. The password was 47 characters long, randomly generated every week and only given to teachers. My friend Marcus was the first to strike back. He brought a 30 foot Ethernet cable to cool and plugged directly into the computer lab wall. When Mr Morrison walked by, Marcus was sitting in the hallway, laptop connected, cable snaking under the door. Marcus, what are you doing? You using wired internet? Sir? The policy only mentions Wi-Fi. That cable is a tripping hazard. I put up caution sign. Marcus had indeed played tiny yellow wet floor signs every three feet along the cable. Mr Morrison updated the policy. No Ethernet cables over six feet. So Marcus brought six separate six foot cables and five friends. They formed a human chain, each person holding a laptop connected to each other, passing internet from the lab to the cafeteria like a digital bucket brigade. This is ridiculous, Mr Morrison said. This is compliance. Marcus replied, each cable is exactly six feet. New rule, no daisy chaining connection. That's when Jennifer got involved. She noticed the smart TV in the library was connected to Wi-Fi. She screen mirrored her phone to the TV, then used The TV's browser to create a hotspot that broadcasted her laptop. Jennifer, you're using the school Wi-Fi? No, sir, I'm using the TV's connection. The TV isn't a student. The TV doesn't need suspension threats, she added sweetly. Mr Morrison banned using school devices as intermediary. Alex took a different approach. He stood outside the teacher's lounge with a clipboard claiming he was conducting a password security audit for his computer science project. He'd ask teachers to write their password down to test memorability. Pattern 3 teachers actually did it before word spread. Alex, this is deception. This is social engineering research, sir. Very educational. Did you get the password? That would be unethical to reveal. Meanwhile, Sarah had noticed something beautiful. The attendance system auto connected to Wi-Fi when teachers logged in. She volunteered as an office aide and memorized the password as it briefly appeared on screen during setup. She didn't share it though. Instead she sold a service. Bring her device, she'd connect it for you, then change your Mac address so it looked like a printer. By week 3, half the school was showing up as HP Laserjet on the network. Why? Why do we have 400 printer? Mr Morrison asked AIT. Those aren't printers, I t replied. Then what are they? Creative student. The arms race escalated. figured out the password was always posted in the teacher's bathroom. Thinking students wouldn't see it there. He used a drone with a camera during lunch when The bathroom was empty. The footage was shaky but readable. Ryan, you flew a drone into school property into the courtyard. Sir, the bathroom window was open. I was investigating ventilation efficiency for my environmental science project. Mr Morrison put curtains on the bathroom window. But the man masterpiece came from quiet Emily. She noticed the school's old Wi-Fi routers were still broadcasting, just hidden from the network list. They'd forgotten to change those password. She connected to school Wi-Fi 2,015 with a password admin 1, 2, 3 and had faster internet than the teachers. Emily, that network was supposed to be decommissioned. Supposed to be isn't the same as was. Sir, how did you even find it? I didn't. My phone did. I have very aggressive auto connect setting. The breaking point came during standardized testing week. The online test required internet, so they had to give all students the password. Within minutes, someone had shared it on a paper airplane that flew across the gym. Then another student wrote it in chalk on the trap. A third person trained the morning announcements kid to say it phonetically while reading the lunch menu. Chicken Tenders, W1 f 1 p at SF, mashed Potatoes, w 0 r d, green Bean 2 dash 0 dash 2 dash 4 chocolate milk, exclamation point, hashtag dollar sign. Mr Morrison called an emergency assembly. Fine, you win. We're going back to open Wi-Fi with content filter. The auditorium erupted. Marcus raised his hand. Mr Morrison about those content filters, don't just don't already found 17 ways around them. Of course you have. The next day, the Wi-Fi password was, please just use salt responsibly, 2,024. Someone changed it to we promise, wink, 2,024. Within an hour, Mr Morrison pretended not to notice. He was tired. The students had won, and honestly, their grades had improved from all the technical research they've been doing. Sometimes the best victory is knowing when you've been outsmarted by 2,000 teenagers who turned your security system into their favorite class.

Wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her? After three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at 2:00am, reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends, authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week, she and maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday, she noticed. You're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes. Obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet. The twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny, because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal. Next one who spends weekends bar hopping, crying about how all men are trash. Crystal, hey, my wife's been telling me about your amazing single. Life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth you guys talk about through the phone? Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out? But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal back petaling. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said, dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting? Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at third 5. Debbie, great news! My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in? I. There's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale, watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard, but they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can go to Yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine. Listening to you repeat their poison every night. Or yours, because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love. You got it. The irony. Her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed to too hard. Janet called later, begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal sent flowers with a card. We were just having girl talk. Debbie showed up at our door crying about how sorry she was. Turns out they wanted to live vicariously through her drama, not actually destroy her marriage. They wanted her to flirt with freedom, not actually choose it. Too late. The papers are filed. She's getting exactly what they convincing her she wanted. And now they're stuck watching their project fall apart, knowing they pushed their friend off a cliff just to see if she'd fly. She didn't. She's crashing, and I'm not catching her. This time yesterday, she asked if we could take a break from the divorce proceedings, just until I figure things out. I showed her the apartment listings I'd bookmarked for her. All in Janet's neighborhood, all way above her budget. Your girls can help with rent, right? Since they're so invested in your freedom? She stared at the prices. Video apartments for two thousand eight hundred dollars. One bedrooms for thirty five hundred dollars. I can't afford any of these. That's weird. Janet said money wasn't important when you're living your truth. Her phone buzz. Text from Crystal. Can you cover drinks tonight? I'm broke until payday. Another Buzz. Debbie, mom says I need to find my own place by Christmas. Then Janet, my ex, stopped paying alimony. Know any good lawyers? My wife looked at her phone, then at me. They're all struggling. No kidding. Almost like their advice came from desperation, not wisdom. She put her head in her hands. What have I done? You chose your sisterhood. Enjoy the membership fees. The moving truck comes tomorrow.

Friends think I'm the innocent one. Wait till they find out what I do for a living. Seven years since graduation, and these women still had me mentally catalogued as the virgin who cried during health class. Lena took it upon herself to arrange a reunion for our high school friend group. I was curious what everyone had been up to, so I went. Big mistake. Second I walked in. Oh, my god. You look exactly the same. Still our innocent baby. They handed me an actual juice box while they opened three bottles of wine. We got you apple juice since you probably don't drink, Ashland said. Like I was 12. Sit here, sweetie. She pointed to the floor. All of them took the couch and chairs. Every single seat except the floor. So there I was, 25 years old, sitting cross legged on Lena's carpet, holding a juice box while they clinked wine glasses above my head. They really thought I was the same shy bookworm from high school. Sure, ladies. Whatever helps you sleep at night. They started playing Never Have I Ever. But stopped. Actually. Wait. She won't have done anything. Ashley nodded to me, and they all laughed. I sipped my juice box. They told relationship stories, then caught themselves. Oops, forgot innocent ears were here. More laughing. Lena actually covered my ears during one story about her honeymoon. I'm 25 years old, and this grown woman covered my ears. They asked me to grab More wine from the kitchen. We need to discuss something real quick. I knew what this was. I walked slow, came back to sudden silence. They've been talking about me, obviously. We were just saying you'd be perfect for Lena's cousin. He's also. Ashley paused. Inexperienced. They all nodded like they'd solved world hunger. But wait, it got worse. Lena took my phone. No phones during Girls Night. You're always so anti social, reading your little books. My phone literally had 57 unread Instagram notifications. But sure, Lena, I'm anti social. We're going to Ashland's Bachelorette next month, April said. But it might be too much for you. The stripper stuff would make you so uncomfortable. They all agreed I'd be traumatized. Remember when she didn't even know what a thong was? That was freshman year. Eleven years ago. I leaned over to grab my juice box from the side table and saw Ashland's phone lit up next to it, the notification preview at the top. Adults only. No Virgin Mary. April. She actually believes the cousin thing. LMAO. I was about to say something when Lena's boyfriend Mark came home with one of his friends, Cooper. Ashlyn practically ran to stand next to Cooper. Nice to see you again. I wondered how often she was invited over, if she recognized him. Lena introduced me as the most innocent person she knows. Mark barely looked at me. Then his neck snapped to look again. His eyes went wide. Really wide. He pulled out his phone. Type something quick, and his face went from confused to shocked. Holy. Mark showed Cooper his phone. The girls stopped talking. What's wrong? Lena asked. Mark looked at me, then at Lena, then back at me. Your innocent friend is. He couldn't finish. Just turned his phone around. Whatever was on that screen made Cooper's jaw drop. No way. No way. He started frantically googling something. The girls tried to see, but Mark pulled the phone back. She. There's a special guest at Denver Con and Seattle. And Cooper kept scrolling, eyes getting wider. This can't be her, Lena said, trying to grab Mark's phone. She doesn't even wear makeup. But Mark and Cooper were having their own conversation now. Both staring at their phones, then at me, then back at their phones. The one from TikTok, Cooper whispered. 3 million views, Mark confirmed. His eyes went huge. Is that. The girls were getting angry. What are you looking at? Ashlyn demanded. Cooper turned red. Actually

Did faking it actually work out for you? I pretended to be my cousin, the substitute teacher for a day and accidentally got my dream job. I was 19, broke as hell, and still waiting to hear back from community college. My cousin Tyler was a substitute teacher who sometimes paid me to drive him around since his car was trash. One Tuesday morning, he calls me, freaking out. Dude, I just rear ended someone. I'm supposed to be at Westbrook Middle School in 20 minutes. If I miss another day, they'll cut me from their sub list. I was eating cereal in my pajamas. That sucks, man. Wait, he said you still have my school I D. From when you helped me move those boxes last month? Yeah, why? I'm serious. Let's go pretend to be me. Take attendance. Keep them quiet. It's just study hall. I laughed. You're insane. Please. They won't even check. Most subs just sit there anyway. It's one period. Something about the desperation in his voice got to me. Plus, I needed money. I threw on Tyler's spare button down shirt that was way too big and drove to the school with his laminated badge. The front desk lady barely looked up. You must be the sub for Miss Peterson's class. Room 2 13. Here's your clipboard. I walked down that hallway trying to look confident while my heart was pounding. The kids were loud, but not crazy. I took attendance, reading names off The roster. When they asked where their teacher was, I said she had a family emergency and today was independent study. Can we work on homework? This girl asked, absolutely, I said, having no clue what else to tell them. For an hour, I just walked around pretending to supervise while they did whatever. Some kid asked me about math, and I said I'd get back to him. Another wanted to use the bathroom, and I let, like, five kids go because I didn't know the rules. The bell rang, and a whole new group of kids walked in. Nobody had told me there were multiple periods. I panicked, but tried to play it cool. Same routine independent study day. The projector wasn't working, so sorry, no video today. I made them read silently and told them I'd be grading papers instead. I just stared at Tyler's lesson plan book, trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Third period came, then fourth. I was making it up as I went. When kids got too loud, I'd say stuff like, remember, this affects your participation grade, even though I had no idea how grading worked. During lunch, I hid in an empty classroom and texted Tyler updates. He kept saying, you're doing great. Just get through the day. Fifth period, this kid asked me about the Revolutionary War assignment. I panicked and said, what do you think the most important battle was? Then I made them debate It. While I googled stuff on my phone under the desk. By sixth period, I was actually getting comfortable. These kids weren't that different from my little brother and his friends. I started a trivia game about random stuff, and they were actually into it. Then the assistant principal walked in. My

Secret ruined your friendship. I was 15 when my crush, Lucia, pulled me aside after chemistry class. We've been close since sixth grades. I need you to promise me something, she whispered. Her pretty eyes not meeting mine. For a moment, I thought she was going to ask me to the dance. I've been working up the courage for weeks. But something in her voice made my chest tighten. Anything I said, that's when she told me about Friday, how she'd been planning it for months. The teachers who ignored her cries for help, her parents who only cared about her grades. She taking her mom's gun from the locked drawer. The next day she was going to publicly end her life. She planned it all out, a live stream during third period when Miss Lillian would be teaching, when Mister Cole would be in the faculty lounge, when everyone who'd failed her would be watching. She'd make sure they'd see, make sure they'd carry it forever. But not you, she said, squeezing my hand. Don't watch. You're the only one who ever really saw me stood there frozen, feeling her fingers intertwined with mine. Something I dreamed about for months, but not like this. Never like this. Lucia, you can't, I whispered. It's the only way they'll learn. She's the only way things will change. That night, I didn't sleep. I stared at her Instagram, scrolling through photos where her smile never quite reached her eyes. Had I missed It the way she'd stopped eating lunch, how she wore long sleeves even when it was warm. The poem she'd started posting, beautiful but dark. So dark I thought about Miss Lillian who was tough but had three kids at home. Mr Cole who was new and trying his best. The other students who'd see it happen live. The trauma that would ripple through our school like a stone dropped in still water. But Lucia trusted me. She'd held my hand. She'd chosen me to confide in. Wasn't that worth something? By the time three a. M. Hit, I was typing and deleting texts to. What if I was overreacting? What if she hated me forever? What if I lost the only girl who'd ever made me feel like I mattered? Then I imagine the alternative, her empty desk and chemistry. Her parents at a funeral instead of graduation. A live stream that could never be unseen, all because I stayed silent. 5:00am, I called the sewer's light prevention hotline. They connected me to the police. My voice cracked as I explained everything. The officer's tone grew urgent asking for details. I wished I didn't have. Lucia's full name, her address, the exact time she'd mentioned you're saving her life, the officer said it felt like I was ending it. They got to Lucia at 7:00am just as she was setting up her phone in her bedroom. Pills were already laid out. The note was already written. The local news Called it a mental health crisis intervention. They interviewed our principal, who promised better resources, more counselors, real change. They never used our names, but Lucia knew. She didn't come back to school for two months. When she did, she wouldn't look at me, wouldn't answer my texts. Her new friends formed a protective wall around her in the hallways. I heard whispers that I betrayed her, that I violated her trust, that I only did it because I couldn't handle rejection. The school did change. They hired two new counselors, started a peer support program, trained teachers on warning signs. Everyone said I'd done the right thing, but I felt like I'd lost everything. Three years later, on graduation day, I found a note in my locker. I instantly recognized Lucia's handwriting. What I read made my heart drop full.
