voice_to_text: What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day, 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these creepy little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniela had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree, volunteering At women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus, mom would tell anyone who'd listen. Her sister has blessed three families while this one hordes her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain. Her hips were destroyed. She had constant infections and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back, told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly, swollen with pregnancy No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. As mom punched the needle into my thigh, I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes, started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyper stimulation syndrome, so severe they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

voice_to_text: Have a friend who used to be your everything. Y'all were always talking, laughing at dumb stuff, venting, being weird together, making the most unhinged inside jokes that nobody else would get. And now they're just gone. Not even gone like we grew apart, but, like, replaced. Like they found a new group and suddenly forgot you existed. And they swear they still care. But the I'm going to sleep early is getting old. Especially when I see you online, in games, in calls with your new little friend group. Like, bro, I'm not stupid. I see the green dot. I see the whole friend list active. Don't lie to me and say it's nothing. You just stopped choosing me. And what hurts more is feeling like I'm just a backup now. Like I'm being kept around just in case the new group drops you or switches up. Like I'm the in case of emergency friend. I'm not a fostering safety net. You used to need me. Now I'm just convenient when you're bored. And I see it, I feel it, and it sucks. But you know what? I'm done begging for space in your life. I'm done waiting for a text back just to see you on Facetime with the new crew. I'm done being loyal to someone who already left me without saying a word. So, yeah, it hurts. It hurts like hell. But I'm not gonna sit here and cry over someone who doesn't miss me. I'm Gonna wipe my tears, put on lip gloss or chapstick, whatever. And remind myself I'm not the problem you fumbled. I was a real one. And when that new group starts acting funny, when you remember what it felt like to have someone who actually cared, just know this friendship doesn't do returns.

voice_to_text: What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these creep be little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. I would tell anyone who'd listen her sister has blessed three families, while this one hoards her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

voice_to_text: 50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating drunk. Guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just, trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her, creating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I, I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height, told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson, real fighters don't fight in bars. Much liability, too much to lose my instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses. With measured movements, he slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping up everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice the brunette. Pulled away from his hand but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now. Some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly holding it up for the bar to see while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up. Then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist immediately insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets Weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now. Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

voice_to_text: I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake, has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the center of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding, I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up, he said. And I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I, I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself and I just can't deal with that stress on my wedding day. The line went quiet for like 10 seconds and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now you're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. She's basically family. I. Tried to explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice. Hope think he changed his mind? He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, he says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted like 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewelry. The caption on the last one says, can't wait to celebrate love today with a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. He's coming anyway. Madison nods. Jake's outside right now arguing with your dad about it. He says he changed his mind and decided to bring her. I'm standing there in my wedding dress, half my makeup done and I have to deal with.

voice_to_text: What do you do when your daughter becomes the most dangerous girl in school? My daughter Charlie accidentally sent 17 boys to the hospital and I've never been more proud of her. I was casually drinking Boba when I got a call from Charlie's school. Mr Jacobs, your daughter is running a gang, a literal gang. She has orchestrated attacks on 17 male students, 17. We're talking about criminal charges here. My daughter, a gang leader? What was this silly goose talking about? Charlie literally cried when she accidentally stepped on a snail last week. But sure, let's go and see what's going on. When I burst into the conference room, I found my baby girl sitting there surrounded by red faced administrators, the principal and two lawyers. It actually called lawyers on my 15 year old daughter who was doodling butterflies on her notebook like this was just another boring school meeting. I sat down next to my daughter Charlie. Tell me what happened. He looked up at me with those same eyes that used to beg for one more bedtime story, completely calm. Remember when you told me that if someone tries to hurt me, I should fight back? I nodded. Well, it wasn't just me who needed to fight back. Principal Donatello slammed a thick folder on the table. Your daughter has been running fight training sessions. She calls it the sisterhood. They have a group chat with coded messages. He's teaching girls how to throw punches. Mr Jacobs, how to break noses, how to cause maximum damage. I raised my hand and told him to shut up before I stole some of his gold teeth. My daughter continued, this one boy has been grabbing girls tooties in the hallway for months. My friend Lila reported it. Principal Donatello said she was just being dramatic. Suddenly the room felt way colder than before, probably because I was glaring daggers at all these lawyers and teachers just standing there in shame. That's not all. A few other boys corner freshman girls every day after second period and rate their bodies out loud on a scale of 1 to 10. When we complained, Principal Donatello said we should take it as a compliment. The room went dead silent. So I started teaching Lila some self defense moves mom taught me before she died. Then Aya asked to learn because boys in her class kept putting his hands on her at dances even when she said stop. Then flora, because three boys surrounded her after school and tried to lift her skirt, she pulled out her phone scrolling through messages. Thirty girls, dad, 30 girls came to me with stories. Every single one had reported it to the administration. Look, she showed me screenshots of emails to Donatello, to teachers, to counselors, all ignored or dismissed. So yeah, I taught them to fight back. The first time that boy tried to grab Lila again, she broke his nose when that Group tried to corner the freshman last Tuesday. Six of my girls were waiting. Those boys Learned real quick that no means no when there are consequences. Donatello's face was purple. This is not how we handle things. You didn't handle anything, Charlie snapped. And I'd never heard her raise her voice like that. You told us to ignore it. You said boys will be boys. Well, of course they will. They're boys, Donatello said. But my daughter wasn't about to stop. Well, guess what? Those boys aren't bothering anyone anymore, are they? This isn't funny, young lady. Donatello sputtered. Those boys were seriously injured. Their parents are threatening to sue the school, to sue you. Charlie actually laughed. She looked him dead in the eye and said, maybe if those boys had Learned to keep their hands to themselves, they wouldn't need medical attention. Funny how they all stopped harassing girls after word got out that we fight back. Now, that's when I couldn't help it. I literally burst out laughing alongside Charlie. And we laughed so hard that we started holding our stomachs in pain. Donatella looked at me like I was insane. Mister Jacobs, surely you understand the severity. Yes, I do understand. I understand that you failed to protect these girls. I understand that my daughter did your job when you wouldn't. I understand that my law firm would be very interested in taking on 30 harassment cases that you ignored. The color drained from his Face. Now wait a minute or no, you wait a minute, you half brained self absorbent piece of manure. I'm not done here. I'm coming back for everything you thought you built. It took me two weeks to get that principal fired and locked up. And Charlie spent that time printing our posters for the sisterhood.

You should have double checked the schedule. If you did, you would have seen that you were supposed to clock in at 9 today. I double checked it yesterday before I left. When did it change? Last night. What time? Eleven PM you're funny, Frankie. I'm not joking around. You realized you were understaff 12 hours ago. So you changed my schedule last minute while I was sleeping and actually expected me to be here two hours earlier. It's your job to show up at your scheduled time and it's your job to effectively communicate any schedule changes in a timely manner. This is a retail store. It's not a hospital. I'm not on call. Just start checking the schedule more often from now on. All right. My fault will do good because I really don't want to write you up, but I will if I have to. I understand. Hey, you should probably start working on finding my replacement for tomorrow. What do you mean you're scheduled to come in tomorrow? Not anymore. I just sent you an email to make it my day off. It's cool, though, because you get to switch the schedules around last minute, so you should be able to figure it out.

At dinner, my grandmother said to me, how was the trip I gave you as a gift? I looked at her confused. What trip? I didn't receive anything. My grandmother's face darkened as she turned to my parents. The fifteen thousand dollar graduation trip to Europe I sent for Diego three months ago. The silence was deafening. My mom started fidgeting with her new designer purse, the one that mysteriously appeared last month along with matching shoes. My dad's gold chain suddenly felt heavier around his neck. And I noticed his expensive watch for the first time. We. We thought it would be better if my mom stamp her newly done nails, tapping nervously on the table. If what? Grandma's voice cut like ice. If you stole from your own son. That's when it all clicked. The sudden shopping sprees every weekend. My sister's new iPhone, iPad and MacBook. Family vacation to Cancun that I wasn't invited to. A kitchen renovation. Dad's new motorcycle sitting in our driveway. They'd stolen my graduation gift and spent it on themselves like it was Christmas morning. My sister Estania, who never worked a day in her life, was wearing earrings that cost more than my monthly gas station salary. Diamond studs that sparkled under the restaurant lights. She and even look up from her plate, too busy admiring her fresh manicure. You gave them everything their entire lives, I said quietly, my voice shaking with years of suppressed anger. And they took the One thing meant for me. The one thing I actually earned. Grandma stood up, her chair scraping against the floor loud enough to make nearby diners turn. 20 years I've watched you favor Estania over Diego like he's invisible. I sent that money specifically for him. With a letter explaining every detail of the trip I planned. My mom's face went white as paper. We never got a letter, I swear. Because you threw it away after cashing the check that had his name on it. The restaurant felt silent, despite other diners around us. Even the waiters seemed to sense the drama unfolding at our table. I couldn't hold back anymore. This explains everything. Why you suddenly had money for mom's Botox appointment and weekly spa days. Why dad bought that Harley Davidson he's been wanting for years. Why Estonia got her nose job and started posting Instagram photos from five star hotels every single week. My grandmother's eyes widened with each revelation. Nose job? Instagram photos? Show me. I pulled out my phone and showed her Estonia's recent posts. Bullside shots at luxury resorts in Miami. Designer shopping halls from Rodeo Drive. First class plane seats with champagne glasses. Expensive restaurant meals that cost more than I made in a week. All time stamped from the past three months. Right after my graduation, I've been working 70 hour weeks at the gas station just to afford my rent and groceries. I continued my voice, getting stronger, eating ramen Noodles for dinner. While watching them feast like royalty, I thought maybe you'd forgotten about my graduation. Or maybe you were disappointed in me. But this whole time, they were living off money meant for me. Grandma scrolled through the photos, her face getting redder with each. This hotel cost $800 a night. I know because I stayed there last year. And this restaurant, their appetizers start at $50. My dad tried to interrupt, loosening his collar nervously. Mom, if you'd just let us explain in the situation. Explain what, Nelson? How you forged my grandson's signature on bank documents? How you intercepted mail addressed specifically to him? How you've been lying to my face for months while spending his money? She reached into her purse and pulled out a thick envelope with legal documents. I brought copies of everything. The bank transfer with Diego's name, the hotel reservations in his name, the flight confirmations, the detailed itinerary. I spent weeks planning for his graduate

My girlfriend said, I need a real man in front of our friends, so I just smiled and left. This morning, my phone exploded with 32 missed calls. It happened at Connor's birthday party. Lauren stood up during dinner and announced to our entire friend group, I've been seeing someone else. I need a real man, not a kindergarten teacher who makes 30 K a year. Everyone went silent. Then Connor actually started clapping. Finally. We've all been saying, you deserve better. The whole table nodded like they'd rehearsed this. I just smiled, put down my fork, and walked out. No drama, no begging. What? They didn't know. I've been teaching kids during the day, but spending nights getting my pilot's license. My broke teacher savings account actually had 180 K from cryptocurrency investments I'd made 3 years ago. But here's the real kicker. My uncle had been battling cancer for months. He owned a small aviation company that did scenic tours and flight training. Two days before Connor's party, he'd asked me to take over the business when he retired. The company was worth 1.2 million, debt free. I've been keeping it quiet while I finished my commercial pilot certification. Lauren knew about my uncle's business, but thought it was just some tiny operation with a couple old planes. She had no idea about the government contracts, the corporate partnerships, or the fact that we were expanding into helicopter tours next year. The night she humiliated me, I called my Uncle and said yes to everything. We started the paperwork immediately. I'd also been secretly applying to international schools. Teaching abroad had always been my dream, but Lauren constantly shut it down, saying it was unrealistic and running away from responsibility. The next week, I put in my transfer request to teach at an international school in Dubai. Posted one photo on Instagram. Me in the cockpit of a small plane with the caption new adventures. Lauren's new real man. Turns out he was married with two kids. His wife found their texts and posted everything on Facebook, tagging Lauren's workplace. She got fired from her marketing job for the drama. The guy's wife also sent screenshots to Lauren's parents, were mortified their daughter was involved with a married man. Meanwhile, my Dubai teaching position came with an 80 five k salary, free housing, and I started a weekend flight instruction business. But the real money came from taking over my uncle's company. Within two months, I'd expanded to corporate charters and landed a contract with a luxury resort chain worth 400 k annually. Connor started following my Instagram again after seeing photos of me flying over Dubai skyline. Even posted a comment, dude had no idea you were doing all this. Tanya from our friend group sent a DM. We all feel terrible about that night. Too late for fake friendship. And even faker.

After Dad's funeral, my family threw my stuff out on the lawn, changed the locks, and said, this house belongs to us now. Get out. I said nothing. Their faces turned pale when the notary revealed the truth. See, my stepmom Cynthia and her twin daughters, Brittany and Ashley, had moved in when I was 12. Dad always treated them like princesses, while I got hand me downs and endless chores. Blood isn't everything, Chloe, he'd say, whenever I complained about the obvious favoritism. The twins got new cars at six. Teen, I got a lecture about being grateful they got college funds. I got told to figure it out yourself. By the time I turned 18, it was clear I wasn't welcome anymore. College isn't for everyone, sweetie, Cynthia cooed, flashing that fake smile. Maybe try community college. There's a nice apartment complex downtown that takes monthly renters. So I left. I worked two jobs. Diner waitress by day, hotel cleaner by night, and clawed my way through nursing school. Six years of exhaustion, but I graduated with honors. I barely visited home every holiday invitation felt more like pity than family. Still, I built my own life. A job at the regional hospital, a small starter house, even a steady relationship with a fellow nurse named Thomas. Life finally felt stable. Then last year, dad was diagnosed with early onset dementia. Suddenly, my phone lit up non stop. We need help with Dad, Cynthia begged. One late night, You're the nurse in the family. You understand this medical stuff. When I came back, the site, it broke me. Dad barely recognized me. The house was filthy, his meds unorganized, while the twins partied by the pool and charged spa trips to his cards. He looked scared, like a child left alone. When I suggested professional caregivers, Cynthia's mask slipped. We're family, Chloe. We can handle our own. Besides, do you know how expensive those people are? They couldn't handle anything. On my next visit, I found dad wandering outside in his pajamas at 3:00am. Neighbors had called the cops. Inside, the air stank from his accidents. No one cleaned up. Britney live streamed makeup tutorials while Ashley planned her next shopping spree. This is neglect, I told Cynthia. Her eyes narrowed. Don't you dare lecture us. Where were you the past 10 years? Now you swoop in like you're better than us. That night, I made a decision. I quit my job, broke up with Thomas, and moved back home. For eight months, I became Dad's full time caregiver. Every morning, I bathed him, dressed him, and fed him. I kept his meds straight, comforted him during episodes, and listened when he had lucid moments. He'd tell me stories about mom, who passed away when I was little. I'm sorry, sweetheart, he whispered. One afternoon, his eyes finally make clear. I wasn't fair to you. Cynthia convinced me treating everyone equally meant giving them more because they weren't Really? Mine. But you were always my real daughter. The twins hated me for it. They wind I was too controlling and making them look bad. All while draining his savings on vacations. When I confronted Brittany, she just smirks. Dad wanted us to be happy. He's not going to live forever, so we might as well enjoy it now. His decline was brutal. I
NA

I ruined my sister's wedding. I was with my ex, N, since I was 13. He was my first. Everything, and I'm talking everything. We got engaged when I was 20, and honestly, life felt perfect, like we had our whole future mapped out. Then six months after our engagement, we found out I was pregnant. We were over the moon about it. N was already picking out baby names and showing me cribs online. But two days later, I miscarried. And that's when everything started falling apart. I went into this deep, dark depression. I couldn't get out of bed some days. And tried to help at first, but then he started saying things, like, maybe it happened for a reason. Maybe we weren't ready. The worst part was when he said I should have been more careful, like it was somehow my fault. Started fighting constantly. He'd blame me. I'd scream at him. That he didn't understand what it felt like to lose something growing inside you. It got so bad, we decided to separate for a while. That while turned into a whole year. I went to therapy, worked on healing myself, and even came to a few sessions with me, which gave me hope that maybe we could fix things. When I turned 23, we decided to try again. But something was off. And was distant, like he was hiding something from me. Get weird about his phone, wouldn't look me in the eyes when we Talked about the future. I started overthinking everything, wondering if he blamed me for the miscarriage. It was eating me alive. So I did something I'm not proud of. I went through his phone. That's when I found out that during our separation year, he'd been texting my sister Emma constantly. At first it looked innocent, just him venting about our relationship. But then the messages got flirtier. Then there were pictures. Then there were messages about meeting up. My own sister had been sleeping with my ex while I was falling apart over losing our baby. The worst part. She was pregnant with his baby. And my parents knew. My friends knew. Everyone knew except me. Kicked out immediately and cut off everyone who had kept the secret from me. I felt so betrayed and alone. I thought maybe with time I could process this and figure out how to move forward. Then two weeks ago, I got a wedding invitation in the mail. My sister and Ann were getting married. Something inside me just snapped. I got drunk, like really drunk, and took a cab to my parents house where they were throwing them an engagement party. I walked into that house with my hair a mess, still in my pajamas, and gave the most epic fuck you speech of my life. I told everyone exactly what I thought of them. How they were all disgusting for keeping this from me. How they helped my sister steal my Life. While I was grieving, my sister ran upstairs crying, and my parents started yelling at me for ruining their precious party. That's when my sister came back downstairs and said the most evil thing I've ever heard in my life. She looked me dead in the eyes and said, maybe your baby died for a reason, so I could get my happy ending. The room went completely silent. Even my parents looked shocked. I just stared.

Flights are one. $400 each. My mom said, if you can't keep up, don't bother coming. She was talking about my cousin Justin's destination wedding in Bali. The whole family was going. Aunts, uncles, grandparents, everyone. Except, apparently, me. I'm a freelance graphic designer, and mom's always treated my career like it's just a hobby. I understand, I said, quietly, stirring my coffee. Have fun taking pictures. My sister Kate rolled her eyes. Maybe if you got a real job instead of playing on your computer. Computer all day. What they didn't know was that I've been secretly working with Justin for six months. He'd hired me to design his entire wedding brand after seeing my portfolio online. Invitations, programs, well come bags, ceremony signage, reception menus, everything. The whole aesthetic was mine. And he paid me $8,000 up front, with another $3,000 due on delivery. Justin made me swear to keep it secret because he wanted to surprise everyone with how professional and beautiful everything would look. Trust me, he'd said. They're going to lose their minds when they see this stuff. The family group chat was buzzing for weeks about their flights, hotels, and outfits. I watched them plan every detail while pretending I wasn't involved. Mom even posted photos of her new vacation wardrobe with captions like when your son can't afford family trips. Three days before the wedding, my phone rang at 2:00am. Justin was panicking. Dude, we have a massive problem. The resort's printer completely Broke down and all our wedding materials are stuck in Indonesian customs. Some paperwork issue. We have nothing. No programs, no signs, no table cards. The wedding planner is freaking out. I sat up in bed. What do you need? Can you fly out here and handle this? You know the designs better than anyone. I'll cover your flight, hotel, food, everything. Plus I'll pay you the final 3 thousand dollars and throw in another 2 thousand dollar bonus. I'm desperate, man. I was already opening my laptop to book flights. Send me the hotel info. I'll be there tomorrow. You're a lifesaver. But hey, still, keep it secret until the ceremony. I want this to be the reveal. Twenty four hours later, I was in a Balinese print shop working with local vendors to recreate everything. The language barrier was intense, but somehow we made it work. I spent two straight days running between the resort print shops and flower markets, coordinating every detail. The morning of the wedding, I was on the beach at sunrise setting up ceremony decorations when I heard familiar voices. My family was walking down the path from the hotel all dressed up and looking around confused. Why does this look so professional? My aunt was saying. This doesn't look like typical resort stuff. I ducked behind the altar setup, grinning to myself. My mom spotted me first. Her face went completely white. Jonah! What? How are you here? You said you couldn't afford The flight, Kate's mouth literally fell open. Did you borrow money? Please tell me you didn't go into debt for this. Before I could answer, Justin appeared in his pre ceremony casual clothes, beaming. He walked straight over and threw his arm around my shoulders. Bored it. Your son didn't pay a dime to be here. I flew him out. He gestured to all the beautiful decorations around us. Meet my secret wedding designer. Joan has been creating our entire wedding aesthetic for months. Every invitation you guys got, every program you'll read today, every single detail you're going to Instagram. That's all his work.
NA

After my father in law's funeral, my jobless wife inherited $379 million. Suddenly, she demanded a divorce, saying, you're useless to me now. I replied, don't regret this later. Lol. The funeral was Tuesday. By Friday, she was already shopping for a mansion in Beverly Hills. I don't need you anymore, she said, tossing divorce papers on our kitchen table next to my unemployment check. I'm finally free from dead weight. I just smiled and signed them without reading. She thought I was an idiot who'd given up. But here's what she didn't know. I've been having secret conversations with her father for months. Before he died, he'd called me one evening, voice shaking with disappointment. Son, I need to tell you something about Kimberly. She's been pressuring me to change my will. She wants me to cut out her brother and sister completely. Says they don't deserve anything because they abandoned me. That wasn't true. Her siblings lived across the country, but called him daily. Kimberly barely visited unless she needed money. There's more he can continued. I caught her going through my financial documents last week. She was photographing my bank statements and investment portfolios. When I confronted her, she said she was just helping me organize. That's when he told me his plan. The will Kimberly knew about. It was fake. He'd shown it to her on purpose to test her character. The real will was locked in a different lawyer's safe. Two weeks after the funeral, we're at What she thinks is the final divorce meeting. She struts in wearing a five thousand dollar Chanel dress and diamond earrings that cost more than my car. She's already bragging about her new Porsche in the mansion she put a deposit on. This is so exciting, she tells the lawyer. I can finally live the life I deserve. No more supporting a jobless husband who brings nothing to the table. The inheritance lawyer walks in with a thick leather folder. I recognize him immediately. It's Martin Lee, her father's real attorney, not the junior associate who'd been handling the official proceedings. Missus Benjamin, son, I'm afraid there's been a significant misunderstanding, he says calmly. Smile falters slightly. What kind of misunderstanding? The will was clear. I inherited everything. He opens the folder and slides a document across the mahogany table. This is your father's actual will, executed just three months before his death. The document you've been referencing was. Let's call it a preliminary draft. She grabs the papers, her manicured nails clicking against the desk. What are you talking about? This can't be right. Martin points to the highlighted section. Your father was quite specific. He left the entire estate to your husband, Benjamin here, with explicit instructions that you receive nothing if you initiated divorce proceedings within two years of his death. The color drains from her face. That's impossible.

My father demanded a DNA test for my grandfather's inheritance. I've been the family disappointment for 23 years while my perfect older brother Kyle got everything handed to him when Grandpa died and left me his house in his will. Dad absolutely lost it. There's no way that senile old man left you anything, he snarled, pacing around our kitchen like a king aged animal. You're probably not even my real son. Anyway, your mother was sleeping around before we got married. My brother Kyle smirked from the corner. Yeah, remember how wild mom was back in college? Dad's got a point. My stepmother Linda chimed in with that fake sweet voice she always used. Honey, we just want what's fair for the real family. You understand, right? They gave me 48 hours to take a paternity test or they challenge the will in court. The whole extended family was already texting about it in the group chat, calling me a fraud and a bastard. Here's what none of them knew. I've been secretly taking care of Grandpa for the past two years while they all ignored him. Every single doctor's appointment when his arthritis got bad, every grocery run when he couldn't drive anymore, every lonely evening when he just wanted someone to talk to about grandma. I also knew about the second will he'd written just three months before he died. The next morning, dad changed the locks on Grandpa's house when I showed up with my key. I couldn't get in. My stuff was piled on the front lawn and garbage bags. Trespassing, dad yelled from the window. This is family property until you prove you belong here, I called the police. Within an hour, Officer Ortiz was standing in the driveway reading the will. Sir, according to this legal document, your son owns this property. You're the one trespassing. Dad's face went red as they made him give me the new keys. The neighbors were all watching from their windows. Test day arrived at the family lawyer's office. The whole crew showed up like it was some kind of Celebration. Dad wore his best suit and kept checking his Rolex, probably already planning how to spend what he thought would be his inheritance money. Kyle brought his new girlfriend to show off. You're about to see how we handle fake family members, he told her loudly. Linda kept taking selfies, probably planning to post about their victory later. Uncle Robert and Aunt Deborah drove in from two states away just to witness my humiliation. The family group chat had been buzzing for days about this showdown. The DNA results came back after the longest hour of my life, 99.9% match. I was definitely Dad's biological son. Dad's victory dance and high fives with Kyle lasted exactly 10 seconds. However, the lawyer continued clearing his throat. There's something else the family needs to know about. Your grandfather actually left a second more recent will that supersedes the First one, the room went dead silent. You could hear Linda's phone camera clicking. I pulled out my phone and played a video I'd recorded with Grandpa just weeks before he passed. His shaky but determined voice filled the entire office. To my son Harold and his family, who abandoned me in my final years, who only called when they needed money, you get absolutely nothing. To my grandson Noah, who stayed by my side, who drove me to chemo appointment.

What's the craziest bet you ever did? I was six beers deep at the hotel bar when Alan put $300 on the counter. Bet you can't give a toast at that wedding next door. We could hear the DJ through the wall asking for speakers. My girlfriend had just dumped me over text for never taking risks or putting myself out there. I've been telling my friends all night that I could charm anyone and Alan decided to test me. The guys all leaned in to see if I'd take the bet. The reception was at that point where they open the mic to anyone who wants to speak. My drunk plan was simple. I pretend to work with the groom and give a generic business guy speech. Rob told me dedication and commitment were perfect wedding words. The ballroom doors were open and people were walking freely between spaces. My shirt was wrinkled, but the lights were dim enough to hide it. I walked in from the hotel bar and when the DJ saw me approaching the microphone, he looked relieved that someone finally volunteered. I grabbed the microphone and a champagne glass from a passing waiter and told everyone I needed a moment outside because big moments get to me. While people smiled and nodded and the bride sat up to listen, I started with safe stuff about knowing the groom from work and watching him grow as a professional before pointing at the bride and saying this. Guy talks about you the way he talks about his biggest wins. Everyone laughed while the groom mouth thank you from his table with tears forming in his eyes. I kept going with generic lines about late nights at the office paying off. Remember those long nights when everything seemed impossible, I said, getting nods from everyone who'd ever worked late. Well, now you found someone worth losing sleep for. My voice cracked when I mentioned what makes a good partnership because that's what my ex said I couldn't do. But I pushed through and finished by saying they deserved all the happiness in the world. The room exploded with applause and the groom caught me in a huge hug saying it meant everything. Probably too emotional and drunk to wonder why he didn't remember me. And that's when Natalie walked up with dark hair and a smile that made me forget why I was there. She pressed a napkin with her purple penned number into my hand while saying, I work for the wedding planner and I've never heard such a beautiful toast from a business guy. And we ended up dancing for a few songs while my friends watched from the doorway in shock. During our last dance, Natalie asked, coffee sometime right in my ear and I said yes immediately. When my friends texted that the hotel bar was closing, she squeezed my hand making me promise to call before I left feeling better than I had In weeks, two weeks later, the bride tried to send me a thank you card but couldn't figure out who I was. The wedding planner pulled security footage and saw me walking in from the public bar and grabbing a glass from their reception waiter. The hotel banned me using my credit card information from the bar tab. That night, Natalie texted the planner.

What strange parenting technique did you experience that you didn't realize was unusual until much later? Growing up, my parents had a unique approach to settling sibling disputes that I assumed was universal until college roommate conversations proved otherwise. Whenever my sister and I fought over something, a toy, TV choice, front seat privileges, my parents would immediately implement what they called the auction. They'd take whatever we were fighting about and announce bidding starts at 10 minutes. This meant we had to bid chore time to win the disputed item. My sister might open with 15 minutes of dishes, which I'd counter with 20 minutes of yard work. The bidding continued until one of us dropped out, unwilling to commit more chore time. The winner got the coveted item. The loser did nothing. But the winner had to complete their bid in short time before enjoying their prize. The genius part, if our parents suspected we were fighting just to get attention, they'd add auction minimums, starting bids of 30+ minutes. That made us quickly decide if the argument was actually worth it. By age 10, my sister and I had developed complex economic analyses of whether conflicts were worth the chore cost. We'd negotiate privately before even involving our parents because we understood the true price of disagreement. In college, I mentioned the auction to my roommates during a dispute over parking spaces. They stared at me like I'd suggested we solve it through ritual combat. That's when I realised most families don't run their homes like micro economic systems, teaching cost benefit analysis. As an adult, I recognise how brilliant it was. My parents never had to determine who was right. They simply created a system where we assigned our own value to our desires and paid accordingly. My sister and I rarely fight as adults. Everything seems negotiable after growing up with the auction.

My daughter Lily had just started kindergarten when I got a notification from the class group chat. Hi, everyone, I'm Sarah Miller, and my daughter Tiffany just transferred here today. The chat lit up with a string of welcomes and hellos. Just as I was about to type out my own greeting, a huge block of text appeared. Important notice from Tiffany's mom. Girls in the class, please take note. Starting next week, I'll be posting a picture of what my daughter is wearing each day. Please make sure your child doesn't wear the same thing. Also, I request that everyone please switch to the same brand of laundry detergent we use. My daughter has a very sensitive nose and can't tolerate other scents. Finally, my daughter was a C section baby and is a bit timid, so I ask you to tell your children not to bully her and make sure she's always treated with priority. Wow. I couldn't help but think, this isn't just a new student. This is a royal princess who's slumming it with us commoners. Some of the moms in the chat were quick to push back. Karen's mom are you serious? What my kid wears is none of your business. Why should we have to cater to you? Jessica's mom exactly! And we're supposed to all use your detergent? My son has allergies, too, and we use specific stuff. Yeah, who made your kid the queen of the class? My kid is special too. The Chat quickly devolved into a debate. Usually I just chuckled at the ridiculous things these parents said in the group chat. The class teacher was the administrator, and she'd usually step in to calm things down. I didn't see a problem, so I just muted the chat to get some work done. Then I got a DM. It was from Alyssa, whose daughter Emily was friends with Lily. Hey, Sarah, you got it.

The mechanic fixing my car asked me, did your dad buy this used from someone local? Yeah, he bought it from some guy on Craigslist about 3 months ago, but I'm the one who drives it mostly now, since I just got my license. The mechanic wiped his hands on a rag and walked me around to the front of my Subaru Legacy, while my dad waited in the shop's lobby, scrolling through his phone, probably answering work emails. We'd brought the car in for a simple oil change, but the mechanic had been under there for way longer than normal, and now his face looked like someone had died. He popped the hood and pointed a flashlight at something underneath that I couldn't really see from where I was standing, but his hand was trembling. You need to get your dad over here right now. And nobody drives this car again until we fix this. His voice was steady, but there was something in his eyes that made my stomach drop, like when you miss a step going downstairs. Someone wanted you dead, and they almost succeeded. Another day or two of driving this thing and you wouldn't be standing here. What's wrong with it? I asked. Well, texting my dad to come outside immediately, but the mechanic was already taking pictures with his phone and muttering about calling the police, which made no sense for a car repair. My dad pushed through the door, looking annoyed because he'd Been in the middle of a work hall. But his expression changed when he saw the mechanic's face. The mechanic grabbed a trouble light and aimed it at the brake lines near the master cylinder, showing us cuts that went almost all the way through the metal. These were sliced to leak slowly over weeks, so when they finally failed, it would look like a magic accident that nobody would question. He moved the light to show three different cut points, all at calculated angles that would have failed simultaneously. Professional job. But they made one mistake. They used a specific cutting pattern I've only seen once before. My dad's face went white as he stared at the sabotaged brake lines. And I remembered last week when I'd slammed the brakes to avoid a dog and felt them go completely soft for a terrifying second before catching. The mechanic kept staring at the cuts like they were a signature, and then walked to the car's rear bumper, where there was a faded church sticker. Was there a Saint medallion hanging from the rearview mirror when you bought it? My dad nodded slowly, and the mechanic's hands started shaking worse as he stepped back from the car. This belonged to my sister Nina, and that cutting pattern is exactly how her husband Greg showed me to slice fishing line when we went deep sea fishing last year. He pulled out his phone and started scrolling through photos until he found one Of this exact car in a driveway with the same dent in the passenger door. She sold it without telling him because she was leaving him after he put her in the hospital twice, but he must have thought she still had it. The and it called someone, and I heard him say frantically, Nina, you need to get out of that apartment right now. Greg knows where you are, and he already tried to kill you once. My dad called 9 1 1, while the mechanic stayed on with his sister, telling her to pack nothing and just drive to the police station immediately. The officers arrived fast, with their lights flashing, and treated our car like an attempted murder scene, while the mechanic explained that Greg had been escalating his violence, and had told multiple people at their church that if he couldn't have Nina, nobody would, especially not some other man. The detective examined the brake lines with gloved hands and confirmed this was designed to fail catastrophically at high speed, probably while going downhill or merging onto the highway. The way these are cut, you'd have about two seconds of pumping the pedal before total brake failure, at which point most people would already be in a fatal collision. He looked at me and asked if I'd noticed anything unusual.

When did you realize your life was in danger? Megan grabbed my arm while we were shopping for jeans and whispered, don't turn around. But is that guy following us? I glanced over my shoulder and saw a man in a gray hoodie looking at his phone that was angled toward us. We noticed him earlier in the food court, then again at Sephora. We decided to test it and left, suddenly walking toward Forever 21. And there he was at the escalator. Now my heart was racing. Megan said we should go to security, but I felt stupid because what would we say? That some guy was shopping in the same stores? We couldn't see his face clearly under the hood, and he wasn't doing anything obviously threatening, just existing near us. We ducked into the crowded store and wove through racks of clothes trying to lose him. I saw him enter and stop near the entrance, scanning the store systematically row by row. We crouched behind a display and Megan whispered, why would someone follow us? What if he's some creep who saw us and just decided we were easy targets? That my skin crawl. We waited until he moved deeper into the store, then slipped out the side entrance. We speed walked toward the department store, figuring we could cut through to the parking garage. My hands were shaking as I texted my roommate where we were just in case something happened. We made it To the department store and started weaving through the makeup counters, past the jewelry, toward the back exit. I was starting to breathe normally again when Megan froze. He was there again, coming through the main entrance, moving faster now, like he knew we spotted him and didn't care about being subtle anymore. We ran toward the back exit, and I could hear footsteps behind us, not running, but walking fast, steady, deliberate, like he we couldn't really escape. An employee asked if we needed help, and I wanted to scream yes, but Megan pulled me along, saying, the exits right there. We burst into the parking garage, and the temperature dropped instantly. Cold concrete and shadows everywhere. Ran toward where I parked on level 3. I fumbled for my keys while we ran, my hands shaking so bad I dropped them and they skittered across the concrete. Megan grabbed them and we reached my car in a dark corner where I parked that morning. She clicked the unlock button, but nothing happened. She tried again, pressing it desperately, but still nothing. The battery in the key FOB must have died. I grabbed the keys to manually unlock it, but my hands were shaking too much to get the key in the lock. That's when we heard the garage door slam open behind us, the sound echoing off every surface. He was coming, walking straight towards us with purpose. I finally got the key in, but it wouldn't turn like The lock was jammed or frozen from sitting all. Megan was pulling on the door handle frantically, saying, come on, come on, come on. He was getting closer, steady footsteps echoing off concrete. And now he was speeding up, almost jogging. I was fighting with the key, trying to force it, and it finally turned, but the door wouldn't open. Something was wrong with it, stuck or broken. He was 20 feet away now, and I saw him reach into his jacket pocket, pulling something out that glinted. Megan turned to faith

My girlfriend bragged she could sleep with my best friend, and I blame him instead of her. So I said, try me. My girlfriend Irene had this theory about me and my best friend Lance. She brought it up during game night at our place when she'd had too much wine. You know what's funny, Jonah? She said with a nasty smile. You're so pathetic, I could literally f lance in our bed. And you'd probably apologize to him for being in the way. Everyone went quiet. Lance's fiance, Marina, looked double. I told her to stop being weird. I'm serious, Irene continued, as if she hadn't just said something insane. You're so scared of confrontation, you'd rather lose your best friend than admit your girlfriend crossed the line. Lance tried to change the subject, but Irene kept going. I could probably seduce him right in front of you and you'd find a way to blame him for it. Men always blame each other. Never the woman. I set down my cards and look at her. That's sick, Irene, she laughed. But it's true. You're too weak to stop me and too pathetic to leave me. Marina said we should call it a night. As everyone left, Irene whispered, I could prove at any time. I said, go ahead. Try. The next few weeks, Irene started testing boundaries. She'd text Lance about random things, always screenshotting his polite responses to show me. See how quick he answers. She'd say she Started dressing differently when we hung out with them. Touching Lance's arm when she laughed, sitting too close on the couch. Marina noticed, Lance noticed, everyone noticed. But nobody said anything because. What do you say? That's when I texted Lance privately, told him I had enough with everything he was saying. He was also really pissed. Marina was furious that she hadn't stopped. They wanted to confront her immediately, but I had a different idea. Let her try whatever she was planning, but be ready. Document everything. Show everyone who she really was. Then Lance announced his birthday party plans. Just close friends at his and Marina's apartment. Irene immediately said, perfect. Maybe I'll give him a special present. She spent two hours getting ready, wearing a dress I'd never seen before. At the party, she started drinking immediately, working her way closer to Lance with each drink. I watched her watch me, making sure I saw every move. She'd touch his chest, look at me, laugh at his jokes, look at me. Around 10 p m, she made her move. Lance went to his bedroom to grab his jacket for Marina, who was cold. Irene followed him, giving me one last smirk before disappearing down the hallway. Marina had excused herself. Five and it's earlier. Hiding in their walk in closet with her phone ready. I stayed in the living room, listening. Irene's voice carried through the walls. Marina doesn't have to know. Jonah is too weak to Do anything anyway, he'll blame you, not me. That's what weak men do. Lance's voice came next. Irene! Get off me! What are you doing, then? Louder! I said stop! This is assault! Come on. No one has to know if you don't. That's when Marina stepped out of

What did your sibling do to reveal their monstrous nature? I always thought my older brother Kyle was just a tech geek. He spent hours in our garage working on what he called projects, building computers, fixing phones, that kind of stuff. Mom and dad were proud of his skills. He was 19 and I was 12, so I mostly stayed out of his way. But something felt off about Kyle. He always seemed to know things he shouldn't. Like when I told my friend Jake a secret over the phone in my room, Kyle would make weird comments about it the next day. Or when my sister Emma practiced her dance routines alone, he tease her about specific moves she'd messed up. At first, I thought he was just good at guessing. Everything changed on a Tuesday after school. I was looking for my phone charger and decided to check the air vent above my bed where I sometimes hid stuff. That's when I felt something that didn't belong. A tiny black camera no bigger than a quarter stuck to the inside of the vent with electrical tape. My hands were shaking as I pulled it out. There were thin wires running from it that disappeared deeper into the ductwork. Followed the wires outside to where they LED straight into Kyle's garage workshop. That night, I waited until Kyle went to his friend's house. I snuck into the garage and nearly threw up at what I found. Three computer Monitors sat on his workbench, each showing live video feeds. One showed my room. Another showed Emma's room. The third showed the hallway right outside our bathroom. I watched myself sleeping from the night before on one of the recorded files. Kyle had been watching me for who knows how long. Next morning, I cornered Kyle in the kitchen while mom was getting ready for work. I found your cameras, I said, trying to keep my voice steady. Kyle didn't even look surprised. He just grinned and kept eating his cereal. Don't be so dramatic, Liam. It's just for fun. I like knowing what's going on around here. You're spying on us. That's sick. It's not spying if it's my own house, he said, laughing. Besides, what are you gonna do about it? I told mom and dad. That afternoon, Kyle spun some story.

What happened when my parents blamed me for my brother's chaos? When I turned eighteen, my parents sat me down for what they called a long overdue conversation. You need to move out, mom announced. Every disaster in this house happens because you're constantly provoking Gonzales. I stared in disbelief while my 14 year old brother Gonzales sat there looking innocent. The kitchen fire last week, the destroyed laptop, the hole in the garage door. It's always when you two are together. We need peace. You have two weeks to find somewhere else to live. Gonzalez smiled sweetly. I just want our family to be safe, he said, hiding behind my parents backs as he mouth goodbye. Fine. If they wanted me to stop protecting them from Hurricane Gonzalez, I'd wish them good luck. The day after I moved out, Gonzalez decided to upgrade the house's electrical system. Every light in the neighborhood now flickered in rhythm with our toaster. When mom tried to make toast. It activated the garage door, the ceiling fans, and somehow started Dad's car. The power company had to shut down our entire grid and rewire our house. The Bill was $3,000. It's synchronized living, Gonzalez explained proudly to the electrician. Next, he discovered online chemistry tutorials without me. Secretly replacing his chemicals with baking soda, he created what he called rainbow smoke bombs in the kitchen. But they were actually just straight up acid that ate through the tiles and corrupted all the food. Hazmat had to gut our kitchen entirely. Total cost $8,000. Why didn't you tell us this would happen? Mom yelled at me through the phone. I did. You just never listened. I reminded her. Then Gonzales revealed he'd been training squirrels in the attic. They're my army, he explained, as 20 squirrels wearing tiny tin foil hats ended through the ceiling during Dad's Zoom meeting with his boss. Dad got fired on the spot. Then came the car improvement incident. Gonzalez filled Dad's gas tank with what he called Super Juice, a mixture of energy drinks, lighter fluid, and glitter. The car made it exactly 12 feet before the engine shot through the hood like a rocket landing in our neighbor's pool. The neighbors

My sister seduced my husband during my cancer treatment, so I became the disease in her perfect life. Savannah had been stealing my moment since we were kids. At my 10th birthday, she blew out my candles to help me. At my high school graduation, she wore white and told everyone we were both graduating, even though she was a sophomore. At my engagement dinner, she spent the night telling Nathan's family how she introduced us, even though they met at work. The cancer diagnosis was just another moment for her to steal. Two days after my diagnosis, Savannah moved into our house without asking. She made a Caringbridge page but wrote everything from her perspective. Every post started with how hard it was for her to watch me suffer. Friends praised her dedication while I spent hours throwing up from chemo. Three weeks in, I asked if Nathan could drive me to appointment. Sometimes she started crying and said I was pushing her away during the hardest time of her life. She posted about how sick people lash out at caregivers. Nathan said I should apologize. By month 2, she reorganized our entire house. I moved Nathan's things to the guest room and started screaming my calls. She turned away visitors, saying stress would hurt my recovery. She joined Nathan for evening runs to discuss my care. They'd come back sweaty and avoid eye contact. Four months into treatment, my white count dropped and the nurse sent me home. Early, I took an Uber because Savannah had our car for shopping. I heard voices from our bedroom and climbed the stairs slowly. When I opened the door, they were in my bed. Savannah was wearing the anniversary pajamas Nathan bought me. She jumped up wearing my robe and rushed over with fake concern. She asked why I was home early and said I must be confused from the medications. She. I actually told Nathan to call my nurse about hallucinations. He just sat there in his boxers while she performed. My legs gave out. I slid down the door frame, realizing she'd stolen my husband while I was fighting cancer. Nathan finally said, I've been distant and Savannah understood his stress better. He compared his stress to my cancer. They moved out next week. Savannah told everyone I'd become paranoid from treatment. She posted about watching loved ones lose themselves to illness. People praised her for setting boundaries. Most friends believed her. I finished three months of treatment alone. No one cheered when I rang the bell. I recorded it myself but deleted it that night on my bathroom floor. I decided Savannah had stolen from me my whole life. This time would be different. During recovery, I studied Savannah's patterns like I was planning a battle. I made fake social media accounts to track her posts and learn her routines. Found out she had joined a fancy yoga studio and was flirting with her married instructor. She worked At a marketing firm downtown and volunteered for their charity events. She and Nathan had rented a condo near the river. I mapped out her entire life and looked for weak spots. Joined her yoga studio but went to different class times. I became friends with the instructor's wife at the juice bar next door. We bonded over books and recovery stories without me mentioning Savannah. When Savannah started asking for private sessions, his wife was already suspicious. She found their text messages and confronted Savannah in the packed studio lobby. She read every flirty message out loud. While Savannah tried to cry her way out, the entire studio turned against her. Next, I joined the board of her company's charity foundation as a cancer survivor advocate. At their annual gala, I gave a speech about finding strength during treatment. I started by describing the loneliness of chemo and how cancer strips away.

When did you realize your parents shouldn't have had kids? I was 9 when my mom left me at Walmart, not by accident. She literally told me to sit on the bench by the entrance and wait while she went to get stuff from her car. I waited three hours. A store worker named Beth found me there when the sun was going down. She had this worried look and asked where my parents were. I told her my mom said she'd be right back. Beth called security, then the cops. Mom showed up 20 minutes after the police arrived. No panic, no tears, just annoyed that I made a scene. She told the officer she forgot I was there because she had errands to run, like I was a grocery bag she left behind. Cop looked at her weird and asked how you forget your kid. Mom just shrugged and said kids are supposed to stay where you put them. That wasn't even the worst part. Two weeks later, she did it again at the mall. This time I waited four hours until mall security found me asleep on a food court chair. When mom finally came back, she was carrying shopping bags from stores that weren't even in that mall. She'd literally gone somewhere else entirely. The security guy was pissed. He asked if this happened before and I told him about Walmart. His face went red and he made my mom sit there while he called someone. I don't know who, but afterward, mom was really quiet on the drive home. At home, dad was watching t. V. Like nothing happened. When I told him what happened, he just said, your mother's got a lot on her mind. Like that explained leaving your kid places. Third time I was ready. We went to target and mom pulled the same move, but this time I followed her to the parking lot and watched her drive away. I went back inside and found the customer service desk myself. The lady there was super nice. Her name was Carol and she gave me a juice box while we waited. When mom came back, two hours.

I didn't change my annual backyard party plans for my boyfriend and his kids. Every August for like six years, I host this huge end of summer party in my backyard. It's basically become the neighborhood event that everyone looks forward to. Kids run around screaming with popsicles. Parents drink beer and complain about going back to school shopping. And by 9:00, the little ones are dragged inside to sleep while the adults keep the party going until like midnight. My house is literally right next to the backyard, so when my kids, Mia and Tyler, get tired, I just take them upstairs, tuck them in and leave the bedroom window open so I can hear everything going on outside. They have my old iPhone, too, so if anything happens, they can just text me. It's worked perfectly for years. This year, I invited my boyfriend, Kevin, and his two kids, Emma and Jake. We've been together for 6 months, which felt like long enough to include them in my tradition. But when I explained how the night usually goes, Kevin's face got all weird. He said he wasn't comfortable with his kids sleeping at my place since they'd never stayed over before. Okay, fair enough. Then he said he didn't like the idea of putting them to bed while he stayed outside with me. didn't want to leave early with them while I stayed at my own party. Basically, nothing about my setup worked for him. Told him I totally understood and that they didn't have to come. Like this isn't some random hangout I threw together last minute. This is an annual thing with a format that works for everyone who's been coming for years. If it doesn't work for you, then don't come. No big deal. But Kevin lost his mind, started saying that he and his kids weren't actually welcome because of how I set everything up, that I should have changed the whole party just for them, that any good girlfriend would leave her own party early to put his kids to bed and stay with them. The party happened without them. It was actually amazing. Missus Chen from next door brought her famous potato salad. The Henderson kids had a water balloon fight that soaked half the adults. And Around 10:30, when all the kids were asleep, we played music and talked until almost 1 in the morning. I didn't think about Kevin once until my phone started buzzing. He'd been texting me all night asking why I wasn't calling him, said I should have made time during my own party to check in with him, that he felt left out and ignored. I saw the messages when I was cleaning up and just put my phone away. The next day he came over and we had this massive fight. He kept saying I chose my neighbors over him and his kids, that I prioritized some stupid tradition over our relationship. That if I really cared about him, I would have either changed the party format or left early to spend time with them. I, I told him that was insane. This party happens one night a year. Everyone knows the deal. His kids would have had fun until bedtime and then they could have gone home or figured something else out. But changing a six year tradition for someone I've been dating for six months, making all my neighbours adapt to his comfort level, leaving my own party early, not happening. He said I was selfish and not ready for a real relationship with someone who has kids. But I clearly wasn't thinking long term about us if I wasn't willing to make adjustments. I said maybe he was right because someone who expected me to completely rearrange my life after six months probably wasn't someone I wanted to think long term about anyway. We broke up. Two days later, he sent me this long text about how I'd realise what I lost when I was alone at next year's party.

When did your biggest critic realise they owed you everything? My son turned eight last Saturday and his mom threw him this huge party at her parents house with bouncy castles and a magician, probably 50 people there. I showed up with my gift wrapped in newspaper because I couldn't afford wrapping paper. And my ex wife's sister actually laughed out loud when she saw it. Her husband pulled me aside and said I should be embarrassed showing my face here when everyone knows I'm three months behind on child support and asked if I even knew what grade he was in. I wanted to tell him that I actually knew his teacher personally because I've been volunteering at his school every lunch hour. But instead I just stood there and took it because arguing would just make everything worse for my boy. The whole party was basically two hours of my ex wife's family taking turns humiliating me while I tried to stay invisible near the fence. Her mom kept making these loud comments about how some fathers actually provide for their children. And her dad walked past me carrying my son's new bike and said maybe someday I could afford to buy my child something that didn't come from a thrift store. When they brought out the cake and my son wanted me to stand next to him for photos, his grandmother literally stepped in front of me and said they wanted pictures with people who were actually Part of his life. I watched my boy's face fall and it took everything in me not to say something, but I knew they'd just use it against me. Court, my ex wife's aunt asked me directly in front of everyone if I was still working that pathetic warehouse job or if I've been fired from that too. And when I said I was still there, she said at least my son would learn what not to become. My ex wife stood there telling her cousins that I lived in some disgusting studio apartment and probably spent my child support money on beer while her sister nodded along and said some people just aren't meant to be fathers and that's okay. That's when a Grace Dan pulled up and this exhausted looking woman got out carrying a thick folder and walking straight through the party toward me like everyone else was invisible. She looked distressed and said she was sorry but this couldn't wait another day because the state was threatening to pull the placement if she didn't get the inspection done immediately. My ex wife's mom immediately stepped forward and demanded to know who this woman was and what the hell she was talking about. The woman said she was from Child Protective Services and she needed to inspect my home for the foster placement renewal and verify the twins were still thriving. My ex wife's sister went completely white and whispered, what twins? The social worker flipped through Her papers and said she was talk.

The dumbest prank you ever pulled that spiraled out of control. My older sister is super jumpy. Like, she gets scared if the toast pops up too loud. So when I found out she'd been watching creepy sleepwalking videos all week, I saw my golden opportunity. One night, I stayed up late and waited until I knew she was asleep. Then I slowly opened her bedroom door, walked in barefoot with my eyes half closed, and started mumbling random garbage like, the bees are listening. They can smell light. She's full panic. I pretended to snap out of it like I didn't know what was going on. And the next morning, I told her I had no memory of it. That's what really got her. She was convinced I was actually sleepwalking.
