So I did it again the next night. This time, I stood at the end of her bed holding a spoon and just. I am the cereal. I was holding myself from bursting out laughing. After that, she started locking her door, so I got creative. I'd rattle the doorknob or just whisper her name through the air vent until she freaked out. I kept telling her I didn't remember any of it. My acting was elite. She even started filming me to prove it was real. But I would just delete the videos when she wasn't looking. It became this little war. Honestly, it was the most fun I'd had in weeks. I never meant to actually Scare her. Just mess with her a little. But then one night, she ran into my room looking pale and said, I need to show you something right now. I followed her down the hall, thinking it was just another one of her over reactions. she opened her phone and pulled up a video from the night before. The footage showed her room in the dark and a figure slowly pushing the door open. Me? Or someone that looked like me. I watched the figure step into her room, stand completely still for a full minute, then start whispering. But it wasn't gibberish this time. It was my name. Over and over, whispered slowly, almost like. Then it tilted its head and said, I know you're awake. That's when the video cut out. I tried to laugh it off and said, okay, I admit it. That one was actually kind of good. But she didn't laugh. She looked at me and said, that wasn't from last night. That was from the night you slept over at Sam's house. My stomach dropped. I'd spent that night two neighborhoods over, crashing on my friend's couch. I pulled out my own phone to double check the text. There it was. A message from me at 11:08 saying, crashing here tonight. Tell mom that video was recorded at 203:00am. I stared at the screen and tried to find some logical explanation. Maybe someone was messing with us. Maybe she faked the whole Thing. But then she said, I didn't want to tell you, but a few nights ago, I saw you standing in the hallway. I called your name and you didn't answer. You just walked into the bathroom and never came out. When I checked a minute later, the light was off and the room was empty. That was the part I couldn't explain, because I remembered.

When did you realize your partner saw you as a bank account, not a person? When the doctor told me surgery or death, and my boyfriend drew told me to start digging my own grave. However, he'd soon come to regret it. I was sitting in the office after finally going in for the stomach pain I've been ignoring for months. This could have been prevented if caught earlier, he said, looking at my chart. When was your last checkup? Four years ago. I couldn't afford it. I have insurance, but I needed every penny for rent, bills, my boyfriend's art studio. The doctor frowned, tapping on a clipboard. I see. Well, the surgery will cost about $5,000 with your coverage. 5,000? I felt the air get knocked out from my lungs. Maybe next time, doctor. I can still handle it. He gave a worried look before signing the release papers. But three steps from the hospital door, I felt a sharp pain zapped through me. I dropped to my knees on the asphalt and coughed up blood. The security guard radioed for help, and they rushed me back on a stretcher. You're bleeding internally. If we don't operate soon, this could rupture. I frowned and gave them Drew's contact. Think he'd understand? Just this once? The nurse stayed with me while they prepped more paperwork. So you handle all the bills? She asked with a disgusted expression, after I'd explained our situation. Well, when drew makes it big, it'll All come back like an investment. The nurse couldn't help but roll her eyes at my answer. And how long has he been not making it big? Six years. And how many of these artworks has he sold? Nothing yet, but he's close to a breakthrough. His mentor says he has talent, but I think this time I might have overdone it. I work 60 hours a week, two jobs. I haven't bought new clothes in three years. I'd love to go to a salon one last time before, you know, I pass away, I said bleakly, laughing at my own terrible situation. You need to take care of yourself too, honey. She touched my hand gently. What does your partner contribute exactly? I opened my mouth and closed it. He contributes. He's following his passion. I'd like to show him my passion. My passionate fists, she mumbled to herself and smiled. All right, you rest up. She left the room, still clearly upset at my story, but it felt nice having someone worry about me for once. Drew arrived two hours later, looking annoyed. This is really bad timing. I have a studio session with my mentor. The doctor explained the situation again. The urgency, the cost. Drew's face lit up. Actually, this is perfect timing. What? I asked, shocked at his happy tone. We have exactly 5,000 saved, right? Well, my mentor knows a gallery owner, and I can finally book my first show. I stared at him. From the hospital bed. But that money is for my surgery. Yeah, but we could get a loan for that, right? This is my one shot, drew. I'm dying. He looked at me with a raised eyebrow and an expression that screamed, so what? I snapped. No, I said calmly. What do you mean, no? The heart monitor slowly started rising. Six years, drew. I've paid for your life for six years. And now when I plan on choosing myself for once, you tell me not to. But it's not just a gallery. It's my dream. I tried to fight back my tears, but couldn't hold them. Your dream over my life. All this time, I've just been some sponsor to your dream. An open bank account. As working 60 hours is easy. It's not. I'm tired. So tired, drew. I said I'd pay it all back. He yelled. I laughed. When? Well, when? My art gallery. If you had to choose now, what would it be? My surgery or your gallery? Drew stood there with his mouth gaping open, acting as if it was a difficult question. I can't believe you're making me choose. That's, um, gaslighting. Choose. Drew paced back and forth nervously. This isn't fair. My mentor said this gallery could really change everything for me. Uh, for us. I said, choose. I'll come check on you after my show. He took my wallet from my back and walked out. I sobbed.

My MIL just showed up with three suitcases because of a lie I told. Three years ago, when I first met my husband, Greg's mother, Mallory, she made her famous tuna casserole with crushed potato chips and mayonnaise that had definitely seen better days. The smell alone made my stomach turn. But she stood there watching me take that first bite with such hopeful eyes. I couldn't crush her heart like that. So I smiled, forced it down, and said it was delicious. That single moment of kindness became my prison. Now, three years into our marriage, edge, Mallory brings food over twice a week, always in those same vintage Tupperware containers she's had since the 70s. When she brings her surprise meatloaf that tastes like cardboard soaked in ketchup, I order meatloaf from the diner and carefully transfer it to her containers. I'm spending $200 a month just to maintain the charade. Things started unraveling two weeks ago when Mallory announced she was entering a cooking competition at the community center and wanted me to be her sous chef and taste tester. She's been coming over more frequently, sometimes unannounced, bringing practice dishes. Greg's been acting strange about it, too. Overly enthusiastic, constantly asking if I'm excited about spending more. I'm with his mother, watching me eat with this weird intensity. His eyes literally track every bite from fork to mouth, and he keeps asking, isn't it amazing? Don't you wish you could have this every day? My stomach Turns every time. Yesterday, he came home early and almost caught me transferring Thai food into Mallory's green bean casserole dish. I had to pretend I was just freshening up the presentation. My hands were shaking so badly, I nearly dropped the whole thing. He stood there for a full minute, just staring at me with a strange smile before saying, you really do love her cooking, don't you? But here's what's really odd. Greg's been having hushed phone conversations that end abruptly when I enter the room. Last week, I heard him say something about measuring the guest room and February move in date. When I asked about it, he said he was helping a coworker with furniture dimensions. He's also been weirdly insistent about us decluttering the spare bedroom, saying we need to make space. It's for new possibilities. Yesterday I found him in there with a tape measure and a notebook sketching what looked like furniture placement. When I walked in, he slammed the notebook shut and practically shoved me out, saying it was a surprise and I'd ruin everything if I kept snooping. Mallory's been dropping hints, too, asking about local doctors, the nearest grocery stores, whether our street gets loud quickly in winter. But if I ever tried to ask more questions, he'd shut me down instantly. Then one day, I woke up with food poisoning from this sketchy replacement Chinese food I had the day before and ran to the bathroom through the window. I saw Greg in the backyard on the phone, and his voice carry clearly in the morning. Quiet. Mom, I know you're excited about surprising her, but maybe we should tell her before my blood went cold. Tell me about what? He continued. I know I said February, but if you win this competition, it would be the perfect Celebration to announce your moving in. She loves your cooking so much. She'll be thrilled to have you here full time. Wait, moving in was my mother in law moving in, and my husband was just letting it happen? I stayed frozen, listening to him reassure his mother that I would definitely want her living with us, that I'm always saying how much I miss her between visits. The competition is tomorrow, and Mallory texted that she's bring

No, because why did I accept money to watch my ex get married? My coworker slides me $200 cash during lunch and whispers, I need you to be my boyfriend tomorrow. Just for four hours. It's my cousin's wedding. I almost choked on my sandwich. She's never talked to me about anything beyond spreadsheets and deadline complaints. Now she's offering me money to fake date her? She explains fast. Look, my whole family keeps asking why I'm still single. My mom calls every Sunday to remind me I'm 32 with no prospects. I just need someone normal to shut them up. Plus, you have that one good suit. The wedding's tomorrow at 2 p m. She promises another 200 after. You just have to hold my hand, laugh at my dad's jokes, and don't get too drunk. Easy money. Four hours of free food and pretending to like someone I already think is pretty cool. The cash would cover my car payment. Sure, why not? She looks relieved, like she was expecting me to say no, thank you. Seriously, you're saving my life here. Saturday morning, she picks me up in a BMW I didn't know she had. She's nervous, talking fast about the rules. We've been dating three months, met at work. That part's true. You love hiking. Because my mom will love that you went to State University. Don't mention your ex. Actually, don't mention any ex at all. She's gripping the steering wheel so tight, her knuckles Are white. Something's bothering her beyond normal. Fake date nerves. The venue is fancy. Way fancier than I expected. Valet parking, ice sculptures, a string quartet playing by the entrance. This isn't some backyard wedding. This is money. She grabs my hand really tight as we walk in, her palms sweating. Just stick close to me, okay? Some people here are complicated. We enter the cocktail area, and my chest tightens. I recognize faces in the crowd. This one guy by the bar is one of my ex's best friends, who always hosted those poker nights. This other guy is talking to someone near the fountain. He's my ex's friend from college who's always tagged with her in beach photos. Made me jealous every time. Then this girl walks by in a bridesmaid dress. She was my ex's roommate senior year. The one who told her I wasn't good enough. My stomach drops. These aren't random people. This is my ex's entire friend circle. Circle? Every person who watched our relationship explode. Hey, whose wedding is this exactly? I ask. She pulls me forward. My cousin Taylor's. Come on. Ceremony starting. Taylor. My ex's name is Taylor. We sit down in the fourth row. I'm scanning in the crowd, recognizing more faces. People who unfriended me after the breakup. I'm sweating through my good suit. Then the music starts. The wedding march. Everyone stands. The bride walks out. It's her. My ex. When I found in our bed with someone Else, two years ago. The one I was going to propose to. She's wearing the kind of dress she used to show me in magazines. My coworker squeezes my hand. You okay? You look pale. I can't speak. Can't move, can't breathe. Taylor looks beautiful, happy, glowing in a way she never did with me. The grooms, tall, everything. I'm not. After the ceremony, we're at cocktail hour. I'm Downing champagne like water, trying to stay calm. My coworker stays glued to my side, introducing me to aunts and uncles. This is my boyfriend. Three months now. He's wonderful playing the part, but dying inside. Then Taylor appears with the groom. Oh, my god, is that you? My coworker jumps in fast. Babe, you know the bride? Taylor's face cycles through emotions. Shock, confusion, something else. We. We dated years ago. Small world, my coworker says. Way too cheerful. We should get drinks sometime.

How do you deal with someone who expects everything and gives nothing in return? During a dinner celebrating us signing a lease on a brand new home, my wife dropped the bomb that she was quitting her job. I want to be a trad wife, she said out of the blue. I thought it was a joke until she pulled up her Instagram, where she had already made an extensive post about how amazing of a husband I was for agreeing to work two jobs to pay for the mortgage. The next morning, Katie quit her nursing job with no notice. By the end of the week, she'd gone full traditional. Wouldn't drive, wouldn't work, wouldn't make financial decisions. She also wouldn't answer the door for deliveries, claiming that was a man's job. So my expensive work equipment got stolen off our porch. she refused to sign for my certified mail from the IRS about a tax because traditional wives don't handle business matters. I got fined $8,000 for missing the deadline. Then my brother got into a severe car accident 40 minutes away. Single dad. His kids were at school and needed to be picked up. In two hours, he was unconscious and I was stuck in a mandatory meeting at work that I'd be fired for leaving. Katie, please, just this once, pick up the kids from school and drive them to the hospital. Traditional wives don't drive, she said, arranging flowers she picked from our garden. It's not feminine. They're 8 and 10 years old. They'll be standing outside school alone. Maybe their mother should have thought about that before divorcing your brother. My brother's kids waited outside their school until child services pick them up. The investigation lasted months. He nearly lost custody because of child abandonment while he was literally in a coma. I remember begging her to stop. She could be traditional and still use her frontal lobe, but nope, because two weeks later, our house caught fire. She was in the kitchen and left the stove on by accident. Extinguisher was literally in the corner next to her. But instead of grabbing it, she ran outside and called me. Traditional wives don't handle emergencies. That's the man's job. By the time firefighters arrived, half the kitchen was destroyed. 20,000 in damages. Insurance investigated why she didn't attempt to put out a containable fire, and our premiums tripled. That was when I finally snapped. You want traditional? Fine. She gleamed with excitement until I opened our banking app. I'm closing your access to our joint account. Her head snapped up. What? Traditional wives don't have their own bank accounts. They get allowances. My grandfather gave my grandmother $10 a week in 1960. Adjusted for inflation, that's $100 a month. That's insane. That's traditional. That evening, she was planning a Friday night out with the girls. Apparently, that's traditional. I'll need an Uber to downtown. Probably $30 each way. Traditional wives don't go to Bars without their husbands? That's inappropriate. It's just drinks with friends. My grandmother never went anywhere without my grandfather after six PM. Very traditional. She ended up canceling. Her father's 70th birthday was the next week, and her whole family had planned a surprise party for months. But when Saturday came, I had to work. I can't take you. I said, so you can't go. She had no car and missed it. Her father cried when he realized she wasn't coming. Her mother called her selfish. When Katie's grandmother was dying in hospice, Katie came to me crying, please, I need money for an Uber. Just this once. She's asking for me. Traditional wives don't handle money. I reminded her you said modern women's financial independence destroyed marriages. Remember your Instagram post? Her grandmother died a 30 minute drive away while Katie sat at home. Then her brother's wedding invitation arrived. Destination wedding in Mexico. Katie begged for her

Has a doctor ever refused to treat you? I came into the emergency room clutching my abdomen. In the same hospital I once worked as chief of surgery. After two hours, I finally got to see Doctor Harm, who barely glanced up at me and sighed like I'd interrupted something by being here. Let me guess, he said before I could speak. You're 90 years old, ate dinner too late, and now you're panicking. On a scale of one to 10, how bad is your imaginary emergency? When I said eight, he actually laughed. Right. Everyone says eight. Real pain doesn't let you walk in here in your pajamas looking so put together. My pajamas were soaked with sweat from the pain. When did you last have your period? He asked with a smirk. When I said I was postmenopausal, he nodded like he'd solved everything. There you go. Hormones. They make women your age think every little cramp is a heart attack or appendicitis. You tried yoga? Maybe losing some weight? He typed something without examining me. I see a lot of hysterical women your age. Retirement gives you too much time to obsess over every little ache. I tried to explain that I knew my body, but he interrupted, ma'am, I have actual emergencies to deal with. Young man next door got stabbed. That's real medicine. Your psychosomatic belly ache can be handled by your GP on Monday. He started to leave, but I grabbed the rails of The bed, please. Something's wrong. I can feel it. He pried my fingers off one by one. This is drug seeking behavior. Are you here for pain pills? Because that's not happening. A nurse came in and harm told her loudly. Just anxiety. Probably wants attention. Her husband probably doesn't listen to her anymore, so she comes here for someone to talk to. He didn't know. My husband died two years ago in this very hospital. Don't waste resources on blood work. Give her some antacids and discharge papers. The nurse looked uncertain, but he snapped. Did I stutter, or do you want to be a doctor now, too? When I asked for a different doctor, he got nastier. You want a doctor shop? Classic drug seeking. I'm noting this in your file. He pulled up my chart on the computer. Oh, look, you've been here before. Frequent flyer. Lonely old women love the attention from young doctors. It's pathetic, but common. He didn't scroll down far enough to see my employment history at this hospital. The pain was getting worse and I doubled over, which made him roll his eyes dramatically. The performance isn't necessary. I've seen better acting from kindergarteners. He called another resident over. Watch this. Classic case of Munchausen's in the elderly. They Google symptoms and then pretend to have them. The president looked uncomfortable but stayed quiet. She probably lives alone. Kids don't visit, so she creates drama. I started describing my symptoms in medical Terms, hoping it would help. The pain is intermittent, positional with guarding in the upper quadrant. He cut me off. Oh, great. You watch Grey's anatomy and think you're a doctor now? Let me guess, you diagnose yourself on Webmd. He turned to the nurse. She's using medical words she doesn't understand. Probably reads medical forums all day. These board housewives always think they have whatever disease is trending on Facebook. When I stood up to leave and find another hospital, I collapsed from the pain. Instead of helping, he stood over me and said, this manipulation won't work. Get up. You're taking a bed from someone who actually needs it. He didn't help me up, just watched as I struggled. In my professional opinion, you need a psychiatrist, not an ER. Maybe some friends, hobby, anything besides wasting our time. He grabbed my arm roughly to pull me up, and I cried out, stop the theatrics! I'm documenting this as a psych case. You'll be lucky if insurance covers this visit when I'm done. He started dictating to his phone. Patient presents with fabricated symptoms, drug seeking behavior and hysteria typical of menopausal women seeking attention. He looked at me with disgust. Women like

What happened when a bride banned all women from her wedding? My cousin Brianna sent out the most insane wedding invitation I've ever seen. Under the dress code, in bold letters, it said, no female guests. This includes family members, plus ones, and children. Male attendees only. I thought it was a typo until she called me personally. I know it seems harsh, she said, but I need my wedding day to be about me. Other women always steal attention. This is my solution. I tried reasoning with her. Brianna, your own mother can't come to your wedding. She'll understand. Besides, she always cries and makes everything about her emotions. Real reason came out after 20 minutes of talking. Brianna was convinced that her fiance, Jerome, would leave her for someone prettier. She'd caught him liking other women's photos online and decided the only solution was to eliminate all competition from her big day. The family was in uproar. Her mother sobbed for days. Her three sisters were devastated. Even Jerome's mother was banned. But Brianna wouldn't budge. She hired all male vendors. Male photographer, male caterers, male florist. She even found a male makeup artist to do her hair and makeup. Two weeks before the wedding, I got a call from Jerome's best man, Terrell. This is insane. He's. Jerome's trying to support her, but his mom is threatening to disown him. Can't you talk sense into her? I tried one more time. Brianna just said, either support my Decision or don't come to the reception. Yes, she was allowing women at the reception, just not the ceremony, because that made sense in her world. The day of the wedding arrived. I wasn't there, obviously, but Terrell live streamed it for the banned women in a group chat. The venue looked beautiful, but eerily empty. Thirty men sat awkwardly in a space meant for 200. No one knew where to look or what to say. Then came the professional. Brianna had no bridesmaids, so she walked alone. The music started, the doors opened, and in walked nobody. The music played for a full minute while everyone stared at the empty doorway. Jerome started sweating. The efficient looked confused. Terrell ran to check. He found Brianna in the bridal suite, locked in the bathroom, having a complete meltdown. Her male makeup artist had given her what she called drag queen makeup. Her hair was teased into a massive Buffon. She looked like she was competing in a pageant from 1987 without any women around to help fix it. She'd been trying to redo everything herself and made it worse. But that wasn't why she was really crying. Through the door. She admitted the truth. I've been so focused on keeping women away that I forgot this meant I'd have nobody to share this with. No mother daughter moment, no sisters helping with my dress. I'm completely alone on the most important day of my life. Jerome went to talk To her, we could hear him through Terrell's phone. Baby, this. It's crazy. You banned my mother? Your mother? What are we doing? I just didn't want you looking at other women, she sobbed. I'm looking at other women every day because you made this wedding into a circus! Everyone's talking about the bride who banned women, not the bride I'm marrying. You created the exact attention you were trying to avoid. She finally came out an hour later, makeup streaked, hair deflated. They did a quick ceremony with just the officiant, Jerome Terrell, and Brianna's father, who looked like he wanted to disappear here. The reception was even worse. All the band women showed up, but the atmosphere was ice cold. Brianna tried to act like nothing happened, but everyone knew. Her mother sat in the corner crying. Her sisters left after 15 minutes. Jerome's mother didn't even show up. The photographer, who'd only been hired for his gender, turned out to be terrible. Every photo was

My boyfriend said he'd never love anyone as much as his dead ex, so I made him choose. We've been together two years. Last month, his college girlfriend Madison died from cancer at just 26. They'd broken up five years ago, but stayed friends on social media. I'd always felt a little weird about their friendship, but I trusted him completely. He was absolutely devastated when she passed. Took a week off work, barely ate anything. Just lay in bed scrolling through old photos of them together. I tried being supportive, making his favorite meals, bringing him tea, giving him space when he needed it. Then he started talking about her constantly. Madison always made the best lasagna from scratch with her grandmother's recipe. Madison would have absolutely loved this movie. She had such incredible taste in everything. Madison understood my twisted sense of humor better than anyone ever has or probably ever will. At first I thought it was completely normal grief. People reminisce about lost friends all the time, right? I figured he'd work through it naturally, but it escalated really quickly. He began comparing literally everything I did to Madison. When I cooked dinner, he'd mention how Madison's version was somehow better. When I laughed at his jokes, he'd say Madison's laugh was more genuine and musical. When I wore certain outfits, he comment that Madison had better style sense. It got really weird when he asked me to dye my hair blonde like Madison's had been. Said it would help him feel closer to those happy memories during this in readily difficult time in his life. I refused Point Blank. He got genuinely upset, accused me of being selfish and unsupportive during his grief. Said a truly loving girlfriend would understand what he was going through and try to help him heal properly. That hurt deeply, but I tried to stay patient. Everyone grieves differently, and I didn't want to be the terrible girlfriend who couldn't handle her boyfriend mourning a friend. Last week, I found him at two a m. Sitting at our kitchen table, writing intensely in a leather journal I'd never seen before, page after page about Madison. How she was his true soulmate and the only woman who truly understood his deepest soul. He wrote things like, I made the biggest mistake of my life letting her go, and I settled for someone lesser because I was terrified of real, assuming love. I was reading over his shoulder in the dark hallway when he finally noticed me standing there. He slammed the journal shut and got incredibly defensive. Said it was private therapy and I was serious, seriously violating his personal boundaries. The absolute final straw was yesterday evening. We're at dinner with his parents at their favorite Italian restaurant, when his mom casually mentions that Madison had sent her a lasagna recipe years ago. He immediately tears up and says, I'll never love anyone the way I loved her. She was absolutely Perfect in every single way imaginable. His dad looked completely horrified. His mom tried desperately changing the subject to the web.

My father in law kicked my boyfriend and me out of his house, saying we would never amount to anything in life. And now that I'm rich, he demands that I give him our house and support him for the rest of his life. I was 15 when my parents died. No family ended up on the streets until a government program gave me housing and half minimum wage until 18. When that ended, I couldn't get work because I had no address. Finally got a job at a diner making almost nothing. That's where I met Cody, my now husband. He was a regular customer and we talked for hours. Six months later, I moved in with him. His dad hated me from day one. Called me worthless, said I'd drag his son down. I paid their rent, bills, groceries. Saved every penny for our future. Didn't matter. Daily insults, constant judgment. Street rat. He'd call me at dinner. My son deserves better than some homeless girl. Cody would defend me, but his dad would just laugh. She's using you, son. Mark my words. I worked doubles at the diner while Cody did construction. Every night I'd come home exhausted to more criticism. Still smell like grease. His dad would sneer, this is what failure looks like. The worst part? I genuinely tried to win him over. Cooked his favorite meals, cleaned the house spotless. Even bought him birthday gifts with money I could barely spare. Nothing worked. One Christmas. I saved for months to buy him a nice watch. He opened it, looked gusted, and said, I don't need charity from a charity case. Then he threw it in the trash right in front of me. Cody's friends would come over, and his dad would introduce me as the homeless girl Cody's wasting his time with. I'd sit there humiliated while everyone looked at me with pity. One night, we came home from a date, and he wouldn't let us in. Said he'd sold our clothes and stolen our savings. I won't support two losers who'll never succeed. We slept in my car that night. Cody cried. First time I'd ever seen him break down. I'm sorry, he kept saying. I should have stood up to him sooner. Got a tiny room near the diner. Cody found work. The room was so small, we had to take turns getting dressed. Ate a ramen for months, but we were finally free. We took a loan, opened our own small restaurant. After hours, Cody would cook while I waited tables. We'd work our day jobs, then run to our place until midnight. The first year was brutal. Barely breaking even, working 16 hour days, sleeping four hours a night. His dad would drive by sometimes just to laugh at us through the window. But slowly, customers started coming back. Word spread. Local food blogger gave us five stars. Lines started forming outside. We hired our first employee, a kid from The streets like me. Then another. Cody insisted we pay above minimum wage. Everyone deserves a real chance, he'd say. Years passed. That one restaurant became five, then 10. We built an empire. Cody proposed in our flagship restaurant. You turn my life around, he said. Let's make it official. His dad wasn't invited to the wedding. We had two kids, Sophia and Frederick. Cody turned into the most incredible father. I want to be everything my dad wasn't, he'd say while reading them bedtime stories. Our company went public three years ago. We're worth about 50 million now. Bought a mansion in the hills with a pool the kids love. Cody's mom visits sometimes. Divorced his dad years ago and finally admits he was always horrible.

My ex wife sued me for child support even though we share custody of our kid. But I went along with it and watched her and her lawyer embarrass themselves in front of the judge. We split custody fifty fifty when we divorced 3 years ago. Same salaries, same time with our 5 year old daughter, so no child support needed. That was the deal we both signed off on. But my ex got greedy. She quit her job to find herself enrolled in some online marketing course, then dropped out after two months when it got hard. Suddenly she's blowing up my phone demanding $200 monthly because I control my finances better than her. I laughed it off until her lawyer contacted me. Fine. I thought, let's play this game. Here's what she didn't know. I'm meticulous with records. Every receipt, every bank statement, every expense tracked to the penny. And color coded bed sheets. It's literally how I survived our messy divorce. Her lawyer filed the case without requesting my actual income. They just guessed based on my old job from two years ago and guessed wrong. They estimated I made 30% more than reality and had half my actual expenses. Basic mistake number one. Meanwhile, I'm gathering evidence like I'm building a criminal case. Stubs, rent receipts, grocery bills, medical co pays, our daughter's dance class fees, everything organized by date and category. As we approached court, my lawyer called with an update. Her attorney figured out She'd been lying about her financial situation and wanted to settle immediately. She doesn't want to go to court anymore, he said, barely containing his laughter. But my ex refused the settlement. She was convinced she'd win because judges always side with the mom. Court day arrives. Sitting there in my best suit, folder full of evidence, watching her strut in like she owns the place. The judge reviews both our financial statements side by side. I watch his expression change from neutral to confused to visibly annoyed. Plot twist after calculating everything properly, she actually had more disposable income than me. Way more. Her unemployment benefits, plus child tax credits, plus help from her new boyfriend, plus the side gig she forgot to mention. It all added up. The judge looked directly at her. Ma'am, you're asking him to pay support when you have $400 more per month than available income? Her lawyer literally face palmed and started shuffling papers like he was looking for an escape route. But it gets exponentially better. She'd submitted completely falsified bank statements as supporting evidence, claiming she only had $75 in total savings. The judge caught the deception immediately. Dates didn't match the statement periods, dollar amounts were clearly altered with correction fluid. The bank routing numbers were from a completely different financial institution. Ma'am, are you fully aware that knowingly submitting false evidence to this court constitutes perjury, which is a felony punishable by up to five years in prison? The Judge asked, his voice absolutely ice cold. My ex Heather went completely pale and start

My boyfriend's manipulative best friend weaseled into our romantic getaway and then spent the entire time trying to break us up. So I got the perfect revenge. She crashed our cabin weekend claiming her Airbnb fell through. I knew it was BS the moment she showed up with a perfectly packed bag and a smug smile. My boyfriend Joseph felt bad for her and invited her to stay without even asking me. For three days straight, she kept creating these elaborate situations to make me look like the worst girlfriend ever. Like when she helped make dinner on Friday night. She volunteered to preheat the oven while I prepped ingredients. Everything seemed normal until I put our carefully marinated steaks in and they came out completely charred. She acted shocked when Joseph got mad at me for ruining our expensive dinner. Later, I noticed she'd secretly cranked the oven to 500 degrees. Saturday morning, she suggested we go hiking to this amazing waterfall she'd been to for. She gave me detailed directions to the trailhead while she rode with Joseph. Turns out she sent me to the wrong trail entirely. I spent two hours lost in the woods with no cell service while they bonded over waiting for me. When I finally found them at the actual trailhead, Joseph was visibly annoyed I'd kept them waiting. She just shrugged and said, oh, I guess I mixed up the directions. My bad. The manipulation got worse as the weekend went on. She kept doing this thing where she'd bring up inside jokes and memories from before I existed, making me. I feel like an outsider in my own relationship. Remember when we did this? And remember when we did that? Always with this little smile directed at me. She'd also accidentally brush against Joseph, constantly grab his arm when laughing, and find excuses to lean over him. During Saturday afternoon, we decided to go swimming in the lake. She conveniently forgot to pack a swimsuit and asked to borrow one of mine. The one she picked was my smallest bikini, and she made sure to comment loudly about how loose it was on her while adjusting it right in front of Joseph. Then she suggested we play volleyball in the water and kept accidentally bumping into me, making me lose my balance. The breaking point was Saturday night, we were all sitting by the fire when she pretended to be drunk and started crying about how much she missed the old days before I came along and changed everything. She was literally sobbing into Joseph's shoulder about how their friend group was never the same, how she felt like she was losing her best friend, and how things used to be so much. My boyfriend was actually comforting her, rubbing her back, and telling her nothing had changed between them. That's when I noticed something crucial. All weekend, she'd been taking tons of photos with Joseph's phone and hers, documenting every Moment. But I realized she was only capturing me when I looked terrible. Messy hair from hiking, unflattering angle while eating, caught mid chew, or when I was frustrated and arguing. Meanwhile, every single photo of her was perfectly posed and filtered. So while she was in the bathroom touching up her makeup for the 10th time that day, I grabbed her phone. She'd left it unlocked on the counter next to the sink. I scrolled through her camera roll and found the absolute worst photo she'd taken all weekend of herself. Double chin, eyes half closed, food stuck in her teeth, hair a complete disaster. It was from when she was laughing too hard at one of Joseph's jokes and snorting. I posted it to her Instagram story.

What turned you into a villain for the rest of the world? One day my kids came up to me and told me they didn't want to go over to mommy's house anymore. I had split custody with my ex, but this was the first time when they outright refused to visit her for the weekend. I knelt down to their level and asked them what was up. Did Mommy say something to you? Then they told me how Mommy's new boyfriend would make them do weird things and also made them promise not to tell anyone. When I asked what these things were, my heart was shattered into a million pieces. Would make both my kids stand in front of a camera and strip to their undies. Then he would take a few pictures, give them both some candy and go back to his room. At first my kids were happy to get free candy, but they eventually realized that something was wrong and became uncomfortable. So they asked him to stop. my wife's boyfriend landed an open handed slap on my daughter's face. They went to their mommy to complain and told her the absolute truth while crying. But instead of helping them, she told them to stop being jealous of her new relationship. She was under the impression that I had told our kids to spin this story and simply refused to believe them. I was so angry but also distraught at the same time. The First thing I did was call the cops. But the person who showed up was my wife's brother in law who was also a deputy. He told me the same thing that my wife said to our kids, stop being jealous and stop telling disgusting lies about other people just because you can't handle their happiness. I don't know what kind of mother my ex wife was being that she didn't even consider the possibility of her boyfriend actually doing this. I knew one thing, which was I couldn't just stay still. I sent my kids to my parents house. Before taking action, I was a regular at this local bar where I had made friends with these two ex convicts, both.

I went to the police over a prank. So I'm 24 and I've been vegan for like 10 years now ever since I was a little kid and found out where meat comes from. I just couldn't do it anymore. Everyone in my life knows this, my family, friends, co workers, literally everyone. Four nights ago, I was at this party at my friend Jake's place. I'll be honest, I got absolutely wasted, like embarrassingly drunk. My friends were all laughing and having a good time and I was just trying to keep up with everyone else. Around midnight, I got super hungry. You know how it is when you're drunk. My friend Caitlin comes up to me with this made of chicken nuggets and I'm like, oh, these look good. Are they vegan? She goes, yeah, totally. They're those sunfed ones from the store. I knew sunfed made pretty good fake chicken stuff, so I trusted her. I grabbed like 6 nuggets and started eating them. It tasted kind of weird, but I figured it was just because I was drunk and my taste buds were off. Plus the lighting was dim and I couldn't really see them that well. I finished the whole plate and didn't think anything of it. The next morning I woke up with the worst hangover ever. My head was pounding and I felt sick to my stomach. But then around noon, my sister Emma text me saying you need to check Jake's Snapchat. Story right now, I had this sinking feeling in my gut. I opened Snapchat and there it was. The first video showed Caitlin holding up a package of actual chicken nuggets, like real Tyson chicken nuggets from the freezer section. Then the next video was me asking if they were vegan and her saying yes. Then there's this clip of me eating them and being all happy and drunk. But the worst part was the last few videos after I left the party, they filmed themselves pretending to be me. When I would find out Caitlin was fake crying and screaming, oh, no, the poor chickens. In this mocking voice, Jake was pretending to throw up and going, I can't believe I ate a real animal. They, we're all laughing hysterically. I screen recorded everything before they could delete it. I was shaking. I was so angry. This wasn't just some harmless joke. They knew how important being vegan was to me. They knew I hadn't eaten meat in over 10 years and they filmed themselves mocking something that was genuinely important to me. I called my sister first and she was furious. She told me I should definitely do something about it. Then I called my mom and she said the same thing. They both said this went way beyond a normal prank. I spent like 2 hours researching online and found out that deliberately giving someone food they can't or won't eat can actually be considered food tampering. Especially when it's done without their knowledge and filmed for humiliation purposes. So I drove to the police station with all the video evidence. The officer I talked to was actually really understanding. He said they'd seen cases like this before, especially with people who have food allergies or dietary restrictions for religious reasons. He took my statement and all the evidence. Within three days, Caitlin, Jake and another friend named Austin, who was also involved, got served with charges. Food tampering is apparently a misdemeanor, but it can still go on your record and everything. My lawyer friend told me I actually have a pretty strong case. Food tampering is taken seriously, especially when there's video evidence and it was done specifically to cause distress. Plus, the public humiliation aspect makes it even worse. The court date is next month. And honestly, I'm not sure what's going to happen.

What's the best way you've seen someone rebel against school rules? A buddy of mine was caught messing with his phone during class. Back then, the school rules were that if you were caught, your phone was confiscated for an entire day and you couldn't get it back until the next day. This was before smartphones and the rules have changed since then. So, oh, buddy hands in his phone but doesn't seem too worried about it. He waits a couple of classes until lunch break and asks me to come with him. He's gonna get his phone back. We went to the staff room where the confiscated phones were held and asked a teacher there if he could copy down a phone number into my phone so he could call his dad later that day. Teacher agrees and gives him the phone. I hand him mine and we wait for him to copy the number. When he's done, he gives me mine back and sticks his own phone in his pocket. He was known as a bit of a joker, so when he jokingly said, well, thanks a lot, see ya, the teacher immediately laughs, tells him to stop messing about and to give the phone back. Laughing and joking about being caught, he does, but not really. See, he had a second phone, the exact same model, except this one was broken, wouldn't charge anymore, he said. So when he stuck his good phone in his pocket, it Was right next to the broken one. When the teacher made him give back the phone, he just gave back the broken one. It was the best switcharoo I have ever seen.

What is the funniest lie to tell kids? 1, that as their father, I could change their names whenever I wanted to. One time I pretended to get on the phone with the Arizona name registry and renamed my two kids snorkle and Gorf because they kept misbehaving. They were bawling. I could barely keep a straight face. 2, I was on a flight where a kid saw the button for calling a flight attendant, didn't know what it was, but clearly was thinking about pressing it, and so asked his dad what it did. His dad said it opens a trap door under your seat and drops you out of the bottom of the plane. Afterwards, the kids spent the whole flight intrigued by the button, thinking about and talking about pushing it, but too worried to actually do it. 3, not exactly a lie, but when I was first learning swear words, my parents made the mistake of telling me the those were words only mommies and daddies are allowed to say. So I was playing house with my sister and her friends and I was the dad. I promptly went on a swearing tirade as the dad and got in big trouble. Four, when we were in the car and it was raining, my mom would wait for a bridge or tunnel. And as we approached it, she would tell us she was going to make the rain stop in 3:21. She told us she could only Make the rain stop for a minute because it made her so tired. My siblings and I were convinced she was magic.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? My therapist told me to write letters to an imaginary boyfriend. I know it sounds crazy, but after my last breakup left me feeling completely broken, it would help me figure out what I actually wanted in a relationship. So I made up this guy named Ryan. Perfect guy on paper, thoughtful, funny, remembered my coffee order, never interrupted me when I talked about work drama. I was supposed to do this exercise for a month. Seven months later, I was still writing to Ryan every single night before bed. I tell him about my day, write about fights we'd have and how we'd work through them without screaming at each other. I even wrote about him meeting my parents at Christmas, how he'd bring my mom flowers and actually listen when my dad talked about golf for three hours straight. The problem started when I printed one of the letters at work by mistake. My coworker Ben found it in the printer tray. Tuesday morning, he walked over to my desk holding this piece of paper, grinning like he'd discovered buried treasure. So who's the mystery boyfriend, he asked, waving the letter around. Ryan, sounds like a catch. When do we get to meet him? I should have laughed it off, made up some story about a guy I was seeing. Instead, I panicked. I grabbed the letter so fast I knocked over My coffee all over my keyboard. Ben just stood there looking confused while I frantically tried to clean up the mess, mumbling something about how it was nobody important. That night, I sat in my apartment staring at the stack of letters I'd written, 43 letters to a guy who didn't exist. I realised I've been comparing every real guy I met to Ryan and obviously none of them could compete with someone I'd literally designed to be perfect. But then something weird started happening. I began noticing things about Ben that reminded me of stuff I'd written about Ryan, like how he always brought me soup when I called in sick, never questioned it or made it weird. How he actually listened when I talked instead of just waiting for his turn to speak. He even started putting that ridiculous Sriracha sauce on everything. After I mentioned in one letter how Ryan loved spicy food, it hit me one Friday when we were walking to the parking garage after work. Ben stopped at the little flower stand outside our building and bought daisies for his neighbour because her cat had just died. That's exactly something I'd written about Ryan doing. Standing there watching him count out quarters for this tiny old lady, I realised I might have been writing about Ben this whole time without even knowing it. So I told him everything. Right there in the parking garage between a Honda Civic and someone's motorcycle. I explained about The therapy exercise about Ryan, about how I've been writing love letters to an imaginary person for seven months, like some kind of crazy person. I told him how he'd somehow become everything I've been pretending Ryan was. Ben listened to the whole thing without interrupting once. When I finished, he was quiet for so long I thought he was going to call security or something. Then he smiled and said, well, that, that explains why you always knew exactly what kind of coffee I liked. Turns out he'd been trying to ask me out for months but thought I had a boyfriend because I kept mentioning Ryan. We've been together for three weeks now, and I finally threw away all those letters. Ryan was great, but Ben's real.

I didn't let my sister see her kids back in 2,018. I got custody of my sister Emma's three kids after she left them alone for two weeks to go on what she called a vacation. The nine year old Caleb was basically raising his two little sisters, changing diapers and trying to feed them cereal for dinner when the neighbors called the cops after hearing the baby crying for hours, found Emma's drug stash under the couch and arrest warrants piling up on her kitchen counter. The kids were a mess when they came to live with me. Caleb had this haunted look like he'd seen way too much for a seven year old. At the time. The middle one, Sophie, was 4 and kept asking when mommy was coming back. The baby Grace was only 3 months old and had diaper rash so bad it made me wanna cry. The first few months were brutal. Caleb would wake up screaming from nightmares and Sophie would hide food under her bed because she was scared there wouldn't be any tomorrow. I had to move them to a new school district, find new daycare, basically rebuild their entire world from scratch. My apartment wasn't ready for three kids, so I slept on the couch for months while they figured out sleeping arrangements. Caleb refused to sleep alone for the first year, so he'd camp out on the floor next to my couch with his blanket every single night. Emma went To prison for child endangerment and drug possession. The whole family was furious with me for betraying her. But what was I supposed to do? Let those kids suffer? During her trial, she sat there crying about how I ruined her life, never once asking how the kids were doing. For six years, I've been mom, dad, homework helper, bedtime story reader, everything. Caleb Learned to ride a bike in my driveway. Sophie had her first day of kindergarten holding my hand. Grace took her first steps in my living room. These kids don't remember Emma as their mom anymore because honestly, she never really was one. Last month, Emma got out of prison early for good behavior. Her first call wasn't to apologize or ask how the kids were doing. She called demanding I bring them to see her immediately because she was ready to be a mother now. She actually said I could give them back like they were borrowed lawn equipment or something. I sat down with Caleb, who's 15 now, and asked what he wanted. He looked me dead in the eyes and said he never wanted to see her again. He remembered everything, the hunger, the fear, having to take care of his sisters when Emma would disappear for days. Sophie, who's 10 now, barely remembers Emma at all. She calls me mom and has for years. Grace doesn't know Emma exists. And honestly, I've never brought her up, but my family won't let it. Go. My parents keep calling, saying I'm being cruel, that Emma deserves a second chance, that blood is thicker than water. My aunt even showed up at my house last week yelling about how I'm poisoning the kids against their real mother. She said it was my fault the little ones don't remember Emma because I never took them to visit her in prison. The thing is, I did try to maintain some connection. At first, I sent Emma pictures and updates when she was locked up. She never responded, not once. Never asked about birthdays, school plays, nothing. When Caleb broke his arm falling off his skateboard, I called the prison to let her know. She couldn't be bothered to call back. The kids are thriving now. Caleb made honor roll last semester and plays varsity soccer.

My fiance claimed love doesn't pay the Bill. I need to be practical about my future. After she pulled out a prenup that could leave me with nothing. Allison and I had been together three years, engaged for six months, with our wedding planned for four months away. I'm a software engineer making $120,000. She works in marketing making $75,000. We. We're supposed to close on our first house in two weeks. I was contributing thirty five thousand dollars of the fifty thousand dollar down payment. Last Sunday she invited me to dinner at her parents upscale home. Her mom had prepared an elaborate spread and her dad, Greg was being unusually friendly, asking about my work and laughing at my jokes. Normally he treated me politely, but distantly. I thought they were finally accepting me as family. Halfway through dinner, Allison suddenly got this serious, rehearsed look. Sean, I think we should sign a prenuptial agreement before the wedding, she said, pulling out a Manila folder and sliding it across the table. My stuff like dropped. This whole dinner had been a setup. Her parents were nodding along. The prenup demanded complete financial separation. Separate bank accounts, separate credit cards, separate everything. But the real estate clause was the worst part. The house we were buying together would be titled solely in Allison's name. If we divorced, I'd walk away with nothing. Regardless of contributions to mortgage payments or improvement. I'd be paying Allison to live in a house She owned. When I asked why she suddenly wanted this, her mom jumped in. It's just smart financial planning, Sean. Surely someone in your field understands protecting assets. Her dad added, nothing personal, just business. This is how people like us protect what we've built. But when we started house shopping, Allison put for both our names on everything, saying it would show we were truly committed as partners. Now suddenly, she wanted legal separation of everything. I said I needed time to review it with a lawyer. The silence was deafening. A lawyer? Allison's voice pitched higher. I thought you'd be more mature about this. Monday morning, my lawyer, James, reviewed the document. His reaction was immediate. Sean, this is one of the most one sided documents I've ever seen. Don't sign this. He explained I'd pay half the mortgage, taxes, and maintenance on an asset entirely hers if we divorced. This reads like someone already planning for divorce while expecting you to subsidize her life until that happens. So I made two decision. I wouldn't sign the prenup, and I was withdrawing from the house purchase. I called our realtor and removed my name. Since Allison couldn't qualify for the mortgage alone without my contribution, this killed the deal. I also moved my $50,000 from our joint savings back to my personal account. When Allison discovered this, she called screaming, accusing me of sabotaging our relationship. Her family launched desperate attempts to pressure me. Her mother showed up, At my workplace, crying, her father offered to personally guarantee I

My girlfriend said, he's going to change my life forever. I replied, he changed mine, too. She didn't know he was my divorce lawyer. Celine had been acting weird for months. It started small. Suddenly caring about her appearance again, buying new clothes she couldn't afford on her teacher's salary. Then came the secret phone calls, where she'd step outside or lock herself in the bathroom. When I'd ask who called, she get defensive and say it was just her sister. The mysterious meetings were next. Working late at school again, she text. But when I drove by the parking lot at eight PM, her car wasn't there. She'd come home smelling like expensive Cologne and wine, claiming she'd grab dinner with colleagues. I'm not stupid. I knew something was happening. But after eight years together, I figured I owed it to us to try counseling first. That's when I started secretly meeting with Elias Thorn, the best divorce attorney in town. We've been planning my exit strategy for three months. Protecting my business, our joint accounts, the house I bought before we got to together. When she asked to talk last Friday, sitting at our kitchen table with this nervous energy, I knew what was coming. I'm leaving you, she said. And for the first time in months, she looked genuinely happy. I met someone incredible. A successful lawyer who actually understands me. She went on and on about how amazing he was, how intelligent, how sophisticated, how different. From me. He's handling this huge divorce case right now, making tons of money. He took me to that new French place downtown last week. You know, the one with the $200 steaks you said was too expensive. I just sat there, letting her paint this picture of her new life. She was practically glowing as she described their relationship. How he understood her need for finer things, how he made her feel valued and desired. He's taking me to Napa this weekend, she continued, her eyes bright with excitement. Says he's going to change my life forever. We're staying at some resort that costs more per night than you make in a week. The dig was unnecessary, but typical Celine. She'd always resented that I ran a small construction business instead of wearing suits and working in an office. I kept my voice calm and asked, that's nice. What's his name? Elias Thorn. She seemed like she was announcing she'd won the lottery. He's brilliant. Drives an Audi RS six, has this gorgeous office downtown. Everything I've always wanted. My stomach dropped, but I kept my face completely neutral. Elias Thorn wasn't just any lawyer. He was my divorce attorney. The one I've been secretly meeting with every Thursday for three months. The one who knew every detail about our finances, our relationship problems, our joint asset. Sounds great. I managed. When are you leaving? Tonight. He's picking me up at 7. I already packed a bag. She gestured. Toward her suitcase by the door, like she couldn't wait to escape. After she went upstairs to shower and get ready, I sat in my truck and called Elias. Straight to voicemail. I texted, emergency. Need to talk before Monday. Two hours later, while Celine was doing her makeup, he called back.
