My mother said on her deathbed, you were never my real child. I stared at her waiting for some explanation, some context that would make those words make sense. But she just closed her eyes with this keeful expression like she'd finally gotten something off her chest. An hour later, she was gone. The funeral was small. My mother didn't have many friends and I was her only family, or so I thought. People kept telling me how sorry they were for my loss, how she was such a devoted mother, how proud she must have been of me. I just nodded and smiled. But her last words kept echoing in my head. For three weeks, I couldn't function. I'd wake up at 3:00am replaying that moment. What did she mean? Was I adopted? Did she have an affair? Was there some family secret she took to her grave? My co workers started asking if I was okay. I'd zone out during meetings, stare at my computer screen for hours without typing a word. My girlfriend Sarah kept suggesting therapy. But how do you explain to a therapist that your dying mother basically told you that you weren't her real kid? I started going through old family photos, looking for clues. In every single picture, my mother looked distant. Even in photos from my childhood birthdays, she had this forced smile like she was performing the role of a happy mother rather than actually being one. Then I remembered how She used to disappear every year on my birthday. She'd make me breakfast, give me presents, sing Happy Birthday. But then around noon, she'd always say she had errands to run. She'd be gone for hours, coming back quiet and sad. I always thought she was visiting my father's grave, but now I wondered. Then I found her old address book. There were names and numbers I didn't recognize, including one entry that just said d, important dates with a phone number. No last name, no address, just d. That's when I decided I had to go through everything in her house systematically. I've been putting it off, but I needed answers. I started in her bedroom, going through drawers, closets, boxes under the bed. Most of it was normal stuff, old bills, jewelry, clothes that still smelled like her perfume. But then in the very back of her closet, behind winter coat she never wore, I found a small metal lock box. It was heavy and when I shook it, I could hear papers shuffling inside. The key was taped underneath her jewelry box. She always hid things in the most obvious places. My hands were shaking as I opened it. Inside were birth certificates, mine yellowed with age, and another one with the exact same date, same hospital, same time of birth, but a different name, David Michael Thompson. The mother's name was the same, Margaret Thompson, my mother. I had a twin brother. But that wasn't all. There were letters, dozens of them, written in my mother's handwriting, birthday cards, Christmas cards, graduation cards, all addressed to my dearest David, photos of a boy who looked exactly like me at every age.

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife, Stephanie, waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said. And I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked? Because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping? We date each other's spouses. She said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered. Room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said, let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something. But then I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. That should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. Put on this red Dress I've never seen before, that she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul never. She started, then stopped at dinner. She pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly, for months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand before. What? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name and she turned it face down. Immediately I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How was Cassie? Good. How was Paul? Then she started telling me everything they did, the hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you wanna know? No, her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down out of Nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner she had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked. And her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons, that's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents'house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom.

Parents, what do your kids think they're hiding from you? My 13 year old son, Alex asked if he could download a chess app on his tablet. I was shocked. All his friends were begging for Fortnite or some zombie game, and here's my kid wanting to play chess. I said yes immediately. See, I'm pretty strict about screen time. No games, no social media. Homework first. Alex has always been quiet, kind of awkward around other kids. Chess seemed perfect for building his brain. He got obsessed fast. Every day after school, straight to his room with that tablet. I'd hear him muttering moves under his breath. Night to E4, check. When I asked how it was going, he'd light up, talking about strategy and logic patterns. Months in, I noticed something weird. He'd quickly close the tablet whenever I walked in. Said he was just thinking through positions. Then one night, I heard him talking. Not muttering chess moves, actually talking to someone. I knocked. Who are you talking to? Just practicing out loud, dad. Helps me think. My gut said something was wrong. Next day, I checked his tablet while he was at school. The chess app was deleted. Completely gone. When I asked him about it, he said he took a break and was doing puzzles in his head now. That's when I installed tracking software. Took me three days to figure out how, but I did it. What I found made my blood boil. He'd Been using a fake chess app that was actually a cover for some underground gambling site. He was playing speed chess for money against adults online. Real money. His username was Chess Master J, and he had over $400 in his account. I watched one of his matches through the tracker. My quiet, awkward kid was trash talking grown men like some kind of gaming streamer. You call that a defense? My little sister plays better than you. Then he destroyed them in under five minutes with moves I couldn't even follow. But here's the crazy part. I kept watching, and this wasn't some gambling addiction. The kid was genuinely incredible. He was beating adults who'd been playing for decades. One guy even accused him of cheating and demanded a video call. Alex turned on his camera, solved three chess puzzles in 30 seconds, then checkmated the guy in seven moves while explaining every decision. I dug deeper into his account. Turns out he'd been banned from our school's chess team six months ago for embarrassing another school's coach during a live tournament. Coach had called Alex a know it nothing kid. So Alex responded by beating him in front of 200 people while explaining each mistake the coach made. The school said it was unsportsmanlike conduct. Alex never told me. Just said he quit the team because it was boring. So for months, he'd been rebuilding his reputation online, earning money, and getting revenge on everyone who'd written him Off the fake chess app. Wasn't about being lazy. It was about hiding how good he actually was. That night at dinner, I put a chess board between us. Wanna play a quick game? His face went white. Dad, I don't really. One game. Humor your old man.

Thirteen year old niece giggled. Mom says if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice while opening the 850 dollar phone I bought her. All 30 guests laughed except me. I nodded and with two taps I shut down every payment. Credit bills, subscriptions gone for years. I paid Lindsay's rent, covered Dad's gambling debts, handled Mom's credit cards and bought countless expense gift. I was the responsible one who always said yes when they needed money, but never really part of the family, just their walking ATM. The birthday party had 30 relatives gathered around. I driven straight from work to deliver that phone, another expensive gesture to show my love. My niece peeled away the plastic with delicate fingers, but her words cut like glass. Mom says, if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice. The room erupted in laughter. Lindsay smirked from the couch like she'd been waiting for this moment. Mom pretended not to hear from the kitchen, but her shoulders lifted in silent approval. Dad raised his beer and chuckled. Well, she's not wrong. Even Uncle Gary who barely knew me beyond family dinners snorted into his drink. Cousins grinned. Thirty people laughed at my expense while I stood there like the fool I'd always been, the one who paid for everything but mattered to no one. But this time something different happened. Instead of forcing a smile, I felt my phone in my pocket and made two quick taps. Every Bill I Paid every subscription I managed, every credit line I'd set up for them, gone just like that. The voices blurred into distant noise as I slipped out without saying goodbye. No one noticed me leave. The one thing my niece got right, I went home, packed a set, then returned with an old black backpack. While they celebrated, I slipped inside, left it by the stairs and disappeared forever. Inside was proof of everything, receipts, bank statements, payment records showing exactly how much I'd done for people who thought I was nothing. The explosion came the next morning. Dad pounded on my door at dawn, shouting about betrayal and family loyalty. Mom sent desperate texts. How could you do this to your own family? Lindsay called six times, then messaged, you think we can't live without you? Fine. See how long you last without a family. That evening, they broke into my apartment using an old key. Dad stormed in, red faced, mom behind him, both frantic about suddenly cancelled credit cards and unpayable bills. You ungrateful little troublemaker, dad snarled, stepping closer with clenched fists. Try it, I said calmly, still drying my hair from the shower. His hand trembled but didn't move. We both knew he wasn't a fighter, just a bully hiding behind words. The cards don't work, Mom's voice cracked. Lindsay can't pay bills. The mortgage bounced. Everything I paid for is over, I said. You think we need you? Dad laughed bitterly. Seems like you Do since you broke into my apartment just to beg. Dad later invited me to a football game, claiming he wanted to talk like men. When I arrived, he clutched.

When did you see a kid you genuinely hope the world never lets grow up? I was at my daughter's soccer game when this 11 year old on the opposing team started losing his mind. Every missed shot he'd blame his teammates. You morons can't pass properly. This is your fault. I should be playing with kids who actually understand soccer. His mom cheered from the sidelines that that's right, sweetie. Demand better from them. These other kids are dragging down your potential. When the referee called a foul against him, the kid completely exploded. He kicked the soccer ball directly at the ref's legs, hitting him hard. You're terrible at this job. I want a different referee. My mom will get you fired. The referee staying calm, gave him a yellow card warning. Done. One more outburst and you're out of the game. The kid's response was even worse. He grabbed another ball and deliberately kicked it as hard as possible at a seven year old girl sitting on the bench with her team. The ball smacked her right in the face, knocking her backward. The little girl started crying, blood trickling from her nose. Her dad rushed down from the stands. Sarah, honey, are you okay? The 11 year old just shrugged with this cold smile. Maybe she shouldn't sit so close if she can't handle real soccer. This is a competitive sport. His mother actually started clapping from the bleachers. Good shot, honey. Show them what real Athleticism looks like these participation trophy kids need reality checks. Sarah's mom was livid. She's 7 years old. What is wrong with you? Nothing's wrong with excellence, the mom called back. Maybe teach your kid to pay attention during games. That's when Sarah's older brother stood up from the stance. He was about 17, clearly played varsity football and easily twice the soccer kid's size. Apologize right now. The cocky kid suddenly looked nervous, glancing around for help. It was an accident, he mumbled. No, it wasn't. Everyone here watched you aim directly at her face. Other parents started nodding and voicing agreement. The kid looked to his mom for support. Mom, tell him it was an accident. But even his mother couldn't help him. Now the teenager stepped closer. I'm not asking again.

When were you sure you were about to lose your best friend? Zoe showed up at my door with a black eye and said today was the day we were getting her things from her dad's house while he was at work. I've been begging her to leave for months, ever since he broke her wrist, and seeing her face all swollen made me want to kill him myself. We drove to her house in silence, my knuckles white on the steering wheel, both of us knowing we had maybe two hours before his shift ended. The house reeked of beer and cigarettes, bottles everywhere, and I kept checking the window every few seconds while we threw her clothes into garbage bags. My heart stopped when I heard his truck pull up outside, that broken muffler sound I'd Learned to fear. Zoe made this horrible whimpering noise, and I knew we were screwed because her dad was already stumbling toward the front door, drunk in the middle of his work day. He crashed through the door and saw us with the bags, and his face went purple with rage. What the hell do you think you're doing? He roared, spit flying from his mouth. I tried to explain, but my voice came out shaky and scared, which made me hate myself because I promised Zoe I'd protect her. He slammed the door behind him so hard the walls shook, trapping us, and when Zoe tried to reason with him, he Backhanded her so hard she hit the wall and slid down it. I screamed. I screamed and caught her before she hit the floor, blood from her nose soaking my shirt, and suddenly I was angrier than scared. He smashed a beer bottle against the door frame and came at us with a jagged neck. Nobody steals from me, he said, and I pushed Zoe behind me, even though my legs were shaking so bad I could barely stand. We backed into the kitchen and he followed, taking his time, enjoying our fear. He flashed the bottle across my arm when I tried to shield Zoe, the glass cutting deep, hot blood immediately running down to my fingers and dripping on the linoleum. The pain, it was incredible, but it made everything clear. He was really going to kill us this time. I grabbed a pan from the stove and swung at his head, but he ducked and I only clipped his shoulder, making him stumble but not stopping him. He punched me in the stomach so hard I dropped to my knees, gasping, unable to breathe, my vision going black at the edges. While I was down, he kicked me in the ribs, and I felt something crack, white hot pain shooting through my chest, tasting blood in my mouth. Through tears and pain, I saw Zoe grab a knife from the counter, and my heart stopped because I knew this would make everything worse. He caught her wrist. As she swung and they struggled, him twice her size twisting her arm until something popped and she screamed, the knife clattering across the floor. I managed to dial 9 1 1 with bloody, shaking fingers, sobbing our address to the dispatcher, who kept asking me to repeat myself while he dragged Zoe by her hair through the kitchen. She was clawing at his hands, her feet scrambling for purchase on the blood slick floor, crying and begging him to let go. He threw her onto the back porch so hard the screen door came off its hinges. He picked up a knife and followed her outside, standing over her while she tried to crawl away, saying she'd never embarrass him again, that he'd raised her, and this was how she repaid him. I forced myself up, despite the stabbing pain in my ribs. My left arm used listen, bleeding, and grabbed a shovel. Leaning against the wall, I swung it with everything I had left and hit him across the back. But he barely flinched, turning and punching me in the face so hard I saw stars and felt my nose break. Blood poured into my mouth and I staggered backward, the world spinning. The sirens were so faint, like they were coming from another city, another world where help actually arrived in time. He pressed the knife to Zoe's throat, and she was begging, daddy, please, I love you. Please don't do this. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. Her voice was so small and broken, and I knew I had one chance left. I threw myself at him with everything I had, and we crashed through the porch railing, splinters of wood flying everywhere as we fell into the yard. He landed on top of me with all his weight, driving every bit of air from my lungs, my broken ribs, screaming in agony. He still had the knife and raised it above my chest while I was paralyzed, unable to breathe. I caught his wrists, but he was so, so much stronger, and the blade kept coming down, inch by terrible inch, my arms shaking with the effort of holding him back. I could hear myself screaming, but it sounded far away, like someone else's voice, like I was already floating outside my body watching this happen. Zoe was trying to pull him off, but her broken wrist made her weak, and he elbowed her in the face, sending her sprawling in the dirt. The knife tip touched my chest, and I felt it pierce my shirt, then my skin just breaking through a sharp point of pain that promised so much worse to come. I looked into his eyes and saw nothing human there at all. Just rage and alcohol and years of violence that would end with us dead in his backyard. My arms were giving out, muscles burning and failing, the blade sinking deeper, and the Siren still sounded miles away. And I knew The cops wouldn't make it in time. Full story on the channel below.

Is your accidentally caught your spouse cheating story. Chris and I had this sweet tradition of sending each other random TikToks throughout the day. Stupid dog videos, cooking fails, whatever made us laugh. We've been together for three years and I genuinely thought he was the one. Friday afternoon he sent me this video of a golden retriever trying to catch bubbles. I was smiling at my phone when something caught my eye. The username posting the video looked familiar. It was a private account called at Rachel waves 23. I knew Chris worked with a Rachel at his marketing company. He'd mentioned her a few times, always calling her his old coworker, even though they'd only been working together for like six months. Something about the way he said it always felt off. Curiosity got the better of me. I clicked on Rachel's profile. It was private, but her bio had a link to her Instagram account. I clicked through without really thinking about it. Her Instagram was public and I started scrolling through her recent posts. That's when my stomach dropped. There were pictures of Chris and Rachel together at some lake I'd never been to. In one photo, they were holding hands while sitting on a dock. In another, he was kissing her cheek while she laughed. Captions had heart emojis and inside jokes I didn't understand. Another perfect day with my favorite person with a bunch of heart eye emojis. The most recent post was from Tuesday, Chris had told me he was going on a guy's fishing trip that weekend, but there he was, arms wrapped around Rachel, next to a campfire, both of them looking way too comfortable together. Screenshot everything with shaking hands. My heart was pounding so hard I could hear it. Three years together. Three years of planning our future, talking about getting married, looking at apartments together. And he was playing house with some random coworker. That evening, Chris came home with takeout from our favorite Thai place, acting completely normal. He kissed me hello and asked about my day like nothing happened. When I asked about his weekend, he launched into this detailed story about the fishing trip. How the guys caught barely anything, how Mike fell off the boat, how they ran out of beer by Saturday night. Every word was a lie, but he told it so smoothly. I just nodded and smiled, pretending to believe him while my stomach twisted into knots. I didn't confront him then. I needed time to think. Sunday came, and his parents had invited us over for dinner, like they did every month. His mom always made this huge spread, and his dad would show off his latest woodworking project. They loved me, treated me like family. Always asking when Chris and I were going to make it official. We. We're sitting around their dining table, his mom serving her famous pot roast. When I decided I couldn't pretend anymore. His Whole family was there. His parents, his older sister, even his teenage nephew. I pulled out my phone very calmly and said,

Friend said I share too much about my feelings, so I stopped sharing anything at all. Jess came over to my place Friday night and I could tell something was bothering her by the way she kept sighing. You know what Britney told me today? She said flopping down on my couch. Her boyfriend is so mysterious and she's obsessed with him. Meanwhile, you texted me 12 times about being nervous for your presentation. The way she said it made me feel like I was some kind of burden. I wish you were more mysterious, more of a challenge. I should have known this would end badly when three weeks later she'd be crying at my door. But that night I just felt hurt and said, fine, I'll be mysterious that night. I usually would have texted her good night, but I didn't and it felt wrong not doing it. She sent me three question marks right away and I just wrote back all good and left it at that. Saturday morning came and normally I text her about my coffee and ask what she was up to, but I kept my phone in my pocket. By noon, she was texting you okay and I just sent a thumbs up, which killed me because I actually wanted to talk to her. Monday was the worst because I got the promotion I've been working for and all I wanted was to call her and celebrate. When we went to dinner that Night she asked about my day and I just said same old while scrolling through my phone, even though inside I was bursting to tell her. She leaned across the table trying to figure out what was going on with me. You seem different, she said. Good, different. And the crazy part was she seemed more into me than she had in months, which made me feel powerful but also completely hollow inside. The second week, she started showing up at my place without calling first and cooking these fancy dinners, basically doing anything to crack me open. I can't figure you out anymore, she said. Wednesday night, and she sounded excited about it. Britney so jealous. She as I got the mysterious boyfriend Jackpot. I wanted to tell her how dumb this whole thing was and how much I missed just talking to her normally, but I just shrugged and kept watching TV. my dad called because my mom was in the hospital for minor surgery and he was freaking out. I spent three hours calming him down while Jess sat next to me trying to figure out what was happening. After I hung up, she asked, is everything okay? And I wanted to fall into her arms and tell her everything, family, stuff. I said instead, it's handled. She killed me harder than she had in months and whispered, you're so strong. But I wasn't strong at all. I was just pretending. The third Thursday night at Eleven PM, Jess showed up at my door with her makeup running down, her face shaking.

My stepfather always treated me like I wasn't his real daughter. So I made sure he found out on Father's Day that he was right. When mom married Eric, I was 8 years old and desperate for a father figure. My biological dad had walked out when I was 3, leaving behind only a box of photos and unpaid child support. Garrett seemed perfect at first. He fixed our broken faucet, taught me to ride a bike, and never missed my school place. But everything changed when my half brother, Colton was born. Suddenly, I became the unwanted stepchild. Garrett would buy Colton expensive toys while telling me my allowance was earned, not given. At family dinners, he'd brag about Colton's first steps while dismissing my honorable achievements. When relatives visited, he'd introduce Colton as my son and me as my wife's daughter. The worst part was how he'd punish me for things Colton did. When Colton broke the living room lamp, I was grounded for not watching him properly. When he drew on the walls, I lost my art supplies for setting a bad example. Mom never intervened. She was so grateful to have a husband again that she pretended not to notice the favoritism. By high school, I'd accepted my role as the family scapegoat. I worked part time jobs to pay for my own clothes and saved every penny for college. Garrett made it clear I wouldn't receive help with tuition. That money was reserved for Colton's Future. Everything changed during my senior year when I needed medical records for a scholarship application. While searching through Mom's filing cabinet, I found my birth certificate. Under father, it listed someone named Pierce Buchanan. Not unknown like I'd always been told. Pierce Buchanan wasn't some deadbeat who'd abandoned us. A quick internet search revealed he was a successful architect living two hours away. His company website showed a man with my exact nose and stubborn cowlick. I found his phone number and called, hands shaking first you can and speaking. Hi, I managed. This might sound crazy, but I think you're my father. My name is. Oh, my god! He interrupted. I've been looking for you for 15 years. We met the following weekend at a coffee shop. Pierce explained how mom had vanished while he was deployed overseas with the National Guard. When he returned, she'd moved and changed her phone number. He'd hired investigators, but she'd covered her tracks well. I never stopped looking. And showing me a folder filled with investigator reports. I've been paying child support to a state account this whole time, hoping it would reach you somehow. Those unpaid child support checks. Mom and Garrett had been collecting them for years. Pierce was nothing like the deadbeat mom had described. He was kind, successful, and genuinely interested in my life. He'd saved every penny of child support in a college fund, enough to cover four years at any university I chose. For months. I kept our relationship secret while planning my revenge. Pierce helped me gather evidence of the diverted child support. We documented every payment, every forged signature, every lie. Father's Day arrived, and Garrett expected his usual Celebration. Colton had made him a clay mug.

13 year old niece giggled. Mom says if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice. While opening the 850 dollar phone I bought her. All 30 guests laughed except me. I nodded and with two taps I shut down every payment. Credit bills, subscriptions. Gone for years. I paid Lindsay's rent, covered Dad's gambling debts, handled Mom's credit cards, and bought countless expense. Expensive gift. I was the responsible one who always said yes when they needed money. But never really part of the family, just their walking ATM. The birthday party had 30 relatives gathered around. I driven straight from work to deliver that phone. Another expensive gesture to show my love. My niece peeled away the plastic with delicate fingers, but her words cut like glass. Mom says if you disappeared tomorrow, no one would even notice. The room erupted in laughter. Lindsay smirked from the couch like she'd been waiting for this moment. Mom pretended not to hear from the kitchen, but her shoulders lifted in silent approval. Dad raised his beer and chuckled. Well, she's not wrong. Even Uncle Gary, who barely knew me beyond family dinners, snorted into his drink. Cousins grinned. Thirty people laughed at my expense while I stood there like the fool I'd always been, the one who paid for everything but mattered to no one. But this time something different happened. Instead of forcing a smile, I felt my phone in my pocket and made two quick taps. Every Bill I paid every subscription I managed, every credit line I'd set up for them. Gone. Just like that. The voices blurred into distant noise as I slipped out without saying goodbye. No one noticed me leave the one thing my niece got right. I went home, packed a, then returned with an old black backpack. While they celebrated, I slipped inside, left it by the stairs, and disappeared forever. Inside was proof of everything. Receipts, bank statements, payment records, showing exactly how much I'd done for people who thought I was nothing. The explosion came the next morning. Dad pounded on my door at dawn, shouting about betrayal and family loyalty. Mom sent desperate texts. How could you do this to your own family? Lindsay called six times, then messaged. You think we can't live without you? Fine. See how long you last without a family. That evening, they broke into my apartment using an old key. Dad stormed in, red faced, mom behind him, both frantic about suddenly cancelled credit cards and unpayable bills. You ungrateful little troublemaker! Dad snarled, stepping closer with clenched fists. Try it, I said calmly, still drying my hair from the shower. His hand trembled but didn't move. We both knew he wasn't a fighter, just a bully hiding behind words. The cards don't work, Mom's voice cracked. Lindsay can't pay bills, the mortgage bounced. Everything I paid for is over, I said. You think we need you? Dad laughed bitterly. Seems like you Do. Since you broke into my apartment just to beg. Dad later invited me to a football game, claiming he wanted to talk like men. When did you see a kid you genuinely hope the world never lets grow up? I was at my daughter's soccer game when this 11 year old on the opposing team started losing his mind. Every missed shot he'd blame his teammates. You morons can't pass properly. This is your fault. I should be playing with kids who actually understand soccer. His mom cheered from the sidelines that that's right, sweetie. Demand better from them. These other kids are dragging down your potential. When the referee called a foul against him, the kid completely exploded. He kicked the soccer ball directly at the ref's legs, hitting him hard. You're terrible at this job. I want a different referee. My mom will get you fired. The referee staying calm, gave him a yellow card warning. Done. One more outburst and you're out of the game. The kid's response was even worse. He grabbed another ball and deliberately kicked it as hard as possible at a seven year old girl sitting on the bench with her team. The ball smacked her right in the face, knocking her backward. The little girl started crying, blood trickling from her nose. Her dad rushed down from the stands. Sarah, honey, are you okay? The 11 year old just shrugged with this cold smile. Maybe she shouldn't sit so close if she can't handle real soccer. This is a competitive sport. His mother actually started clapping from the bleachers. Good shot, honey. Show them what real Athleticism looks like these participation trophy kids need reality checks. Sarah's mom was livid. She's 7 years old. What is wrong with you? Nothing's wrong with excellence, the mom called back. Maybe teach your kid to pay attention during games. That's when Sarah's older brother stood up from the stance. He was about 17, clearly played varsity football and easily twice the soccer kid's size. Apologize right now. The cocky kid suddenly looked nervous, glancing around for help. It was an accident, he mumbled. No, it wasn't. Everyone here watched you aim directly at her face. Other parents started nodding and voicing agreement. The kid looked to his mom for support. Mom, tell him it was an accident. But even his mother couldn't help him. Now the teenager stepped closer. I'm not asking again.

All deaf people, what are some things you thought were silent, but later found out they weren't? I was born completely deaf and got my first cochlear implant when I turned 16. My parents had been pushing for it since I was little, but I kept refusing because I was perfectly happy in my silent world. The day they activated my implant was like stepping into an alien universe. Suddenly, everything had sound. And I mean everything. The audiologist warned me it would be overwhelming, but nothing could have prepared me for the chaos. The first shot came when I walked to the bathroom after my appointment. I sat down to pee and heard this loud rushing water sound. I jumped up, thinking something was broken. My mom had to explain through tears of laughter that peeing makes noise. For 16 years, I thought it was completely silent. But that was just the beginning of my sound discoveries. Walking became this weird symphony. Every footstep made noise on different surfaces. Carpet with soft thumps, hardwood with sharp clicks. And don't get me started on gravel. I spent 20 minutes just walking back and forth on our driveway, amazed that each step sounded like tiny explosions. Eating was absolutely disgusting. I had no idea chewing was so loud and gross. That first dinner, I kept asking my family if they could hear my mouth making all these wet, crunching sounds. They said yes, but you just learn to ignore it. How Do hearing people eat without being grossed out constantly. My cat Oliver became this whole different creature. Apparently, he'd been meowing at me for years and I never knew. The first time I heard him, I thought there was a baby crying somewhere. He also purrs, which sounds like a tiny motor running. Plus his footsteps on hardwood sound like little tap dancers. The biggest shock came during my first night sleeping with the implant. I kept hearing this rhythmic thumping sound that scared me. I woke up my parents thinking someone was in the house. Dad checked everywhere before realising I was hearing my own heartbeat through the pillow. Nobody told me hearts make noise. School became a nightmare of new sounds. Pencils scratching on paper sounded like nails on chalkboards. Kids clicking pens drove me absolutely crazy. The worst was when people cracked their knuckles. I literally screamed the first time my friend Jake did it, thinking he broke something. But the most embarrassing discovery happened during lunch. I was eating an apple when this girl named Tessa sitting nearby started laughing. I asked what was funny, and she said I was eating really loudly. Apparently, biting and chewing apples sounds like someone stomping on bubble wrap. I've been crunching away completely unaware that everyone could hear me. The weirdest thing was learning that some of my habits were actually really annoying. I used to tap my fingers on desks when I was thinking. Turns out that makes Noise and had been driving my teachers crazy for years. They just never said anything because they knew I couldn't hear it.

Deleted my friend's wedding photos in front of them. My best friend Jess was getting married and asked me to be her photographer. I've been doing photography for like 3 years now, mostly just for fun and some side cash, but nothing super professional. She said she trusted me more than some random person and honestly couldn't afford a real wedding photographer. Anyway, the wedding was beautiful. I spent the entire day running around getting shots of everything, her getting ready, walking down the aisle, the first kiss, all the family photos. I was exhausted but felt good about it. I probably took like 800 photos that day. After the reception just pulled me aside and said she couldn't wait to see them. She was literally glowing with excitement. I told her I'd edit them and have them ready in a week. That's when things got weird. Two days later, Jess texted me asking if I could rush the photos because her and her husband Jake wanted to post them on social media. I said, sure, no problem. But then she started texting me every single day asking for updates like multiple times a day. Then she called me crying saying her mom was asking about the photos and could I please just send her like 5 unedited ones. I sent her a few thinking that would calm her down. Wrong. The next day she showed up at my apartment unannounced. She had Jake with her and they both looked Stressed. She said they needed to talk about the photos. Apparently, Jess's mom had been showing the unedited photos I sent to family members and now everyone was asking why the photographer didn't know how to use proper lighting. Just said she was embarrassed and needed me to fix them immediately. I explained that editing takes time and I was working on them. But she cut me off and said she'd found another photographer who could fix my mistakes for $500. She wanted me to send her all the raw files so this other person could edit them instead. I was honestly hurt. These weren't even bad photos. The lighting was a little dim in a few shots because the venue was dark, but nothing that couldn't be fixed in editing. That's literally what editing is for. But here's where it gets really messed up. When I hesitated about sending the raw files, Jake stepped in and said they weren't paying me anything anyway, so I should just hand them over. He said they'd already been more than generous letting me practice on their wedding. Practice. I had busted my ass for 12 hours straight on their wedding day. I barely ate, missed most of the reception, and my feet were killing me from running around in heels all day. That's when Jess said something that made my blood boil. She looked me dead in the eye and said, if I was a.

Who woke up mid surgery? What happened? I woke up during throat surgery when I was 23. They had me knocked out to remove some polyps on my vocal cords. But something went horribly wrong with the anesthesia. When I first opened my eyes, I couldn't move a muscle. I was completely paralyzed from the medicine, but fully conscious. Everything felt muffled at first, like I was underwater. Then I started hearing snippets of conversation. The surgeon was discussing a baseball game with the nurse while he worked on my throat. I tried to scream to let them know I was awake, but my body wouldn't respond. I. I could feel everything. The cold metal of the tools sliding down my throat. The burning sensation as they cut away the growths. The metallic taste of blood pooling at the back of my mouth. But I couldn't even twitch a finger to signal I was conscious. My heart was pounding so hard, I thought it would burst. But the monitors didn't show any change. The paralytic they gave me was working perfectly. Too perfectly. I. I was trapped in my own body, forced to experience every excruciating second. At one point, the surgeon made a joke about my tattoos. Look at all this ink, he said. Wonder what her parents think. The nurse laughed and said something about kids these days. I wanted to cry, but couldn't even do that. Then things got worse. I felt this sharp, searing pain as Something went wrong. The surgeon swore under his breath. Damn it, we've got a bleeder. My throat was filling with blood faster than they could suction it out. The calm discussion about baseball was replaced with urgent commands. BP is dropping. Get me more suction. Where's that clamp? I, I could feel myself choking, drowning in my own blood, but still couldn't move. That's when the anesthesiologist finally noticed something was off with my readings. He rushed to adjust something in my IV, and everything started fading to black. The last thing I heard was him saying, she's fighting the paralytic. When I woke up in recovery, the nurse asked how I was feeling. I wrote on my notepad. I heard everything. The baseball game, the joke about my tattoos, the bleeding. Her face went white. They pulled my records and discovered my body had metabolized the anesthesia way faster than normal, but the paralytic had stayed at full strength. Apparently, it's a rare genetic condition that runs in my family, something my mom forgot to mention. The hospital tried to sweep it all under the rug. They offered to waive all my medical bills if I sign some papers promising not to sue. But that wasn't what I wanted. I just wanted them to document my case so it wouldn't happen to anyone else. The surgeon and anesthesiologist came to apologize later that day. The surgeon looked like he hadn't slept in days. He kept saying how sorry he Was about the tattoo comments. I wrote back, the baseball game was more offensive. Yankees suck. But here's the crazy part. When they checked the surgery recording, apparently they film everything for teaching purposes. They found something disturbing during the bleeding incident.

How did you scam the scammer? Last Tuesday, I was making lunch for my kids when my phone rang. Unknown number, but I picked up anyway. Big mistake, right? This guy with a thick accent starts telling me he's from the IRS and I owe $4,200 in back taxes. If I don't pay immediately with gift cards, the police will arrest me within an hour. Now, here's the thing. I literally just got my tax refund two weeks ago. My accountant, Beth, handled everything perfectly, and I even got money back. So I knew this dude was full of it. But instead of hanging up, something clicked in my brain. My neighbor, Mrs. Kim, had fallen for this exact scam last month and lost $800. Time for payback. I started crying into the phone. Oh, no, I can't go to jail. My kids need me. The scammer ate it up. He told me to go to target and buy iTunes gift cards worth $2,000 as a first payment. I said I needed an hour to get the money together. First I called my cousin Jake, who's a cop, told him what was happening, and he said to keep the guy on the line as long as possible. Then I started my revenge tour. I called the scammer back an hour later, sobbing. I'm at target, but I'm so confused. Which gift cards do I buy? He walked me through it step by step. I pretended to be this helpless single Mom who didn't understand technology. Sorry, can you repeat that? My hands are shaking so bad. For the next 20 minutes I wandered around target asking him questions. Do I need the physical cards or the digital ones? Cashier is asking for I. D. Is that normal? Sorry, my 4 year old is having a meltdown in the cart. Finally I told him I had the cards. He was so excited. Probably thinking about his commission. I read him the first number. Okay, it starts with 5. Wait, is that a 5 or an S? The scratching messed it up. I gave him completely fake numbers, mixing up digits, going super slow. After 20 minutes of this he got frustrated. Ma'am, those numbers don't work. Go buy new cards. So I did the whole routine again. Drove to Walmart, called him back crying harder. The first store's cards didn't work. Are you sure you're really from the IRS? This time I really went for it. I'm in the Walmart parking lot fake crying so loud other shoppers were staring. My kids are asking why Mommy is buying $5,000 worth of iTunes cards. My daughter wants to know if we're going to be homeless. The scammer actually tried to comfort me. Don't worry ma'am, just read me the

Charlie Kirk has died at the age of 31. Yes, you heard me right. Charlie Kirk, the conservative guy that is pro Trump supporter and the debater got shot and killed at a college campus in Utah. And the thing is that people were celebrating on his death like it's a dictator day. But guys, he is a Trump supporter. Of course, some bad thing were coming out of his mouth. People were celebrating, making jokes about his death. And most disgusting part is that some people post a clip of him getting shot and blood just coming out of neck like it's a fountain. Guys, guys, this guy was a freaking dad. He had a wife, two kids and this assassin was the one who took Charlie away from his wife and kids. And now, let's imagine this for a second. Imagine you're one of the Charlie's kid, you're standing there watching him debating about some gun violence and boom, gunshot. And you're just seeing him slowly dropping dead while a pool of blood coming out of his neck. That is the way to get traumatized forever seeing your father die in front of you. I'm sending my condolences to Kurt's family. And guys, please be respectful in the comments. And let their family have some privacy. Although he has a lot of bad takes as a Trump supporter. But no one deserves to die for having different opinions.

Bro, I can't figure out if there's 8 billion birthdays or just 365. I think about it. Every single person on earth has a birthday, but at the same time, there's only 365 days in a year. So does that mean everyone is just sharing the same 365 birthdays? Like technically, your birthday isn't even special. You're just in the queue with 20 million other people. Imagine blowing out your candles and somewhere across the world another dude is doing the exact same thing at the same time. That's not even your day. That's just the world's group project. And don't even get me started on leap year babies. They don't even exist half the time. They're just DLC characters that spawn in every four years. So is it 8 billion or 365? Shut your fucking mouth.

This week has been absolutely horrific. And honestly, humanity is finished. Firstly, Charlie Kirk. Assassinated on stage at a university. Died at 31 years old. I didn't like him, but celebrating his death is messed up. He had a family, two kids and a wife. Imagine watching someone you love die like that in public, in front of everyone. Nobody deserves that. Then there's Arena, a 23 year old refugee, a Ukrainian girl who literally escaped war, only to be stabbed on a train in Charlotte for being white. She wasn't doing anything. She was just trying to live. And the worst part, nobody helped her. She was bleeding out while people just stood there just minding their business. That's absolutely dialogue. And then the D4 V D situation. I don't know much about this, but I heard they found a decomposing body in his car. And it was a girl. What has humanity come to? It feels like every headline is darker than the last. This world is cooked.

Bro, nothing cracks me up more than the sorry for the late reply text. Like late. That wasn't late. That was a whole ghosting session. You disappeared for 24 hours like you were filming an episode of survivor and then they pop back like oops, I was busy. Busy with what? A NASA mission? You didn't just reply late, you respond after a whole day cycle. Honestly, don't say late reply. Just admit you didn't feel like texting me back. Be real. Because if I vanish for 24 hours, trust people are filing a missing person's report.

Who the fuck named the Sahara Desert anyway? Sahara is just the Arabic word for deserts. You named it the desert. Desert. Wait a go. Chai tea? I'll take European imperialist who never bothered to translate the local languages for $200, Alex. Soviet means union. The Union. Union. We're good at this. The world is full of nothing but moon moons. We are all moon moon. All of us.

I hate when I tell someone I have autism and they immediately think I'm one of those TikTok autistic people who treat it like an aesthetic. Like no, I don't call cats cars. I'm not playing for saken in Dandy's world. I don't call ADHD and autism silly. And I didn't diagnose myself after watching a 30 second slideshow with sparkles. No shade if you're into that stuff, but don't group me with it. I didn't spend 14 years wondering why I'm wired the way I am, sit through evaluations, paperwork, an actual psychologist just for people to assume. I got bored and gave myself a sticker diagnosis because it looked fun. And I'm sorry, but those people are so unbearable. Same recycled, silly goober point three jokes, same copy paste alt style and same performative internet personality. Anyways, I have nothing else to add. Hope you guys enjoyed my first video.

You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like, no big fall out, no drama. Just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened. Like, what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part. I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this. Or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't. Cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. Yeah. I could reach out. I could say something. Deep down, I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it. Pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them, I really wanted to stay.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parent decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to Enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. Their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of Zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.

People who work in HR, what's the wildest thing you've discovered that LED to a firing? Two women in our accounting department got pregnant at almost the exact same time. Jessica found out first and was super excited, showing everyone her ultrasound photos and talking about baby names during lunch breaks. Three weeks later, Amber announced she was also pregnant, due just two weeks after Jessica. Everyone was thrilled. The whole office was buzzing about having two babies so close together. Both women submitted their maternity leave paperwork right away, since we needed time to arrange coverage for their positions. Jessica went on leave first. When her daughter was born, everything seemed normal. Then Amber went into labour early, about a week before her scheduled leave was supposed to start. That's when things got weird. Our payroll system flagged an error. When I tried to process Amber's leave, it said someone had already filed maternity leave under her name and Social Security number. I figured it was just a computer glitch, so I called our IT department. They pulled up the records and found something impossible. According to our system, Amber had already been on maternity leave for three weeks. But she'd been working the whole time. She was literally at her desk yesterday. I started digging deeper and found the original leave request filed under Amber's name. It had her Social Security number, her employee ID, everything. But the submission date was from a month ago, right when Jessica Had filed hers. Something was seriously wrong here. I pulled the security footage from the day the duplicate paperwork was submitted. At 6:47 p m, after most people had left, Jessica was sitting at Amber's desk, using her computer. She spent 43 minutes there printing documents and filling out forms. But it got worse. Way worse.

Hating on a queer ship is not homophobic. I know it's hard to hear, but it's true. I fear just because the ship that you love just happens to be gay or lesbian doesn't always mean all hate that is directed at it is only because of it being gay. I genuinely don't know what it is with some people in the LGBTQ community using discrimination as Agacha when someone hates on a queer ship. And it's even worse when the ship is toxic. Like there is a good reason to hate it. Maybe if we stop calling the most stupidest shit homophobic, you would actually take the real discrimination against us seriously. Cause no one is gonna take you seriously when you cry and whine over someone's opinion and assume that it's discrimination when it's.

My boyfriend saw my Venmo and asked, why are you getting paid $500 weekly by someone called Sugar Daddy? I nearly choked on my cereal because that was not a conversation I wanted to have at 8:00am on a Tuesday. It's not what it looks like, I said quickly. But Jake was already scrolling through my transaction history with his eyebrows raised. Really? Because it looks like you're getting paid every Friday for the past three months by someone whose contact name is literally Sugar daddy Mike with money bag emojis. He turned his phone toward me showing the evidence. Are you seriously doing that kind of work? Without telling me, I grabbed my phone back, my face burning red. Jake, I swear to God it's not what you think. Mike is my boss at the pet sitting company. He stared at me like I'd grown a third leg. Your boss pays you through Venmo and you call him Sugar Daddy Mike? I realized how absolutely insane this sounded, but it was the truth. The company payroll system has been broken for months. Mike pays all the employees through Venmo. And I saved his contact as Sugar Daddy Mike as a joke because he's always buying us coffee and treats for the dogs. Jake was not buying this explanation at all. That's the most ridiculous cover story I've ever heard. Look, I'll prove it. I called Mike right there in our kitchen. He answered on the second ring with his Usual cheerful voice. Hey, and you're not scheduled until this afternoon. Everything okay? I put him on speaker. Mike, my boyfriend thinks we're having some kind of inappropriate relationship because of how you pay us and how your name shows up in my phone. Mike burst out laughing. Oh, no, not again. This happened with my daughter's boyfriend last month. He thought she was cheating on him with her sugar daddy Mike. He explained to Jake that his payroll company had been hacked six months ago, so he'd been paying everyone through cash apps. Jake still looked skeptical. But why Sugar Daddy Mike? Mike laughed even harder. Because I spoil my employees and the pets rotten. Free coffee every day, premium dog treats, bonuses for good work. The girls started calling me Sugar Daddy Mike because I'm always buying supplies and treating them like family. He invited Jake to come by the office to meet the team. You can meet the other four dog walkers who probably also have me saved as Sugar Daddy Mike in their phones. I could see Jake starting to believe the story, but he was still embarrassed about jumping to conclusion. This is why you should have just told me you had a job, he muttered. After we hung up with Mike, Jake apologized profusely. I should have just asked you directly instead of making assumptions. But then he got curious about other things. Wait, if you're only making $250 twice a month, how are You paying for all those expensive dinners you've getting delivered? My stomach dropped because I've been hoping he wouldn't notice my Doordash habit. That's a different situation, I said, trying to change the subject. But Jake was already connecting dots. Please tell me you're not actually doing sugar daddy stuff on the side to pay for food. I just waved it off and tried to ignore him for the rest of the day. The next day, I brought Jake to the pet sitting office to meet Mike and prove my story. He was exactly what you'd expect, 50 something guy in dog hair covered clothes who immediately offered us both coffee and dog treats to sample. See, he said to Jake, total sugar daddy behaviour but completely innocent. The other employees confirmed that they all had similar contact names for Mike and that he was basically the most generous boss ever. Last month he paid for my dog's vet Bill when I couldn't afford it, one co worker said. Jake felt terrible for assuming the worst and bought lunch for the whole pet sitting crew as an apology. I watched too much true crime, he explained to Mike. When I I saw those payments, my mind immediately went to the darkest possibility. Mike laughed it off and said it happened more often than you'd think. My wife gets suspicious, looks at the bank when she deposits checks made out to Sugar Daddy, Mike's Pet Care. That night, Jake finally relaxed. Convinced everything was fine. But when I checked my phone before bed, another 500 dollar transfer came in. The message read, good job. He bought every word.

Bro, can someone explain to me why the internet is obsessed with the dumbest meme ever? 6, 7. That's it? Two random numbers and suddenly everyone's acting like it's peak comedy. Like this weekend the calendar hits six for Saturday, seven for Sunday and people are losing their minds. Wow, crazy. Never seen numbers before. Someone asks me how old I am, I say 67 and apparently that's the funniest joke of the year. No, it's not clever, it's not deep. It's just two numbers slapped together like a bad group project. And yet somehow my whole feed is flooded with it. TikTok comments. Just a wall of people spamming 67 like they unlocked a cheat code. Bro, you don't look cool, you look cooked. Teachers ask what page we're on and kids scream 6 7 like it's a cult meme. How is this funny? It's literally the definition of cringe. And the worst part, the more I complain, the more people spam it. Like I'll rant for 2 minutes straight and the comments are still just 67 67, 67. At this point if feels less like a meme and more like brain rot. It's everywhere and now I can't even escape it. I'll wake up, check my phone, and first thing I see another 67 meme. My brain is broken. So fine. If you're part of this chaos, prove it. Type 67 in the comments right now. I wanna see the entire comment section cooked beyond repair.
NA

I can't watch anything that doesn't have a lesbian couple. Like it gets so boring. It doesn't even have to be a full on lesbian relationship. I'll happily ship two girlfriends together. I'm so starved for lesbian representation at this point. It's not that I hate straight ships. I just can't care about them. Like why would a man be there? Especially when it's written from the perspective of the girl? Same with gay ships. Yay, queer representation. Love the gays, but Loki, I just can't get invested. There's some exceptions though, like Pure Vanilla x White Lily from Cookie Run and a couple others, but that's it. I wish WLW ships were more normalized. 99% of the time when there's a girl who could end up with either a guy or another girl, the writers always go with the guy, even when the gay dynamic is clearly better. On the same note, I don't care if the girls I'm shipping have only interacted like four times. I love rare pairs most of the time. I also don't even care if the dynamic between the girls is more toxic. I get more joy from shipping girls together. I love you.

I don't care that Charlie Kirk died. And before some of you guys attack me, I do feel sorry for his family. I do hope that they can find peace as I'm sure he was a great husband, dad, son and whatever else. But then again, I've seen people say that people who are happy are disgusting. I just don't agree with that. Nobody is going to have empathy for a guy who said he'd force his daughter to give birth to her rapist baby. And how I see it, people are happy because Kirk was somewhat an oppressor who was also friends with an oppressor. And wasn't this the same guy who said that gun deaths were worth it to keep the 2nd amendment? Should he have been killed? No. Do I feel sad? No. Do I feel empathy for him? No. But until then, Jim Jam is out. Hashtag stay gooning.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. Morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

Do you guys ever laugh so hard to the point where you actually run out of breath and things get serious? Like, I swear there must be at least one person who passed away from literally laughing too hard. And I'm talking about the laughter that has you wheezing and makes you skip the gym because it gives you a whole core workout. So I was in freshman year, right? Everything was going decent. I was meeting new kids and stuff at lunch. I sat at a table with a group of my friends from middle school and I promise that was one of the funniest lunches I've ever had. I don't know why, but each single joke would have the table bursting out laughing. At the table, two of my friends were arguing and one of them said, shut up, bro. That's why when you smile, you have a 99% match to an orangutan. My other friend next to me choked on his rice and just spat it all over the table. Principal who was monitoring the cafeteria got mad and yelled at him to clean it up. The whole lunch table lost it. I mean, slapping the table and snorting. I was laughing so hard that there was a point where I actually couldn't breathe. My heart actually dropped. I legit panicked and it felt like an eternity. The table noticed and one of them said, breathe, brother, breathe. And I swear on dead dogs, he almost caused My unofficial passing, although I almost died. Damn, that wouldn't be a bad way to go out.

So it's been about a day since Charlie Kirk died, and I don't really give a fuck now. Of course, my heart goes out to his family, but he was genuinely such a weirdo. And some of the things he said were crazy. What do you mean? You'd force your daughter to give birth if she was raped. And some of his other takes were just shit, too. Like he supported pedophilia, was very racist and islamophobic, anti immigrants and abortion, and said black people are criminals, just to name a few things. Mind you, he was pro gun violence, so he kind of had this coming.
NA

so today was my first day at an American high school and oh my god, I have a lot to say so buckle up. First of all, to the motherfucker that decided school should start at 7:45 in the morning, fuck you. Say your prayers and count your days because I am personally going to file a lawsuit against you. Like I already adjusted to the time zones. I legit thought I was safe. Nope, I'm suddenly expected to brush my teeth before the sun even knows what's going on. Okay, moving on, let's talk about the cult you guys have labeled school fashion. Why was everyone wearing red and black pajama pants? Was this planned? It was like walking into a Christmas themed asylum. I'm not even gonna hate because I am absolutely dragging my host mom to target to get some so I can blend in with the cult members. Anyway, first thing they gave me was my schedule and then first thing I did was hide in the bathroom because what the fuck do you mean I'm supposed to actually talk to people? Absolutely not. Homeroom teacher was chill though. Shout out to Mr Lincoln for not forcing me to stand up and introduce myself. Fucking legend. Thankfully my host sister was in most of my classes so I just stayed with her and her friends. Now my classes were really easy like I suspected. So to the people who told me school was gonna be Hard yikes that is until I had biology 5th period bro. I did not realize how many science words exist that I don't know in English. They gave me a language helper like a translator. I felt like a fucking idiot. They also messed up my classes again and put me in French class. What am I supposed to do in there? They said it's gonna take a few weeks before I get my classes switched but you know what? I actually kind of get it now. I get why you guys hate French, but I don't even think it's the language's fault. I think your teachers just hate their jobs about lunch. Oh my God, lunch was disgusting. Starting to feel like the chicken was not chicken. How are you people not dying from this? Do you just build immunity over the years like a vaccine but edible also. Why is it so short? 45 minutes? That is not enough. I'm gonna stop here before this turns into a fucking documentary tomorrow I'll give you the tea on the people instead of the school itself. Anyways, I'm done yapping so bye.

Have you ever noticed that the school bathroom during class just stops being a bathroom? You walk in expecting silence, maybe a cough, maybe the faint smell of lemon cleaner. Instead, it's a fully operational underground economy. First of all, there's a kid leaning against the wall like a mob boss selling individual skittles for 50. Sensei. He's got a little ziploc bag of them and this tiny notebook where he writes down who owes him money. Like, bro, what happens if I don't pay you? Are you gonna send the urinal guys after me? Second stall. The door is locked, feet dangling. Kids not using the bathroom? Nope. They're sitting on the toilet lid like it's a lounge chair, playing Clash Royale on full volume. And when you glance under the stall, they shush you like you're interrupting a performance. By the sinks, there's three kids treating it like a mirror photo shoot. They've got sunglasses, LED lights. One kid's holding a ring light. Where did they get a ring light? We've been in school for two hours. I don't even think the janitor has a ring light. Then you got the acrobats. Some seventh grader decides the handicap stall is now a gymnast. Sticks are real, and they're doing pull UPS on the stall door frame while their friend times them with a stopwatch. Meanwhile, the door is creaking like it's seconds away from ending someone's bathroom. And through all this, the only person actually using the bathroom, Is the mystery kid. They're always in the last stall, always completely silent. And somehow they've been in there since second period. So now I'm just standing there holding my hall pass, trying to wash my hands without getting roped into buying a two dollar Starbucks or accidentally joining a TikTok. And when I leave, the teachers, like, you were gone for 10 minutes. What were you doing? Ma'am, I just survived an entire bathroom surface. I think I deserve extra credit.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque. Not here on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare, bro. Rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught smallpox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got a I rockets to Mars and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First, it was Covid tearing everything apart. Then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.
NA

TW my opinion I genuinely hate when my friends have the same interests as me don't get me wrong the ones that just like it too are okay. I'm talking about the ones who think they're a bigger fan than me like you just started liking it because I told you about it and and then they proceed to make it their whole personality and yeah they're my friend but it annoys me so much I just don't really care if we are friends in that moment if you're like that please think about your personality and change it anyways. Bye Ari out.

I don't care if I'm gonna get hate or not, but why do lesbians brag about being lesbians? Like, okay, we get it. You are, woo, woo, woo! But why are you trying to let everyone know about it? Okay, but like the other day I saw a girlfriend and a boyfriend just having a romantic moment. I opened the comments, you know, like always, and tell me why. I saw a girl saying, is he bothering you? Queen? You cannot be serious. Lesbians are just weird. Sorry, not sorry, LMAO.

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20 and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude, maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, figured why not? My little sister Mia is 15 and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for like an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. And Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I found my Sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what?

Got herself pregnant is the dumbest phrase in the world. Like, for real. If it was possible to get pregnant by ourselves, we'd have eaten all the men long ago. It actually is possible to get pregnant without the sperm of a man whatsoever, using bone marrow from another woman. A child conceived this way can only be female. So actually, men are entirely useless. Fun fact. Let's begin the feast.

Everybody switching up on Charlie Kirk just because he's dead and has a family, but let's not pretend we forgot who he was. This is the same man who stood on stages telling women how they should live their lives, saying Palestine doesn't exist, being racist, etc. So when people suddenly feel sympathy or wanna act empathetic, it feels fake. I'm not saying people who celebrate his death are in the right, because why care about a person like him? If anything I just feel bad for his family. And I know I'm not saying he deserved to die. I'm simply saying why do you care? Now get out.
NA

Secret signs A boy likes you but is just shy. The last one will shock you. His body language gives him away. He sneaks, glances at you, but quickly looks away when you notice. His feet or body are often pointed toward you. He plays with his hands, adjust clothes, taps foot when you're around. TikTok knows someone who has feelings for you, but it's too afraid to tell you it's the second person. When you click share and more. He gets nervous around you. His voice cracks or he stumbles over words. When talking to you, he finds small excuses to be near you. He shows up where you are more often than coincidence allows. He remembers the little things. Comment I hate when and let your keyboard finish the sentence. Even if he doesn't talk much, he notices details about you, like your favourite snack, something you said weeks ago. He pays attention in ways others might overlook. He interacts differently with you than with others. He may be loud and confident with friends, but quiet around you. He engages online more than in person. He texts, comments, or likes your posts, but is quieter face to face. He's more relaxed when there's no direct eye contact. Before the last fact. Please like the video and follow or you might never see me again. His friends know something. They tease him when you're around. They may drop hints or act differently towards you because they know how he Feels

I don't think people realize how sweet it is when someone laughs at your unfunny jokes. Like they know it wasn't really funny and you know it too, but they still let out this little laugh just so you don't feel awkward. It's not even about the joke. It's about the kindness behind it. That tiny moment where they choose to make you feel good instead of letting you shrink into silence. It honestly means more than people think. Well, anyways, thanks out Mwah.

Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. And Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I found my Sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what?
