Oh, men get raped too. Yeah, but that doesn't mean you get to bring up men's experiences just to put down women's. As much as male essay deserves more acknowledgement and representation, nobody should be using men's trauma as an excuse to silence female victims. And the phrase men get raped should be its own sentence, not an add on to whenever a woman talks about her personal experiences. And if you do only bring up male essay just to tear down women's experiences, you're a scumbag, a weirdo, and an annoying attention seeker. Anyways, teary out.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

I honestly love when people remember the smallest details about you. Like you'll mention something so random one time and later they bring it up or do something with it like wow, you actually listened! That stuff means so much cause it makes you feel seen in a way most people don't bother to make you feel lowkey. That's one of the sweetest kinds of love. Anyways, VEX out. Mwah!

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy, Robert, looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess. Looking for a rich boyfriend, smart girl, lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interesting perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me and continued his lecture. A girl like you probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was familiar, With the artist's work, Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from talk. Robert decided to test me, rapid firing questions. Who's baskiat? What's kiarascuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See, this is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men. But Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie, real universities. He returned to my painting now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. What Riley has achieved here would cost probably 100,000 in education to even attempt. The materials alone cost more than you'd make in a month at whatever retail job you have. He looked at my outfit with disgust. Target, clearance rack, right? Someone who shops there couldn't possibly grasp the investment in this piece. He probably spent more on one brush than your entire outfit. When I suggested the artist might be self taught, Robert sneered at me. Is that how you Learned about art? Painting parties? Robert grabbed my wrist to pull me to another angle. His grip too tight. You're too stupid to even stand in the right spot. Riley intended for this to be viewed from exactly here. Your ignorance is actually disrespectful to his work. He kept his hand on my wrist while explaining, though honestly, explaining this to you is like teaching calculus to a toddler. You lack the basic foundation to understand any of it. He noticed me trying to pull away and.
NA

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated, remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, would grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept filling glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting Back or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.

My wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her? After three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at two a m, reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends, authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week, she said maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday, she noticed. You're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes. Obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet. The twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny, because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal. Next one who spends weekends bar hopping, crying about how all men are trash. Crystal. Hey. My wife's been telling me about Your amazing single life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth with you guys? Talk about through the phone? Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out? But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal backpedal. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said, dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting? Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at 35. Debbie, great news. My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in? I. There's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale, watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard, but they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can Go to yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine. Listening to you repeat your poison every night. Or yours. Because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love. You got it. The irony. Her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed too hard. Janet called later, begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal

My stepchildren said they answer only to their biological parents. So I changed the locks, canceled every privilege in my name and told their father pick up was tonight. No one argued. I'm Tom, 35, and I've been married to Lisa for 18 months. She has two kids from her first marriage, Marcus, 17, and Sophia, 15. Their biological father lives about 40 minutes away and sees them maybe twice a month when he feels like showing up. When Lisa and I got together, I genuinely wanted to be the stepdad I never had growing up. My own father walked out when I was 12, so I knew what it felt like to need a father figure. I thought being a good stepdad meant being the yes man, always supportive, always generous, always understanding. New school clothes? Sure, no problem. Concert tickets for Sophia's favorite band, of course. When Marcus wanted the latest gaming setup, I dropped $800 without blinking when he crashed my car last month after staying hang out past curfew. I didn't even make him pay the 500 dollar deductible. But respect, that was a completely different story. It started with small things. You're not our real dad became their go to response whenever I asked them to do basic household tasks. When I'd ask Marcus to take out the trash, he'd say, I only listen to actual parents. When Sophia left dishes piled in the sink for days, she'd shrug and say, my mom didn't tell Me to clean them. Lisa would have talks with them about respect and they'd apologize and behave for maybe a week. Then we'd be right back to the same pattern. The breaking point came last Friday. I decided to leave work early to surprise Lisa with dinner plans for our anniversary weekend. I pulled into the driveway around 3 in the afternoon and immediately knew something was wrong. There were cars I didn't recognize park on our street and I could hear music blasting from inside the house. I walked through my front door to find about 20 teenagers having a full blown party in my living room. Red solo cups everywhere. The coffee table pushed against the wall. Kids I'd never seen before eating food from my kitchen. My house was completely trashed. Broken lamp, mysterious stains on my white couch, empty bottles scattered everywhere. Marcus was in the center of it all, acting like the king of the castle when he saw me. He didn't even look embarrassed, just annoyed that I'd shown up. Party's over, I said loudly. Everyone out now. The music stopped. Kids started grabbing their stuff and heading for the door, but Marcus didn't move. Clean this mess up immediately, I told him once the house was empty. He actually laughed. You can't tell me what to do. You're not my father. This is my house, Marcus. My couch that's ruined. My lamp that's broke. Can no. Sophia interrupted, appearing from the kitchen. It's Mom's house, too. We live here. We only take orders from real family, not from some guy mom married. That's when I noticed something that made my blood run cold. The door to my home office was wide open, and I always kept it locked. I walked over and immediately saw that my safe was open. My emergency cash envelope, the one where I've been saving money for Lisa's surprise birthday trip to Hawaii, was completely empty. $2,000 gone. I turned around slowly. Where's my money? Marcus shrugged with this smug expression. What money? I don't know what you're talking about. $2,000 from my safe. The safe that was locked this morning. Prove we took it, Sophia said with a smile. That made me realize this wasn't just disrespect anymore.

Bro, fuck you mean Charlie Kirk just passed? Like what the hell is even going on this week? A body found in David's car. Some girl got slime just because she's sitting down in a bus and this bullshit, I beg of you, don't even look it up. I'm begging you right now because that had me traumatized. I'm grown and people call me UNC and I still can't do blood. The second it started he pouring out like juice. I wanted to tap out bro. That's exactly why I could never be a surgeon or anything medical long term. I don't care what my parents say. Basically he was giving a speech at a university and some old bald sniper just came out of nowhere and actually took him out from like 30 feet away and it's wild because you can disagree with a man, I know I didn't with some things he said and think he said some foul or even racist stuff but at the end of the day he had a wife and two little daughters. You can't wish death on nobody. This division between Republicans and Democrats is gonna spread wide faster than the rift in Superman literally. Watch the presidential debate from 2008 between Obama and some other guy I can't remember. Jokes aside, shit was respectful. Now we got they're eating the dogs and Sleepy Joe memes from the two presidential debates from last year. That sniper got the worst karma coming his Way cause assassinations like this never make sense. You really gonna pull up with a rifle, plan it out and take someone's life when you the dude who's already old shooter should have spent his time in a retirement home or some shit or a warden. Yeah, that unless we're talking about monsters like Epstein, controversial people ain't worth that. I pray that Kirk's family gets through this. May god help America.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque. Not here on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare, bro. Rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught smallpox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got a I rockets to Mars and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First, it was Covid tearing everything apart. Then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Sky, Taylor kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her moods. Things. Year 1 was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball in our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I've forgotten how To enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor, I only helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught sky to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after Three years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.
NA

So Charlie Crick just died. Look, I never looked up to the guy or idolized him, but people celebrating his death isn't cool at all for any reason. And whatever he did is in the past. Yeah, he could have been a rapist or whatever, but being happy because someone died isn't cool at all. I know for sure there will be a couple of haters, but it's alright. I don't care. But like, just imagine one day Charlie's kids go on social media to see what happened to his dad and they start seeing all the videos and comments people are saying about him. He might have not been the best person in the world, but at least he had passion for his speeches and look like a great father. He might have done fucked up shit, but that's normal. I fucked up too. And I'm still here because y'all wanted me to be here. And if you don't got anything nice to say, just don't say it. Imagine Charlie was your dad and you start seeing people being happy about his death anyways, may Charlie quick rest in peace.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around, and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram. Tall, brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem? He didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby, and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed after that first dinner. My mom kept inviting him back. Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand, asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together, and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, would grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night, after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly. Made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me. We can't keep this up forever, you know? That message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing. And I wasn't. Not even close. Instead of texting Back or giving him some weird speech? I invited him over for dinner at my place. Cooked his favorite pasta dish. The one my mom always made. When he came over. At the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them. Just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.

My wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her after three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at 2:00am reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week she said, maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday she noticed you're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes, obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet, the twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says, you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal next 1 who spends weekends bar hopping crying about how all men are trash. Crystal, hey, my wife's been telling me about your amazing Single life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth with you guys. Talk about. Through the phone, Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out. But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal back pedal. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting. Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at 35. Debbie, great news. My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in. I, there's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help, help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard. But they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can go To yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine listening to you repeat your poison every night. Or yours because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love? You got it. The irony, her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed too hard. Janet called later begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal.

If there's an earthquake, just get on a plane. Like, bro, the ground is the one having a seizure, not the sky. Why are you crying in your collapsing house when Spirit Airlines is right there? Imagine everyone getting crushed under rubble while you're 30,000 feet in the air. Skill issue, honestly, if earthquakes scare you, just become a pilot. That way you can crash into the fault line yourself and speed run the ricter scale, bro. Said earthquake killed thousands. No, that was me hitting autopilot. Shut your fucking mouth.

Things that boys do when they like you. First thing, he'll try to make you laugh, even if it means making a fool of himself. Your smile is worth it. TikTok can reveal who secretly likes you. It's the second person that shows up when you click share. Then more. Boys will often find excuses to be around you, like asking for your help or accidentally bumping into you. 20 million people have the same birthday as you. Write yours in the comments to see who shares it. If he's always the first to view your stories or react to your posts, it's because he's keeping an eye on what you're up to. Most people's phone doesn't have this secret emoji, just comment star in square brackets to unlock it. Boys might act more confident or try to impress you when they're around you. It's their way of catching your attention. If you wanna know more, signs like this, follow now because you won't wanna miss what's next. When a guy likes you, he'll find ways to touch you, even if it's just a friendly pat on the back or a high five. If he remembers tiny details you've mentioned, like your favourite song or a story from months ago, he's definitely interested. Hit like if you've seen these signs before and drop a comment if you think someone's been showing them to you. And here's the last one. Boys might tease or playfully annoy you, but it's just their way. Of getting closer and seeing your reaction.

That's not defense, that's disrespect. And we're sitting here like, maybe it's peaceful. Well, it's a bit late for peace when we're the ones firing missiles at it immediately. You don't get to throw hands and then act surprised when it looks back. It was just floating there, minding its business. We threw the first punch, it didn't even blink. And now we're all just standing around like that's normal. If it ever turns around and starts charging up, we're cooked. 2,025 cannot get any crazier. But hey, at least it's ending with a bang. Follow for more daily rants!

And bro, her friends acted like this was the funniest thing they've ever seen. But I wasn't gonna just let this slide now. So I did some digging and found all their social media channels and saw that they're actually trying to blow up on TikTok themselves, just not with much success. My dad treated us like crap until his boss had dinner at our house. For 17 years, I lived with two different fathers. The perfect employee who preached about his perfect marriage and strong kids, and the man who made mom sob herself to sleep for buying the wrong coffee brand. Mom Learned to time grocery shopping before his Thursday bowling league when he'd be rushed. Once she forgot, dad discovered generic pasta instead of name brand. You're too stupid to even shop, right? No wonder you never amounted to anything. He made her return every item while he watched, then quizzed her on prices to prove she was wasting his money. She cried in the car afterward. That weekend's company barbecue. I do the shopping because the wife gets overwhelmed by choices. His co workers laughed at how understanding he was. My brother walked past Dad's home office during a virtual meet. Invisible for just two seconds, dad kept smiling, discussing collaborative workspace culture. The second he clicked leave meeting, he cornered my brother. You made me look like I can't control my own house. The belt came out. Two weeks of complete silence followed. My brother stopped eating, stopped talking at school. Teachers thought he was just shy. I saved money from my part time job for college application fees, knowing he'd never support it. He found them anyway. You think you're better than me? He burned them in the kitchen sink while I watched. Later, his boss Asked about my plans. She's applying everywhere. We stay up late working on essays together. I nodded and smiled, knowing I'd missed every deadline. Two fathers. Only we knew which one was real. Then my dad announced, the CEO is coming to dinner on Saturday. After ten years grinding for senior VP, a 1 hundred thousand dollar promotion, it came down to this. The CEO was famous for his values based leadership. He'd fired executives for screaming at waitstaff. I passed over vps for bad parenting in public. Now he wanted to see Dad's home life personally. With a three hour dinner. One mistake, dad hissed, and I'll make you regret it forever. But dad had never maintained his perfect act at home for more than 20 minutes. Phone calls, easy, quick. Doorway chats, no problem. But three hours in his kingdom, where he trained us to fear him. That's never happened before. Watched Mom's hands shake, my brother shrink into his chair. For 17 years, home was where dad dropped his mask. Saturday, he'd have to keep it on for three whole hours. There was no way, right? We all prepared like our lives depended on it. Practiced conversations, rehearsed dinner etiquette. Cleaned until the house looked like a magazine spread. I helped mom cover the bags under her eyes. My brother practiced speaking in full sentences. Again. Dad was a wreck. Pretending to be calm. He'd bark orders, catch himself, force a smile. Remember, we're a happy family. He'd say through gritted teeth, the vein in his forehead pulsing. Saturday arrived and the doorbell rang. Showtime, Dad whispered, transforming into the man his co workers knew. A warm smile with a firm handshake. Welcome to our home. The first hour was perfect. Dad told charming stories. We laughed at the right moments. Mom served flawlessly. But I watched dad carefully. Saw his jaw clench when my brother took too long answering a question. I noticed his knuckles whitening when mom laughed too loudly at the CEO's joke. I watched that familiar vein start to pulse. By hour, two cracks appeared. His smile became strained, his laugh forced. He was gripping his wine glass so tight, I thought it might shatter. This was the longest he'd ever had to pretend in his own home. And it was killing him. I didn't have to do anything. I just had to wait. Then it happened. During dessert, mom served the sea

Why don't homeless people just try and rob a bank? Like hear me out. If they're successful, they're instantly rich. No more sleeping under bridges. They're straight up balling. But if they fail, what happens? Jail, which is basically free food, free bed, free shelter, free Wi-Fi if you're lucky. That's literally a win win situation, bro. Worst case scenario, you end up with three meals a day and a roommate named Big Mike. Best case scenario, you're the next Elon Musk, but without the lawsuit. Honestly, I don't get why no one's speed running this strategy. It sounds more efficient than half the self improvement TikToks I see.

We talk about people who self diagnose themselves like, no, Emily, you do not have 4 different mental disorders just because you saw a TikTok that said if you breathe sometimes and also blink, you might have ADHD. Congratulations. That's called being a human. Look, I get it. Mental health awareness is hella important. It's amazing that people are talking about it more openly now. But here's the problem. Scrolling through hashtags at 2:00am is not the same thing as a professional evaluation. Google is not your therapist. ID Labs, tests are not your psychiatrist. And that one influencer who talks about their symptoms in a story time, definitely not a doctor. When everyone just casually slaps a label on themselves, it waters down the real struggles people actually face. Like someone living with legit OCD is out here battling life every day. And then some dude is like, oh my God, I'm so OCD. I color code my closet. No, you're not OCD. You're just organized, my guy. And even with depression, just because you're feeling a little sad one week does not mean you have depression unless you're diagnosed. I don't wanna hear it. You're free to self pity in private. But self diagnosing is probably one of the most selfish and attention seeking things you can do. Faith out.

Every school has that annoying ass girl group who thinks they're the shit and every boy likes them. Like bro, they're always looking for attention. Like, Omg, everyone is staring at us. What the fuck? And then my fuck ass friends have the audacity to say, you like her, don't you? Like what? No, they're all fucking chopped and built like oversized vending machine friends every week like it's a fucking Netflix series. New season, new guy. Make fun of other people's looks. But then they take pictures and scribble out the spots on their face like, bro, you're just a fucking hypocrite. The worst part is when the girl everyone thinks I like starts playing along with it. So that just makes it even more fucking believable that I like her. I always explain to everyone that no, I don't fucking like her. She sounds like a dying vacuum cleaner choking on Legos that went up its ass. But no, still continue. At this point I might as well just confess to my real crush so people stop shipping me with that ugly hippo. Anyway, have a great fuck ass day.

Bro, what the flip is this? A man with alzheimer's forgets he had alzheimer's, remembers everything. Like how? Who are you? What are you? When did this happen? Bro literally beat the system. You're telling me this man forgot so hard that he forgot to forget? That's some next level anime plotline. This is literally math in real life. Negative plus negative equals positive. Bro used stones to destroy stones. Bro used some cursed reverse psychology and clutched up. This guy is him. This guy is overpowered. This guy teaches his teachers the air breathes. This guy. The earth walks. This guy. But wait, if he recovered his memory, wouldn't he remember he had alzheimer's? Like, wouldn't that just cancel out again? Bro is in an infinite memory glitch. But honestly, this is a W. He literally beat one of the worst illnesses ever. Spam w in the comments.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque, not here, on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare? Bro, rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught small pox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever, and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like, think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got A I. Rockets to Mars, and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First it was COVID tearing everything apart, then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

What's your perfect example of play stupid games, win stupid prizes? My high school made all the boys holding their pee because someone wrote hi on the wall in Sharpie. Monday morning, we all showed up to find a sign taped to the boys bathroom door, closed until further notice due to vandalism. The girls bathroom was still open, of course, but our school only had one bathroom for boys in the entire building because it was an old school built in the 60s when they apparently thought teenage boys never needed to pee. Principal Carpenter made an announcement during 1st period, due to the disrespectful graffiti found in the boys restroom, this facility will remain locked until someone comes forward with information about who did it. The entire male population of our high school groaned at the same time. The crazy part was what the graffiti actually said. My friend Peyton had seen it Friday before they locked everything up. Someone had written hi in tiny letters on the bathroom stall. Not a curse word, not a drawing, just hi, I in black Sharpie about the size of a quarter. By lunch, the situation was getting desperate. Guys were asking teachers for hall passes to go to the nurse's office just to use that bathroom. But the school nurse caught on quick and started turning people away unless they were actually sick. Some guys tried using the staff bathroom but got detention for that. A few desperate souls walked To the gas station across the street during lunch. But security started watching for that, too. We tried talking to Principal Carpenter. Reasonably group of five guys went to his office to explain that punishing 300 boys for one tiny word was insane. He sat behind his big desk with his arms crossed. Actions have consequences. When the vandal comes forward, everyone gets bathroom privileges back. By Wednesday, things were getting bad. Guys were dehydrated from not drinking water all day. The basketball team couldn't practice properly because half the players were holding it in. Parents started calling to complain. The carpenter wouldn't budge. He sent out an email saying this was a lesson in collective responsibility. That's when Dean Patterson had his brilliant idea. He was this quiet kid.

Secret signs A boy likes you but is just shy. The last one will shock you. His body language gives him away. He sneaks, glances at you, but quickly looks away when you notice. His feet or body are often pointed toward you. He plays with his hands, adjust clothes, taps foot when you're around. TikTok knows someone who has feelings for you, but it's too afraid to tell you it's the second person. When you click share and more, he gets nervous around you. His voice cracks or he stumbles over words. When talking to you, he finds small excuses to be near you. He shows up where you are more often than coincidence allows. He remembers the little things. Comment I hate when and let your keyboard finish the sentence. Even if he doesn't talk much, he notices details about you, like your favourite snack, something you said weeks ago. He pays attention in ways others might overlook. He interacts differently with you than with others. He may be loud and confident with friends, but quiet around you. He engages online more than in person. He texts, comments, or likes your posts, but is quieter face to face. He's more relaxed when there's no direct eye contact. Before the last fact. Please like the video and follow or you might never see me again. His friends know something. They tease him when you're around. They may drop hints or act differently toward you because they know how he Feels

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball when our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I've forgotten how to enjoy my Children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of Zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the plate.

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife Stephanie, waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said, and I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping. We date each other's spouses. Said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered, room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie, and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said. Let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something, but. And I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. That should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. She put on this red Dress I'd never seen before that she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul? Never. She started, then stopped. At dinner. She pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly. For months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand. Before what? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name, and she turned it face down immediately. When I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How is Cassie? Good. It was Paul. Then she started telling me everything they did. The hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you wanna know? No. Her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere, and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down. Out Of nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner. She had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked, and her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons. That's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom noticed it right away and her face changed. Is that men's Cologne? The whole table went quiet. We're sharing partners with Cassie and Paul, I said. Every week. Her dad dropped his fork and it made this loud sound. Sharing? Taking turns dating each other's spouses. Stephanie's idea. Her mom stood up from the table in my house, she said, and her voice was shaking. Stephanie tried to explain, but everyone had already smelled the Cologne and knew what was happening. That night Cassie called me. I know about Tuesday afternoons. I felt sick to my stomach about them. I followed Paul once four months ago to the hotel. She sounded drunk. I saw everything. By week five, everything fell apart. It was Cassie's birthday and I threw her a surprise party, made a video of all her artwork and gave the speech about how talented and kind she was. Paul Forgot it was her birthday completely. I watched Stephanie watch Cassie cry happy tears and hold on to me like she didn't want to let go. That night, Stephanie came home from Paul's and started telling me what they did in graphic detail again. Stop! I don't want to hear it. She got mad. But I'm telling you everything. I didn't ask. Then she demanded to know what Cassie and I did together.
NA
NA

Wife confessed during a family dinner that she always wished she married my best friend. So I packed my things and left, but now she's begging me to come back. Last Sunday at my in law's house for their 30th anniversary dinner, everything seemed perfect. My wife Emma was helping her mom arrange flowers while I watched the game with her dad. My buddy Josh was there, too. He's been like family since college, always invited to everything. The whole extended family was there, maybe 20 people total. Emma's cousins, her weird Uncle Dave who likes vintage spoons. Her grandmother, who still asks when we're having kids even though we've been trying for three years. After dinner, her Aunt Linda starts this thing where everyone shares their sliding door moments. Those what if scenarios that keep you up at night. Everyone's going around the table sharing cute stories. Her cousin Sarah talks about almost moving to Japan to teach English. Uncle Dave mentions nearly buying Bitcoin in 2,010. Her brother Tom jokes about almost joining the military instead of becoming an accountant. Normal, harmless stuff that gets people thinking. Then it's Emma's turn. She's had a few glasses of wine, and she gets this dreamy, distant look in her eyes, like she's somewhere else entirely. Honestly, she says, looking directly at Josh across the table, I sometimes think I should have dated Josh instead of Mark back in college. We just click so naturally, you know, the entire table goes Dead silent. Her dad literally chokes on his coffee and starts coughing violently. Her mom drops her fork with a loud clatter. Her grandmother's mouth falls open. I'm sitting right there like a complete idiot, watching my wife of eight years fantasize about my best friend in front of our entire family. Josh's face goes bright red. He starts stammering something about how that's not appropriate. But Emma just keeps going like she's in some kind of trance. I mean, we have so much more in common than Mark and I. I do. Josh actually listens when I talk about my art projects. He gets my sense of humor. He remembers little things I say. Sometimes I wonder if I settled too quickly. That last part hit like a freight train. Settled? After eight years of marriage, two miscarriages, buying our first house together, and me working overtime to pay for her art supplies, I settled. I excused myself to the bathroom. But really, I just sat in my car for 20 minutes trying to process what had just happened. My hands were shaking. I called my brother Mike, but couldn't even form words to explain. When I came back inside, everyone was pretending nothing happened, making awkward small talk.

How did you scam the scammer? Last Tuesday, I was making lunch for my kids when my phone rang. Unknown number, but I picked up anyway. Big mistake, right? This guy with a thick accent starts telling me he's from the IRS and I owe $4,200 in back taxes. As if I don't pay immediately with gift cards, the police will arrest me within an hour. Now, here's the thing. I literally just got my tax refund two weeks ago. My accountant, Beth, handled everything perfectly and I even got money back. So I knew this dude was full of it. But instead of hanging up, something clicked in my brain. My neighbour, Missus Kim, had fallen for this exact scam last month and lost $800. Time for payback. I started crying into the phone, oh, no, I can't go to jail. My kids need me. The scammer ate it up. He told me to go to target and buy iTunes gift cards worth $2,000 as a first payment. I said I needed an hour to get the money together. First, I called my cousin, Jake, who's a cop, told him what was happening and he said to keep the guy on the line as long as possible. Then I started my revenge tour. I called the scammer back an hour later sobbing. I'm at target, but I'm so confused. Which gift cards do I buy? He walked me through it step by step. I pretended to be this helpless Single mom who didn't understand technology. Sorry, can you repeat that? My hands are shaking so bad. For the next 20 minutes, I wandered around target asking him questions. Do I need the physical cards or the digital ones? The cashier is asking for ID is that normal? Sorry, my 4 year old is having a meltdown in the cart. Finally, I told him I had the cards. He was so excited, probably thinking about his commission. I read him the first number. Okay, it starts with 5. Wait, is that a 5?

My girlfriend said she wanted to be friends with benefits, so I treated her exactly like one. I've been planning Miranda's dream Valentine's Day for weeks. When she destroyed me over brunch, I just pulled out my phone to confirm the reservation at the restaurant she'd been dying to try, when she interrupted me. God, you're so clingy and needy. We need to talk, she said, pushing away the flowers I'd brought. I can't do this anymore. It's suffocating. You're always trying to be romantic, always wanting to do couple stuff. My heart broke. About to be a year, Miranda. Exactly why we need to set boundaries now. From now on, we're best friends who happen to sleep together. Treat me exactly like you treat Nate or will. No flowers or special treatment. Just buddies. I'm just someone you have sex with. She said it like I was pathetic for wanting more. The couple next to us looked horrified. If that's what you want, I said quietly. She rolled her eyes. Finally. Maybe now you'll stop being so desperate and embarrassing. Valentine's Day arrived. Miranda texted asking about if we had plans. I responded that I was going to Nate's to watch the game. She could come if she wanted. Dead silence for an hour. Didn't we have a reservation? She finally asked. Reminded her that I don't make romantic reservations for my buddies. That night, she showed up at Nate's in a red dress and heels. I handed her a beer. Without looking up from the TV and went back to the game. When she tried to sit next to me on the couch, I pointed to the recliner across the room. Dude, you're blocking the TV! Nate looked confused. Miranda's face went red. She spent the night watching us play video games and talk about sports. Her birthday came three weeks later. I got her what I got all my bros. A six pack of beer and buffalo wings from the sketchy place near campus. Stared at the grease stained container like it was radioactive. Where's my actual gift? She asked, voice shaking. That is your gift. Same thing I got will last month. Pretty good wings, too. But I'm your girlfriend. No, you're my friend who I occasionally sleep with. Your exact words. Didn't speak to me for two days. The real entertainment started at her company's spring gala. She begged me to come, bought me a suit, and said it was important for her promotion. When her boss approached asking how long we've been together, I corrected him immediately, oh, we're not together. Her boss looked bewildered, but she said you were her boyfriend of 10 months. Nah, she doesn't do the relationship thing. We're buddies who hook up occasionally. She was actually just telling me how suffocating real relationships are. Miranda grabbed my arm so hard it left marks. Her coworkers started whispering at her cousin's wedding in may. The disasters multiplied when they called for couples Photo. I stayed seated, playing on my phone. We're not a couple, just friends with benefits, I explained to the photographer, who asked three times if I was sure. During the slow songs, I was at the bar with other guys talking about basketball, while she stood alone on the dance floor. Her family kept asking if we'd broken up. I explained cheerfully that Miranda didn't want to be together, just friends with benefits. Her grandmother nearly fainted. Her mom pulled her aside for a long conversation about self respect and not letting men use you. By month three

You'll never be able to ride all the rides at a theme park and you'll never be able to fit in any rides at a theme park. At least I can reach the top shelf. At least I don't eat everything that's on the shelf. Where do you work again? Gnome de Poe, the Circus, Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory. Of course you're thinking about chocolate. Do you take fall damage when you step off a curb? Does the curb take damage when you step on it? Whatever. I'm done talking to you. Chicken Little. Okay, Big Chungus, Oompa Loompa. Jabba the hut, Langton Yate without the y. Edna from The Incredibles, Dumbledore, dash Smurf, Christiano McDonald, Kaysenat, Gorlok the destroyer, built like the kid from Hotel Transylvania. Built like a one by 1 Lego stud. Built like the chef from Ratatouille. That's it. I'm locking in. What you're a necklace beanbag. A human sized jelly roll built like a bowling ball that forgot how to stroll. You wobble when you walk. Gravity's your biggest foe. That double chin so thick it deserves its own zip code. I hate being a picky eater so fucking much. I get so embarrassed when people ask me about food or what foods I like because I have such a small pool of foods that I like. And most of it stems from my sensory issues because for whatever god forsaken reason, I'm so scared of trying new foods because it might be gross. And it doesn't help that my doctor likes to be passive aggressive about my diet too. I told her I eat a lot of pasta because it's my safe food. And this lady told me to pick a new safe food like fruit. Hello. The whole point of it being a safe food is that I know it will always be the same. It's just overall so embarrassing for me. And then I see randoms on the internet talking about some picky eaters. Piss me off. The fuck did I do? Why are you mad that I'm ordering chicken fingers and fries? I just wish I could actually try stuff like a normal person. It's hard out here.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around, and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her co worker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. She showed me his Instagram. Tall, brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem? He didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby, and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed after that first dinner. My mom kept inviting him back. Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand, asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about Basketball scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night, after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept stealing glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us. Said she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly. Made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me. We can't keep this up forever, you know? That message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing. And I wasn't. Not even close. You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like no big fall out, no drama, just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened, like what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part, I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. I can reach out, I can say something, but deep down I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it, pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them. I really wanted to stay. What toxic family tradition did you break that cost you everything? In my family, December 3rd is off limits. No one is born on it, no one dies on it. No celebrations, no gatherings, no flights, no weddings, no trips. It's circled in thick red ink on every calendar in every relative's house. Growing up, it was just the day. If you asked why, you got a cold look and a quick we don't talk about December 3rd. I assumed it was just a creepy superstition. My cousins and I used to joke that it was the day someone sold their soul or bury gold or something equally ridiculous. But the adults, they didn't laugh. Ever. When I turned 28, I was engaged to the love of my life, Harper. She was funny, brilliant, and absolutely not into weird family rules. I didn't bring up the whole December 3rd thing until we started planning our wedding. Turns out the only date available at our dream venue was. Yep, December 3rd. I hesitated, not because I believed in any of it, but because I could already hear my mom's voice in my head. Over my dead body. Harper looked at me and said, do you actually believe anything will happen? No, I admitted, but my family will freak. So we did what rational adults do. We eloped. Quiet ceremony. Close friends, no one announcements. We figured we'd have a bigger party later and just say it was on a different date. We even posted the Photos on December 4th to avoid triggering anyone. Holy shit, what is wrong with September? It's only been 11 days and the world is completely off its fucking Rocker. Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family, David was found with a body in his car, a Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway, and now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. The scene was so bloody and gruesome it's insane. A Ukrainian girl gets stabbed on a train in Charlotte. She escaped a literal war, came here to be safe, and still got killed because this planet has zero peace. Then D4D has a whole body in his car. Like, not a metaphorical one, an actual human body in a bag in his trunk. And this dude just casually performed like he didn't have a horror movie in his backseat. What the hell? And even outside all of that, Elon Musk is no longer the richest person in the world, losing his top spot to a rival tech CEO, showing how unstable everything feels right now, even at the highest levels. It's like every time I open my phone, reality speed runs another tragedy. Like, bro, it's been 11 days. September just started. I thought my only problem this month would be math class, but no, apparently it's Full blown world collapse. Society isn't just cooked, it's burnt to ash.

Guys, y'all do not know how annoying it is to be colorblind. Like, you're just chilling with your friends, and then you tell them, or they find out that you're colorblind, they will begin to ask the dumbest question, like, what color is my shirt? Or what color is the grass? Like, your shirt is purple. And then they say, no, it's blue. Like, bro, it isn't my fault that I didn't know that because I see purple. And then as soon as they know it, they'll tell their friends, like, bro, did you know he's colorblind? And then in one second, everyone comes and asks me questions. And then there is that one time I was with a friend, we got out of the store, and I see a purple bicycle with green wheels. So I say, bro, what is that combination, bro? Like, purple and green? And then he says, bro, that's blue. And I say, no. And then he calls an old man and says, sir, that bicycle is blue, right? And that gentleman says, yes, and then he says, well, that guy says it's purple. Or one time I saw someone drawing with gray, and I asked him, dude, why are you coloring with gray? And he says, uh, bro, it's dark green.

Okay, so today was my first day at an American high school, and oh, my god, I have a lot to say, so buckle up. First of all, to the motherfucker that decided school should start at 7:45 in the morning, fuck you. Say your prayers and count your days, because I am personally going to file a lawsuit against you. Like, I already adjusted to the time zones. I legit thought I was safe. Nope. I'm suddenly expected to brush my teeth before the sun even knows what's going on. Okay, moving on. Let's talk about the cult you guys have labeled school fashion. Why was everyone wearing red and black pajama pants? Was this planned? It was like walking into a Christmas themed asylum. But I'm not even gonna hate, because I am absolutely dragging my host mom to target to get some so I can blend in with the cult members. Anyway, first thing they gave me was my schedule, and then first thing I did was hide in the bathroom, because what the fuck do you mean I'm supposed to actually talk to people? Absolutely not. Homeroom teacher was chill, though. Shout out to Mr. Lincoln for not forcing me to stand up and introduce myself. Fucking legend. Thankfully, my host sister was in most of my classes, so I just stayed with her and her friends. Now, my classes were really easy, like I suspected. So to the people who told me school was gonna Be hard. Yikes. That is, until I had biology fifth period, bro. I did not realize how many science words exist that I don't know in English. They gave me a language helper, like a translator. I felt like a fucking idiot. They also messed up my classes again and put me in French class. What am I supposed to do in there? They said it's gonna take a few weeks before I get my classes switched. But you know what? I actually kind of get it now. I get why you guys hate French, but I don't even think it's the language's fault. I think your teachers just hate their jobs. About lunch. Oh, my god. Lunch was disgusting. Starting to feel like the chicken was not chicken. How are you people not dying from this? Do you just build immunity over the years? Like a vaccine, but edible? Also, why is it so short? 45 minutes. That is not enough. I'm gonna stop here before this turns into a fucking documentary. Tomorrow I'll give you the tea on the people instead of the school itself. Anyways, I'm done yapping, so bye.
NA

I kicked my family off my Amazon plan. So my whole family had been using my Amazon Prime account for like three years. My mom, my sister Ashley, my Uncle Rick. Even my grandma somehow figured out how to order stuff. I was paying for it because I actually use Amazon all the time for work stuff and groceries, but they were just leeching off it. The breaking point happened two weeks ago. I check my account and see 17 packages coming to different addresses. 17! My sister ordered a whole workout set she'll never use. My mom got some fancy face cream that cost 60 bucks, and my Uncle Rick ordered a drone he definitely doesn't need. But the worst part was my cousin Blake ordered a gaming chair that cost $400. I called Blake and asked him what the hell he was thinking. He just laughed and said it's not his problem. I gave everyone access. He said if I didn't want people using it, I shouldn't have shared the password. This kid just graduated high school and acts like he runs the world. So I called my mom and told her everyone needed to chip in for prime or get their own accounts. She got all dramatic and said family should help each other out. She reminded me how she used to buy me clothes when I was younger. I told her that was literally her job as a parent and not the same thing at all. Then Ashley calls me crying, saying she can't afford her own prime account because she's saving for a wedding. I reminded her that her wedding is in two years, and she just spent $300 on workout clothes she turned last month. She said I was being petty and that it's only like $10 a month split between everyone. I did the math. If everyone chipped in 10 bucks, that would actually cover prime and give me extra money. But when I suggested this in our family group chat, suddenly everyone had excuses. My mom said she's on a fixed income. Ashley said she's saving for the wedding. Rick said he barely uses it anyway, which is a lie because he ordered protein powder just yesterday. The final straw was when my grandma called me, confused about why her soap order got canceled. Turns out my account got flagged for suspicious activity. Because there were so many different addresses, Amazon temporarily locked my account and I couldn't order my medication.

Man, the one fucking day my dad don't go to work, everything goes straight to hell. I wake up feeling good as shit, thinking I got the house to myself. I go downstairs, ready to make some cereal, and boom, this man already sitting at the table with a mug, staring at me like I just committed a fucking crime. Oh, so you just wake up at noon now? Bro, it's 10:30. Chill. Then he hits me with the classic, since I'm home today, we're gonna get some stuff done around here that we ain't fooling nobody. He mean me. Next thing I know, I'm cleaning the dusty ass garage, holding a flashlight while he trying to fix some shit that's been broken since Obama was in office. And of course, I'm getting yelled at for not doing it right, even though he ain't tell me Jack. I try to sneak back into my room, throw my headphones on, maybe catch a break. This man kicks the door open like the damn SWAT team. Why the fuck you on your phone? Go clean the yard. The yard? Bro, it's 95 degrees. The sun beating my ass like it's personal. Every time I sit down for 2 seconds, he pops up with, back in my day, we didn't have time to sit. Back in your day, y'all didn't have Wi-Fi or air conditioning either? This ain't the damn 80s. Let me chill. Finally, by the time he done dragging me through The surprise boot camp. He sits on the couch like a proud general and hits me with, wasn't that a productive day? No, it was a fucking nightmare. I didn't sign up for this unpaid labor. Moral of the story, if your dad's off work, you better fake sleep, hide in the basement, or disappear altogether. Cause once he hits you with that get stuff done bullshit, your peace is done.
