Did you convince your parents to remove your bedtime rule? My brother saved our entire house because he refused to sleep. We had the strictest bedtime rule of any family I knew. Nine PM meant lights out, no exceptions, no matter what. Had projects or homework finish before 9, exams study before 9, gaming with friends? Definitely before 9. It didn't bother me much because I was 7, but it affected my brother a lot. He told me how he felt left out sometimes because his friends constantly texted about late night shows and online game he'd never see. My brother was the only eighth grader who had to be in bed before fourth graders. Growing bodies need 10 hours of sleep. Mom and dad would say nothing good happens after 9 anyway. But my brother tried everything to change their minds. He offered to get straight A's in exchange change for a 10:30 bedtime. He showed them studies about how teens only need five hours of sleep to function well compared to kids and adults, but they still refused. When you're 18, you can destroy your sleep schedule all you want. My brother looked heartbroken. 18 was so far off and by then he'd be too old to enjoy it. That's when my brother became an expert at fake sleeping. He Learned to lie completely still with his eyes shut, breathing so evenly that mom's flashlight checks never caught him. He could hear footsteps on the stairs from two Rooms away and transform from wide awake to dead asleep in two seconds. After the ten PM inspection, he'd wait exactly 20 minutes for our parents to pour their wine and start their TV shows. He made me promise never to tell. In exchange, he'd let me stay up too sometimes with him. It was like our own secret midnight meetings and our parents never really caught on. They ended up bragging to everyone about how well we listen to their rules. But then one day my brother got cornered into a wall and was left.

My fiance told me to leave if I didn't like her lifestyle. So I left. I was looking at credit card statements last month when my fiance Bianca was packing for another girl's trip, her fourth this year. We need to talk about these trips. I said. This Miami one will cost at least $3,000. That's 12,000 this year alone. She rolled her eyes. I work hard. I deserve fun. The thing was I covered all our expenses, rent, utilities, groceries, her car payment. Her entire salary was play money. You spend your whole income on trips while I cover everything else. I pointed out my trips are non negotiable. She said, you don't like it, then leave. She said it so casually like our five year relationship meant nothing. Fine. I said I'll leave. She laughed over a girl's trip? Seriously? Over you telling me to leave rather than discuss our finances like adults. Yeah. She grabbed her suitcase from Miami without even saying goodbye. I called my brother. Still have that empty room, started packing immediately. While packing, found receipts from her Vegas trip, bottle service, VIP sections and a 500 dollar receipt from a men's clothing store. Who buys men's clothes on a girl's trip. Next morning, removed her as authorized user on my credit cards. By Saturday, 47 missed calls from her friends in Miami. Her card got declined. Sunday she texted, my cards are maxed. I'm stranded. Use your own cards. I replied, that's financial Abuse. This is me leaving like you suggested. Monday I went to our apartment early, packed all my stuff, took everything I bought, TV, gaming console, coffee maker, even the good shower head. Left her designer clothes and makeup. Left a note as suggested, I've left rents paid through months end. After that, it's your responsibility. Also left, print out showing 47,000 thousand dollars spent on girls trips over three years, almost a house down payment. She exploded by a text, you took the TV. Are you 12? This is theft. Then pivoted to, please let's talk. I'm sorry. Showed up at my office, had security escort her out. Posted on Instagram about toxic men who can't handle independent women. Comments weren't what she expected. Independent? Don't you live in his apartment? Maybe he got tired of funding your lifestyle. She deleted it within an hour. Week later, she emailed, I can't afford the apartment. My cards are maxed. Parents think I'm irresponsible. Please come home. I'll cancel the next.

Did your child ever hear you say a word that they now repeat? Poodle. My wife and I use the word poodle as a sort of safe word when we're discussing issues that might force one of us to lie just to make the other happy. We stole it from a Chuck Palahniuk novel. It's a standalone question. Poodle or a confident statement? Poodle. Basically, it means I'm being completely truthful. For example, my wife might want me to accompany her to a dance costume expo in Atlanta on a Saturday morning. She really wants company because her dance teacher friend had to cancel at the last minute, so she asks me. I reluctantly agree. She asks, are you sure you're okay going to this dance costume expo? I answer yes. She replies with poodle. Ugh. If I reply with poodle, it means I'm being completely truthful about wanting to go, but I'm not really, so it forces me to admit that I'd really just rather lie around in my jammies playing video games. When one person invokes poodle, you're not allowed to lie in response. It's a staunch rule that means it also has to be used sparingly. We have never explained this rule or our reasoning for the word poodle to our three year old daughter. And yet, one evening as we're cuddling on the couch, I squeeze my daughter and say, I love you. She looks lovingly up at me and asks, poodle? I smile. Poodle.

My daughter told me she wished I was more like her friend's cool mom, so I became exactly that. Emma came home from school last Tuesday looking all pouty, dropping her backpack with that dramatic thud only 13 year olds can master. What's wrong? I asked, stirring Mac and cheese on the stove like I did every Tuesday. Madison's mom is so cool, she muttered, slumping into a kitchen chair. She lets Madison wear whatever she wants, doesn't make her do chores, and they go shop together like they're best friends. She even bought Madison a crop top yesterday. Emma crossed her arms. I wish you were more like her instead of being so strict about everything. That hit me weird. I've been raising Emma alone since her dad left when she was seven, working my butt off as a bank teller to keep us afloat. I thought I was doing okay, make making sure she ate vegetables, had a bedtime, did her homework. But maybe I was being too uptight. You know what? I said, turning off the stove. You're right. Let's go shopping right now. Emma's face lit up like Christmas morning. Really? Can we go to the mall where Madison shops? Two hours later, we were walking through target with a cart full of stuff I never would have bought before. Crop tops, makeup, a phone case with fake diamonds, energy drinks, even some of those expensive face masks she'd been begging for. When Emma asked if She could get her ears pierced at the kiosk. I said yes before my brain could catch up. That weekend, I let her have friends over without hovering. I ordered pizza instead of making them eat carrot sticks, and they wanted to watch some rated R movie on Netflix. I figured, why not? When Emma asked if she could walk to the convenience store with Madison at 9 p m, I handed her 20 bucks. The next week, Emma started staying out later. Madison's mom lets her stay out until 11 on school nights. She'd text me at 10:30. I text back, okay, even though my stomach felt twisted up then.

The thing about trios is that no matter how hard you try, you're always going to end up feeling like the outsider. It's like being right there, sitting with them, but still invisible. You laugh when they laugh, but deep down you know you're laughing at something you weren't even part of. You watch them get closer and closer, and you start questioning yourself, like, what's wrong with me? Why am I never enough to be chosen? It's the kind of hurt that doesn't scream. It just sits heavy in your chest until you feel like breaking. And the worst part is, you can pour your heart out, you can beg them to understand, but nothing changes. They keep being a duo, and you keep being the leftover. That's when it hits you. You deserve better than fighting for scraps of attention. You deserve friends who make you feel like you belong, who don't make you wonder if you're the problem. It's so hard to let go. But sometimes you have to. Because staying in that kind of pain is worse than being alone.

Why is math class easy but the exam feels like squid game? Like, math teachers will tell you that the exam is going to be easy, next thing you know, question 1 looks like it was written by NASA. Bro, I came here for algebra, not to calculate rocket fuel. And in class they're giving us baby problems. Like if Johnny has two apples and gives away one, how much apples will he have? Bro, on the exam it's if Johnny invests his apples at a 7% return while traveling at the speed of light, how many apples does he have left in a black hole? What? Where was that in the notes? And the best part is when they say if anyone has doubts, ask me. So one kid actually raises his hand like um, I don't get No. 3 and instead of helping, the teacher goes full roast mode. You don't know this? We literally just did this yesterday. Bro, he asked for help, not a public execution. And they'll hit you with damn is just like the homework. Yeah right. The homework was 2 + 2. The exam is proof why 2 + 2 = 4 using 18 pages of logic. When it's finally over, they smile and go see? It wasn't that hard. Bro, that wasn't an exam. That was a boss fight. And I walked in with no armor, no weapons, and half a health bar.
NA

Bro, can someone explain to me why the internet is obsessed with the dumbest meme ever? 6, 7, that's it. Two random numbers. And suddenly everyone's acting like it's peak comedy. Like this weekend, the calendar hits 6 for Saturday, 7 for Sunday, and people are losing their minds. What? Wow. Crazy. Never seen numbers before. Someone asks me how old I am? I say 67. And apparently that's the funniest joke of the year. No, it's not clever. It's not deep. It's just two numbers slapped together like a bad group project. And yet somehow my whole feed is flooded with it. TikTok comments, just a wall of people spamming 67 like they unlocked a cheat code. Bro, you don't look cool. You look cooked. Teachers ask what page we're on and kids scream 6, 7, like it's a cult meme. How is this funny? It's literally the definition of cringe. And the worst part, the more I complain, the more people spam it. Like I'll rant for two minutes straight and the comments are still just 67, 67, 67. At this point, it feels less like a meme and more like brain rot. It's everywhere. And now I can't even escape it. I wake up, check my phone, and first thing I see another 67 memes. My brain is broken. So, fine, if you're part of this chaos, prove it. Type 67 in the comments. Right now. I wanna see the entire comment section cooked beyond repair.

You know what? I really love people who speak up for me. Like even when I don't have the words or I feel too quiet to defend myself, they just step in. Not in the loud, over the top way, but in that protective, I got you kind of way, makes you feel seen, safe and honestly so cared for. And that feeling, I don't think I'll ever stop loving it. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.
NA

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favourite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.
NA

So apparently, even escaping a war zone doesn't guarantee safety anymore. A 23 year old Ukrainian woman moved to the United States for a better life, only to lose it in the most tragic way on a train in Charlotte. Her name was Irina. She was just heading home after work, wearing her pizza shop T-shirt, AirPods in, minding her own business like everybody else on that train. But sitting right behind her was a man in a red hoodie, restless, agitated. And within minutes, he pulled out a knife and attacked her, completely unprovoked. She never even saw it coming. The man, the Carlos Brown, wasn't some random first time offender. He had a long history of violent crime and mental illness. He'd already served prison time, and he wasn't even supposed to be on that train because he didn't have a ticket. Yet somehow, he was there. And because of that, a young woman who just wanted safety ended up losing her life. Other passengers who witnessed it said they're traumatized. And honestly, who wouldn't be? You're just commuting home, and suddenly something unthinkable happens right in front of you. This story is more than a headline. It's a reminder of how fragile life really is. Rant signing off.

I don't know how to explain it, but I really love people who make sure I don't feel left out. Like, it's the little things, when they slide me into the conversation or when they make sure I'm included in the plans. It just means so much. It makes you feel like you actually matter to them. And that feeling, that's something I'll never take for granted. Well, anyways, thanks. Out. Mwah.

You know what? I love people who don't make me feel like an option. Like it feels so different when someone actually chooses you, you know, not just when they're bored or when it's easy, but because they really want you there. It shows in the little things, when they check in, when they make time, when they make you feel like you actually matter. And that feeling, that's the kind of thing that sticks with you. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.

Do you ever notice how comforting it is when someone just matches your energy? Like if you're laughing at something stupid, they're right there laughing with you. If you're tired or quiet, they don't make it weird. They just vibe with you. It's such a safe feeling knowing you don't have to perform or explain yourself. They just get it. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.

My teacher just accused me of using AI. I was just chilling in class when he suddenly put someone's essay on the projector and says, whose is this? I start reading through it and I'm like, oh my god, that's mine. He's about to give me an award or something. So I raise my hand all confident and go, yeah, that's mine. And he looks at me and goes, are you sure? Like, bro, yes, I'm sure. I literally finished writing it at 3:00am last night. So I say, yeah, I'm completely sure. And he goes, okay, see me after class. Now this is at the start of class. So the next 40 minutes everyone is just staring at me while I'm stressing out. Finally class ends and I walk up to him like, hey, that's my essay. I'm actually pretty proud of it. He pulls it up on his computer, points to an em dash and says, what's this right here? I tell him that's an em dash. And then he snaps, cuts me off mid sentence and says, don't play smart with me. You didn't write this. You used AI. And if you think I'm letting that slide, you're dead wrong. You'll explain yourself to the principal tomorrow because as of right now, you failed this class. I tried explaining everything to him, even showing proof I wrote it, but he just wasn't listening, bro. I walked out of there with tears in my eyes and now I've Got a meeting with the principal tomorrow morning, guys. What should I do?
NA

Men who proposed and she said no. What happened afterwards with your life? I've been dating Sophia for four years when I finally decided to ask the big question. Her parents treated me like their own son, especially after they found out I grew up in foster care. Her little brother would literally follow me around their house, begging me to teach him how to fix engines. Someone who never had a real family, being part of theirs felt like everything I've been missing my whole life. I've been saving every extra dollar from my job at Murphy's Auto Shop for months. The ring wasn't fancy, just a simple band with a small diamond, but it was real and it was all I could afford. I planned everything perfectly. Sophia's dad was turning 60 and they were throwing this big backyard BBQ. All her family would be there, plus her closest friends. She always said family was the most important thing to her. So I figured proposing surrounded by everyone who loved us both would be perfect. The party was going great. Sophia's mom made her famous brisket. Her dad was telling embarrassing stories about Sophia as a kid. And everyone was laughing and having a good time. After they brought out the birthday cake and saying happy birthday, I figured it was the perfect moment. My hands were shaking as I tapped my beer bottle with a fork to get everyone's attention. The whole backyard went dead silent. Sophia Looked confused at first, then her eyes went wide. When I got down on one knee and pulled out the ring box, her mom gasped and started tearing up. Her dad had this huge smile on his face. Her friends were already pulling out their phones to record the moment. I opened the box and said all the things I've been practicing in my head for weeks, how much I loved her, how she changed my life, how I wanted to spend forever making her happy. The words just poured out of me. But Sophia just stood there frozen, not good, frozen like she was overwhelmed with happiness. Bad frozen like she'd seen a ghost. Liam, she finally said, and I could hear the panic in her voice, I love you so much, but I'm not ready for this. I'm so sorry. The silence that followed was the worst sound I'd ever heard, 30 people just staring at us, not knowing what to do or where to look. I stayed on one knee for probably five seconds too long, trying to process what had just happened. Then I slowly stood up, shoved the ring box back in my pocket and nodded. Okay, I said, because what else could I say? Sophia reached for my arm, but I stepped back. I couldn't deal with her trying to comfort me in front of everyone. I mumbled something about needing to go and walked straight to my truck. The drive home was the Longest 20 minutes of my life. I stayed up all night staring at the ceiling, replaying every conversation we'd ever had about the future. We talked about getting married, about kids, about buying a house together. How had I read everything so wrong? Next day I was under the hood of a broken down Chevy trying to lose myself in work when I heard footsteps approaching. I looked up expecting to see my boss, but it was so.
NA
NA

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy, Robert, looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess. Looking for a rich boyfriend, smart girl, lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interesting perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me and continued his lecture. A girl like you probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was familiar, With the artist's work, Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from TikTok. Robert decided to test me, rapid firing questions. Who's basket? What's Kiara Scuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See, this is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men. But Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie, real universities. He returned to my painting now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. What Riley has achieved here would cost probably 100,000 in education to even attempt. The materials alone cost more than you'd make in a month at whatever retail job you have. He looked at my outfit with disgust. Target clearance rack, right? Someone who shops there couldn't possibly grasp the investment in this piece. Probably spent more on one brush than your entire outfit. When I suggested the artist might be self taught, Robert sneered at me. Is that how you Learned about art? Painting parties? Robert grabbed my wrist to pull me to another angle. His grip too tight. You're too stupid to even stand in the right spot. Riley intended for this to be viewed from exactly here. Your ignorance is actually disrespectful to his work. He kept his hand on my wrist while explaining, though honestly, explaining this to you is like teaching calculus to a toddler. You lack the basic foundation to understand any of it. He noticed me trying to pull away and.

Did your family realize you weren't a little kid anymore? I'm 23 and my family still cuts my food for me at restaurants. Not kidding. My mom will literally reach over and slice my chicken into bite size pieces while I'm eating it. Growing up as the youngest of seven kids by a huge gap didn't help. My siblings are all 10, 15 years older than me. So they've always treated me like their living doll at family dinners. They still ask if I need help tying my shoes or if I remembered to brush my teeth. My sister Amanda still tries to help me order at restaurants, telling in servers she'll have the chicken nuggets without asking what I want. Last month at my cousin Abigail's wedding was the absolute worst. The whole extended family was there, aunts, uncles, grand, grandparents, great aunts, family, friends. The worst, during cocktail hour, my Aunt Janet loudly announced that I couldn't have champagne because babies don't drink alcohol. She handed me a juice box instead. A juice box at a wedding? I'm 23 years old with a medical degree. Then came dinner seating. My Uncle Mark grabbed my arm and said, come on, sweetie, you're sitting at the kids table. I tried to protest, explaining I was an adult, but he was already walking me over to a table full of actual children. Eight year olds coloring on placemats. Ten year olds playing with action figures and me with my college degree. And my job that none of them bothered asking about. The kids kept asking me questions like what grade are you in and do you like our coloring books? I spent the entire dinner helping a six year old nephew cut his chicken while my family laughed from the adult tables, pointing and taking photos like it was cute. My cousin Kelly walked over during appetizers. Ah, look at you helping the little ones, she cooed. Maybe someday you'll be ready for grown up conversations. She patted my head like I was a golden retriever. The breaking point came during cake cutting. When the bride and groom finished their ceremonial first slice, they started serving guests. My Uncle Mark walked over with a plate and a plastic fork. A plastic fork. Let me help you with this, honey, he said, and started cutting my slice into tiny little pieces like I was a toddler who might choke. Uncle Mark, I can careful with the fork, sweetie. He interrupted, taking it from my hands. We don't want any accidents. Remember what happened at Christmas when you tried to use the good silverware? I haven't dropped anything at Christmas. He was just making stuff up. The entire reception was staring at this point. Other guests were whispering and pointing. Some were filming with their phones. I felt my face burning with embarrassment. That's when the bridesmaid of honor walked over. She was this elegant woman in her 40s looking confused. Excuse me. Are you Doctor Nguyen? She asked, staring directly at me. Everyone at nearby tables turned to look. My Aunt Janet burst out laughing like this was the funniest thing she'd ever heard. Oh, honey, that's just our baby cousin, she said condescendingly. She's still figuring out college classes and living in the dorms, playing dress up as a doctor. Aren't you, sweetie? The woman's face went from confused to absolutely shocked. Have you ever been asked to explain your ankle monitor at Disney World? The Disney princess stopped mid autograph, stared at my ankle, then at my six year old daughter, Emma, then back at my ankle. Sir, is that. She started clearly breaking character, which apparently requires something serious at the happiest place on earth. It's not what you think, I said quickly, but Cinderella was already flagging security. Within minutes, I was surrounded by three guards and mouse ear hats trying to look threatening, while tourists took photos of what they assumed was part of the show. Here's the thing. I'm not a criminal. The ankle monitor was court ordered, but not for the reason everyone assumes. My ex wife, Patricia, claimed I was a flight risk during our custody battle. Said I might take Emma to Brazil because I'd renewed my passport. I renewed it for a work conference in Toronto. Judge still ordered the monitor as a precaution until custody was finalized. I've been wearing it for three months, setting off every metal detector in Orange County. Emma didn't understand why Cinderella looked scared. Daddy, why is the princess sad? I knelt down, ankle monitor clicking against the pavement. She's just confused about daddy's special bracelet. Security moved closer. One spoke into his radio. We have a code yellow in fantasy land. I didn't know what that meant, but it sounded bad. Tourists and pulling their kids away from us. One mom loudly whispered, that's why we Check the registry, Karen. The head of security, a surprisingly intimidating man named Raul, escorted us to Disney Jail. Yes, that's a real thing. It's a small office behind Main Street that smells like churros and broken dreams. Emma thought it was a VIP experience. Are we getting special Mickey ears? She asked. Raul pulled up my information on his computer. His expression shifted from suspicious to confused to sympathetic. Like custody battle? He asked quietly. I nodded. He sighed. My brother went through the same thing. Judge made him wear one for six months because his ex said he'd flee to Cuba. He's never even been to Cuba. Raul made some calls. Twenty minutes later, we had a Disney escort. Not because I was dangerous, but because Raul felt bad. No kids should have their Disney trip ruined by adult problems, he said. Our escort, Jerome, was a former NBA player who'd retired to work at Disney because he loved making kids happy. Emma rode on his shoulders the entire day. We, every line, got front row seats to every show. Jerome told everyone I was a special guest, which technically wasn't a lie. The ankle monitor kept setting off the sensors on rides. Space Mountain stopped three times because of me. They had to manually override the system. By the third ride, the operators knew me by name. Ankle monitor dad is back, they'd radio ahead. It became a running joke. One operator said, you know, we've had Weapons, drugs, even a snake once. But you're our first ankle monitor. I chose to take that as an achievement. Plot twist came at dinner. We were at the character meal when goofy sat down at our table. He pointed at my ankle, then did an elaborate MIME of being arrested, going to court, then being innocent. Emma laughed hysterically. Goofy's silly daddy. But then goofy pulled out his phone.

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the centre of attention for five minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day. The one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up? He said, and I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself, and I just can't deal with that stress. On my wedding day, the line went quiet for, like, 10 seconds, and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now? You're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. He's basically family. I tried To explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice, hoping he'd change his mind. He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, she says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted, like, 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewellery. The caption on the last one says, can't wait to celebrate love today. With a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. He's coming anyway. Madison nods. Jake's outside right now, arguing with your dad about it. He says he changed his mind and decided to bring her. I'm standing there in my wedding dress, half my makeup done, and I have to deal with.

How do I tell my crush I fell in love with her kids? I found my work crush share crying in the break room, looking completely stressed. My dad's in the hospital and I need to fly out tonight, but I can't find anyone to watch my kids. My ex won't answer, the babysitter I hired bailed, and I just. I can't afford to miss this flight, but I can't afford anything else either. She leaned against my shoulder, crying even harder. I volunteered without thinking. I'll watch them, I said, heart racing from how close she was to me. Are you serious? It's three kids. Three for at least two weeks. I waved my hand around like a lovesick fool. How hard can it be? The kids showed up at my apartment that night with tons of suitcases. The oldest, around 14, looked at her mom and said, really? Another boyfriend? Cher's face went red. He's just a friend from work. Camilla. The middle one, 10, rolled his eyes. The youngest, seven, wouldn't even look at me, stood in my doorway like they were being sentenced to prison. Cher hug them quickly told them to be good, and left for the airport. I stood there with three kids who clearly hated me and realized I was in way over my head. The first morning, I woke up early to make them pancakes. When the oldest one, Camilla, laughed. She's not here, you know. You can stop trying, she said. Besides, you're not her type. Mom doesn't date guys without kids. We've seen this a dozen times already. It hurt, but it wasn't a lie. Cher's co workers, guys from her gym, men from dating apps. Everyone wanted to play dad until they realized three kids meant actual work. And the kids really didn't make it any easier. From spilling drinks on my laptop to turning the TV up during important zoom meetings, they hated every second with me. Dude, just survive until she gets back, then ask her out. My friend told me that became the plan. Survive two weeks, do whatever to keep the kids happy. Be the hero, finally land a date with share. But like most things, it doesn't always happen the way you want it to. Sometime within the second week, the middle kid, Murph, came home from school trying to hide a black eye. Before I could even ask, Camilla grabbed ice from the freezer and held it against his face. Just pretend you didn't see anything, she told me coldly. I bent down beside them and asked in a kind but stern voice, tell me what happened. Just leave me alone, he said, turning away. I shook my head. I'm not here to lecture you or get get mad at you or do anything without your permission. Not even tell your mom. But I need to know what happened. Murph blinked at me and frowned. Someone called me an orphan because I don't Have a dad! I patted his head and thanked him, walking away as calm as I could, even though all the blood in my body was boiling with anger. Next afternoon, I took a half day at work and showed up at their school in a rented GTR, strikingly white engine, purring like a monster. I rolled down the window and waved, wearing sunglasses and a black polo. Who's got the coolest dad now? I said loudly, as Murph and his friends ran over excitedly. Murph watched his bully's jaw drop and quickly hopped in. He rolled down the window and flipped him off, which was my signal to immediately drive off the middle school campus. Okay, I like the enthusiasm, but let's never tell your mother about this, I said, grinning. I picked up the other two kids and took them to in and out for a quick afternoon snack, then surprised them with a baseball game. Murph ate in a helmet full of nachos, and I managed to snag a foul ball for little Celia. Not bad, old man, Camilla said, watching her siblings enjoy the game. We made sure to take pics with the car and at the stadium, all covered in ketchup and mustard, sent everything to their mom with a caption we wish you were here. After that, things between me and the kids sort of changed. When the youngest, Celia, had a nightmare and called for her mom, I sat beside her bed reading Out fairy tales until she fell asleep. I made the kids meals and lunch box.

Grandmother asked me, do you wear that bracelet I sent you every day? My stomach sank. What bracelet? She pulled out her phone and showed me a receipt. 3,000 dollar custom gold bracelet with your birthstone delivered four months ago. I'd never seen it in my life. My mom suddenly got very interested in her coffee cup. Dad started scrolling through his phone like nothing happened. The air in the restaurant felt thick with tension. Mom, I said slowly, did you sign for a package addressed to me? Her face went red. We thought it was a mistake. Grandma sends so many things. A mistake? Grandma's voice could cut glass. I had it engraved with his name. And track the delivery myself. I watched my parents exchange that look, the same guilty look they'd been giving each other for months whenever grandma brought up gifts or money. I thought I was being paranoid. But now everything was starting to make sense. Show me the tracking information. Dad interrupted, trying to sound authoritative. Grandma scrolled through her phone. Delivered to your front door on March 15th at two forty seven PM signed for by Leora Hensley. She looked directly at my mom. That's you, isn't it, Leora? My mom's hands started shaking. I, I don't remember every package that comes to the house. You don't remember a 3,000 dollar piece of jewelry? Grandma's eyebrows shot up. That's when I noticed my sister's new tennis bracelet sparkling on her wrist. The same design. The same stones, the same everything. My stomach dropped. I'd seen Alara wearing it for weeks, bragging to her friends about how she'd treated herself after getting good grades. Alara's idea of treating herself was usually a five dollar coffee, not luxury jewelry. Alara, I said, staring at her arm. Where did you get that? She yanked her sleeve down faster than I'd ever seen her move. I, um, saved up for it. Alara works part time at a smoothie shop making $12 an hour. She spends most of her paycheck on makeup and clothes. There was no way she had $3,000 saved. How long did you save? I pressed, feeling my anger building. Like a few months, she mumbled, not making eye contact. A few months of smoothie shop money bought you a 3,000 dollar bracelet. Mom jumped in. Alara has been very responsible with her money lately. Really? I turned to my parents because last month she asked me for $20 for gas money. The month before that, she needed $50 for textbooks. Just last week she was complaining about being broke. Dad cleared his throat. Lauren, you're being dramatic. Maybe Alara got a bonus or from a smoothie shop. I cut him off. Alara, what's the most expensive thing you've ever bought with your own money? She fidgeted with her napkin. I don't know, maybe my phone case, which cost like $30. The math wasn't mathing and everyone at the table knew it. Grandma leaned forward her Eyes locked on Alara's bracelet. Show me that bracelet now. I don't wanna take it off, Alara said, her voice getting smaller. It might fall.

If you have a skin color other than white or speak a language other than English, the immigration police today got permission from the Supreme Court and Donald Trump to arrest you, throw you in jail for a couple days and check on your citizenship and green card. My brother got me kicked out. Now my he wants my house. When I was 16, my gaming obsessed brother Tyler convinced my parents I was taking up too much space in our cramped three bedroom apartment. He'd been complaining for months that he needed my room for his elaborate gaming setup. My parents sat me down one evening and basically said I had two weeks to find alternative living arrangements. The reasoning? I was almost 17, practically an adult, and Tyler needed space to pursue his passion in gaming and dreaming. They genuinely believed he was going to become the next big Twitch star. I was devastated, but had nowhere to go. My girlfriend Emma's parents noticed I'd been spending more time at their house and eventually asked what was going on. When I explained the situation, her mom immediately said I could stay stay with them as long as I needed, no questions asked. Emma and I got serious fast. Living under the same roof will do that to a relationship. When we turned 19, I proposed with a ring. I'd saved six months for working overtime every weekend. Her parents were thrilled. They basically raised me for two years anyway and considered me their son. At 23, we finally had enough saved for a down payment on a small two bedroom house. Nothing fancy. We spent every weekend renovating, learning YouTube tutorials, making mistakes and fixing them. Meanwhile, Tyler was still living with my parents in his Gaming paradise. He dropped out of community college after one semester, claiming his streaming career was about to take off. College was just holding him back. Three years later, he was still grinding away at maybe five viewers on a good day. Sleeping until two PM, gaming until 4:00am. Ordering Doordash with my parents money. My parents occasionally texted generic holiday messages or shared Facebook posts about family, but otherwise we had zero relationship. Last month my mom showed up at my house completely unannounced. I hadn't seen her.

My husband punched my pregnant sister in the stomach and thank god he did. My husband walked up to my 8 months pregnant sister during her baby shower and punched her full force in the stomach. Her boyfriend was checking for blood and everyone was filming while my grandmother was having chest pains from the shock. My aunts grabbed their kids and ran while I dropped beside my sister trying to feel the baby kick, but she kept pushing my hands away saying don't touch, it hurts too much. The neighbor who was a midwife tried to come help, but my sister curled into a ball screaming not to touch her stomach. My uncle was on the phone with his lawyer saying we needed to press charges for attempted murder of an unborn child. While my sister's mother in law fainted and had to be laid on the couch, my sister kept her arms wrapped around her stomach so tight nobody could get close, crying that she could feel something was wrong inside. My hands went numb pressing against foam edges and Velcro straps where my nephew should have been. She's been buying different sized fake bellies online to fake the progression, stealing ultrasound photos from pregnancy forums and photoshopping her name on them and scamming everyone for $30,000 in medical bills for appointments that never existed because I checked with every OB in the city. I kept pressing on the dented foam while my sister tried to push me away and everyone started grabbing at her stomach, finding more straps and padding underneath. I followed her after she said she had an OB appointment yesterday and she went to a bar and drank for two hours, then bought three more fake bellies at a costume shop downtown. My sister was crying.

Daughter Lily had just started kindergarten when I got a notification from the class group chat. Hi, everyone. I'm Sarah Miller and my daughter Tiffany just transferred here today. The chat lit up with a string of welcomes and hellos. Just as I was about to type out my own greeting, a huge block of text appeared. Important notice from Tiffany's mom. Girls in the class, please take note. Starting next week, I'll be posting a picture of what my daughter is wearing each day. Please make sure your child doesn't wear the same thing. Also, I request that everyone please switch to the same brand of laundry detergent we use. My daughter has a very sensitive nose and can't tolerate other scents. Finally, my daughter was a C section baby and is a bit timid. So I ask you to tell your children not to bully her and make sure she's always treated with priority. Wow. I couldn't help but think this isn't just a new student. This is a royal princess who's slumming it with us commoners. Some of the moms in the chat were quick to push back. Karen's mom, are you serious? What my kid wears is none of your business. Why should we have to cater to you? Jessica's mom, exactly. And we're supposed to all use your detergent? My son has allergies, too, and we use specific stuff. Yeah. Who made your kid the queen of the class? My kid is special, too. The chat Quickly devolved into a debate. Usually I just chuckled at the ridiculous things these parents said in the group chat. The class teacher was the administrator and she'd usually step in to calm things down. I didn't see a problem, so I just muted the chat to get some work done. Then I got a DM. It was from Alyssa, whose daughter Emily was friends with Lily. Hey, Sarah, you got a. If you don't want to wait for part 2, you can watch the full story on my YouTube channel. Just click on share and then more and then click on the YouTube link here in my profile or search for the Flag Stories Reddit channel on YouTube.

You get attention at home twice if your parents stop caring for you at the age of 3. And the worst part is whenever the class is just having their own conversations with their friends, he just tries to jump into other conversations that did not include him at all. Like bro, get a friend or something. I don't know. The funniest part though is when they say a joke in class but it just crashes and burns. Everybody silent, no one laughs or even makes the slightest smirk. Just a couple of stairs. If you call yourself the class clown and you get in trouble for popularity, please shut your fucking mouth anyway. Have A great fuck ass day.

This country is cooked. We're not even, like, in a state of repair. We're just going downhill very, very fast. This man, Charlie Kirk, was just shot, publicly executed on video on a college campus because people didn't agree with his political beliefs. And there are people on Twitter genuinely celebrating this man's death. He didn't do anything to them, by the way. Just had different political views. They're throwing up old quotes of him and just mocking his death. Like, actually gross. This serves as a reminder that every day you leave your house, it could be your last. Life is never promised. So live and rest in peace, Charlie.

The public reaction to Charlie Kirk passing away is honestly really disturbing. Almost any comment section of someone reporting on this news, whether it be on Twitter or TikTok, are just users spamming the comments celebrating what happened. Charlie had a wife and he has two very young kids. They are now going to have to grow up without a father around because of stupid politics. And the way that some people are reacting online is honestly just making the situation worse. What's even more upsetting is that footage of the incident has been circulating all over Twitter. So please, please be careful when you're scrolling because there is absolutely no sensor on it. And the only slightly good news that I have for today is that the FBI director has finally announced that they have the attacker in custody.

Charlie Kirk just got shot in the neck at one of his events in Utah. If you don't know, Charlie Kirk is, he's a professional debater, I guess you could say, or a politician. And he usually does debates on like college campuses where he goes and talks about stuff. And today in Utah, one of them, he was shot in the neck. And I don't think he's with us anymore. The reason why I say I don't know is because it just happened. So there's no reports from the hospital. But I'm praying for Charlie, Man. I'm not gonna show the video of it happening on here, but there's videos on the internet. You can search it up if you want. Be warned, it's very, very disgusting. And it's really unfortunate because he has a wife, kids, and I'm pretty sure his wife is pregnant right now. I mean, dude, the world is actually such an evil place.

Do you guys ever get that heavy feeling when you realize you're not really a priority to anyone? Like, I feel like I only exist when my friends are bored, lonely or need something from me. Whenever I need them, I'm left on delivered for hours, sometimes all day. It's like I'm just a second option or a last option. And honestly, sometimes I'm not even an option at all. They never prioritize me. They never make time unless it's convenient for them. And the worst part, I still show up for them every single time.

I think my friend just downloaded a virus on his school laptop. It's so over like bro. We were in the computer lab supposed to be working on a history project but my friend who has zero self control now is the perfect time to download a pirated version of Minecraft. I told him bro, that's a terrible idea. You're gonna get a virus. He just hits me with nah, trust me this site is legit. This numb skull then proceeded to somehow spawn in hunt tons of ads advertising the most unhinged things. It looked like his computer was having a seizure. He was trying to close everything but every time he closed one pop up three more would appear. All of a sudden his computer speakers started blasting Roblox Tycoon music at full volume. The entire class went silent. They all stared directly at the scene my friend has caused gets up and immediately marches towards him with the force of a thousand suns and she stops right at his desk. She looks at the screen then at my friend and with a voice as commanding as Zeus she says that's it. Go to the office now. Bro didn't just get a virus, he got a one way ticket to detention for the rest of his life. Subscribe to save him from detention.

Every school has that annoying ass boy who thinks he's literally the main character of the school and his friends just walk after him like a dog and do everything he says like, no bro, you ain't tough and no one's respecting you. You feel way too tough. You're just in cornball and actually no one likes your dumbass. The only people who actually like him are his dog friends. He thinks he owns the school or something and he has like every week a new girl bro, new season, new girl or what. That ain't tough buddy. He walk around thinking everyone is afraid of him bro, but actually everyone thinks of you shit. Some months ago he pushed me into the bush with his minions. What the fuck? That ain't tough. And he started laughing like a dog who's choking sand. Please just switch schools. And his annoying little sister feels herself way too much because she's the sister of that cornball. If I had one wish, I would wish for that chopped ass cornball to be gone. I don't even understand how his chopped dumbass got that many girls. Anyway, Melissa out.

What's your most bitter sweet childhood memory? When I was 8, my cousin Tiffany came to live with us for six months while her parents sorted out their divorce. I'd always wanted a sister and suddenly having a 12 year old girl in the house who knew about makeup and had actual opinions about music seems like winning the lottery. My mom set up the guest room for her with new curtains and cleared out half the closet. Dad built an extra shelf for her books. My little brother Sean, who was only 5 then, followed her everywhere until she taught him a secret handshake that made him feel special. The first weekend Tiffany was with us, she suggested we build a time capsule. I collected items all week. I contributed my favorite marble. Sean added a plastic Dinosaur. Mom put in a recipe card and dad included a baseball card. Tiffany added something wrapped in tissue paper that she wouldn't show anyone. This stays sealed until exactly 10 years from now, Tiffany said. As we buried it under the old maple tree in the backyard. We marked the spot with rocks arranged in a circle. Every Sunday became capsule checking day, where we'd go out to make sure the rocks hadn't been disturbed. Sometimes Tiffany would press her ear to the ground and claim she could hear our treasures talking to each other. Sean believed her completely. I pretended to believe but secretly knew better. Still, I played along. In Month 4, our neighbors Adrian and Yasmin invited us to their daughter Molly's birthday party. Molly was Tiffany's age and they become friends at school. The day before the party, I overheard mom on the phone. I know it's difficult, but you need to make a decision soon, mom said. She's doing well here. She asks about you every day. That night, Tiffany taught me to braid my hair. Her fingers worked quickly and I sat perfectly still, afraid any movement might make her stop. When she finished, she took a picture with her disposable camera. This is how I'll remember you, she said. At Molly's party, the adults gathered in the kitchen while us kids played games in the basement. I noticed Tiffany kept checking the stairs. When Molly's mom called everyone up for cake, Tiffany pulled me aside. I have to tell you something, she whispered. I'm going back home next week. The cake tasted like nothing. After that, I watched Tiffany laugh with Molly and the other older girls. She seemed happy, not like someone about to leave everything behind. On her last night with us, we had pizza, Tiffany's favorite, with extra cheese. Dad made ice cream sundaes and mom gave Tiffany a necklace with a tiny silver heart. Sean cried when he found out she was leaving and refused to do their secret handshake. It won't be special anymore if we do it when I'm leaving, Tiffany explained after Sean went to bed. Tiffany And I sat on the porch swing. I wanted to ask her why she had to go, why she couldn't just stay with us forever. But instead, I asked about the time capsule. What did you put in there that you wouldn't show us? A letter to you, she said, about why I really came to stay here. The next morning, her dad picked her up in a car I'd never seen before. Mom hugged him for a long time. Tiffany hugged each of us. But when she got to me, she whispered, remember 10 years? We got two postcards from her that summer, then Christmas cards for a few years, then nothing. Mom said, people get busy. Dad said, that's just how life works sometimes. When I was 13, Sean wanted to dig up the time capsule early. I wouldn't let him. I promised Tiffany we'd wait the full 10 years. Last month marked exactly 10 years. I came home from college for the weekend and went straight to the maple tree. The rocks were gone. Landscapers had redone the yard years ago. I dug where I thought the capsule should be. Nothing. I tried another spot. Nothing again. I was about to give up when my shovel hit something.
NA

Genuinely, what is going on this week? There has been a school shooting in Denver. A girl got stabbed on the subway and no one helped her. A decomposing body found in D4V D's car. A man was beheaded at a Dallas motel. Charlie Kirk getting shot and killed at a university. And all on top of that, the 9 11 was 24 years ago today. As much as I hate Charlie Kirk and his decisions, no one deserves to get killed. Imagine what his wife and kids are feeling right now. His children can't grow up with their dad. His wife is now a single parent. I genuinely hate Charlie, but I can't imagine how his family is handling this right now. And apparently they witnessed it. The way the blood came out of his neck was genuinely traumatizing. The way his body went limp immediately was horrifying. But anyways, moving on to the D4 V D situation. He's been on tour for like what, a month now? He hasn't been in LA for like a month. And the body hadn't decomposed enough for it to be in that car for so long. The body was in there for three days, and the police haven't even made him a suspect. And plus he had a concert like yesterday, I'm pretty sure. But yeah, moving on to the girl that was stabbed. She was literally minding her business before she got stabbed. And as soon as she got stabbed, everyone Was so calm, like, hello, she needs help. There was literal blood dripping on the floor. I don't have much information on the other situations, but the fact that this is all happened in a week is honestly scary. Like, this month has just started. What's going on

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

Bro, fuck you mean Charlie Kirk just passed? Like, what the hell is even going on this week? A body found in David's car. Some girl got slime just because she's sitting down in a bus. And this bullshit. I beg of you, don't even look it up. I'm begging you right now because that had me traumatized. I'm grown and people call me UNC, and I still can't do blood. The second it started, he pouring out like juice. I wanted to tap out, bro. That's exactly why I could never be a surgeon or anything medical long term. I don't care what my parents say. Basically, he was giving a speech at a university, and some old bald sniper just came out of nowhere and actually took him out from like 30 feet away. And it's wild because you can disagree with a man. I know I didn't with some things he said and think he said some foul or even racist stuff, but at the end of the day, he had a wife and two little daughters. You can't wish death on nobody. This division between Republicans and Democrats is going to spread wide faster than the rift in Superman. Literally watch the presidential debate from 2008 between Obama and some other guy, I can't remember. Jokes aside, shit was respectful. Now we got they're eating the dogs and Sleepy Joe memes from the two presidential debates from last year. That sniper got the worst karma coming. His way. Cause assassinations like this never make sense. You really gonna pull up with a rifle, plan it out, and take someone's life when you the dude who's already old? Shooter should have spent his time in a retirement home or some shit. Or a warden. Yeah, that. Unless we're talking about monsters like Epstein. Controversial people ain't worth that. I pray that Kirk's family gets through this. May god help America.

The thing about trios is that no matter how hard you try, you're always going to end up feeling like the outsider. It's like being right there, sitting with them, but still invisible. You laugh when they laugh, but deep down you know you're laughing at something you weren't even part of. You watch them get closer and closer, and you start questioning yourself, like, what's wrong with me? Why am I never enough to be chosen? It's the kind of hurt that doesn't scream. It just sits heavy in your chest until you feel like breaking. And the worst part is, you can pour your heart out, you can beg them to understand, but nothing changes. They keep being a duo, and you keep being the leftover. That's when it hits you. You deserve better than fighting for scraps of attention. You deserve friends who make you feel like you belong, who don't make you wonder if you're the problem. It's so hard to let go. But sometimes you have to. Because staying in that kind of pain is worse than being alone.
NA

Mom, can I go to the ditty party? What? No, of course not. What even is that? It's a party a lot of celebrities go to. I got invited. No, you can't go to a party. You have exams. Please, mom, this is a one in a lifetime opportunity. Fine, you can go, but only if your dad lets you. I love you so much, mom. You're the most caring person ever. Oh, thanks, son. I'mma ask dad now. Hey, dad, can I go to the ditty party? No, you have exams. Okay, fine. Can you help me with my homework then? Yeah, sure. What does this say? What class is this for? English class. It's so we can improve our vocabulary. But I can't figure this one out. Please help me. It says you can go to the ditty party. Thanks, dad. I have another one I need help with. It says, you have my permission. Damn, daddy, you're so good at this. How about this one? I can't do this one. This looks hard. Please, dad. This is the last one. You don't want me to fail, right? Please, dad. Oh, I got it. I make all the decisions in this house. You're the best, dad. Thank you. No problem, son. Are you studying for your test? Of course, dad. That's what I'm working on right now. When are you going to be back from your work trip? Two weeks from now, mom. Look, dad said I can Go to the party. He said he makes all the decisions in this house. Wow. I'm gonna have to talk to him when he's back. I guess you could go now. Have fun at the party. Yay! I can't wait to get diddled.

How did you scam the scammer? Last Tuesday, I was making lunch for my kids when my phone rang. Unknown number, but I picked up anyway. Big mistake, right? This guy with a thick accent starts telling me he's from the IRS and I owe $4,200 in back taxes, says if I don't pay immediately with gift cards, the police will arrest me within an hour. Now, here's the thing. I literally just got my tax refund two weeks ago. My accountant, Beth, handled everything perfectly and I even got money back. So I knew this dude was full of it. But instead of hanging up, something clicked in my brain. My neighbor, Mrs. Kim, had fallen for this exact scam and last month and lost $800. Time for payback. I started crying into the phone, oh, no, I can't go to jail. My kids need me. The scammer ate it up. He told me to go to target and buy iTunes gift cards worth $2,000 as a first payment. I said I needed an hour to get the money together. First, I called my cousin Jake, who's a cop, told him what was happening and he said to keep the guy on the line as long as possible. Then I started my revenge tour. I called the scammer back an hour later sobbing. I'm at target, but I'm so confused. Which gift cards do I buy? He walked me through it step by step. I pretended to be this Helpless single mom who didn't understand technology. Sorry, can you repeat that? My hands are shaking so bad. For the next 20 minutes, I wandered around target asking him questions. Do I need the physical cards or the digital ones? The cashier is asking for ID is that normal? Sorry. My 4 year old is having a meltdown in the cart. Finally, I told him I had the cards. He was so excited, probably thinking about his commission. I read him the first number. Okay, it starts with 5. Wait, is that a 5 or an s? The scratching messed it up. I gave him completely fake numbers, mixing up digits, going super slow. After 20 minutes of this, he got frustrated. Ma'am, those numbers don't work. Go buy new cards. So I did the whole routine again, drove to Walmart, called him back crying harder. The first store's cards didn't work. Are you sure you're really from the IRS? This time I really went for it. I'm in the Walmart parking lot, fake crying so loud. Other shoppers were staring. My kids are asking why Mommy is buying $5,000 worth of iTunes cards. My daughter wants to know if we're going to be homeless. The scammer actually tried to comfort me. Don't worry, ma'am, just read me the numbers and everything will be fine. I fed him another set of fake numbers, this time adding, sorry, my baby spilled juice on the card. Let me clean it off. Three Hours in, this guy had wasted his entire afternoon on me. I could hear other scammers in the background getting impatient. His supervisor was probably wondering why he hadn't closed the deal yet. That's when I went for the kill shot. You know what's funny? I just got off.

Guys, I think my dad is a fucking femboy and my mom is into that shit. Don't get me wrong, I love the man. But I've been noticing some weird ass behavior lately. So it's Monday morning. I wake up late as fuck, already annoyed because school exists, right? I'm rushing to get my shit together. I somehow located both my goddamn missing socks and I step out of my room only to hear some high pitched voice coming from my dad's office. Naturally, being a curious idiot, I go check. Worst decision of my life. My dad is on all fours barking at my mother dressed in a fucking maid outfit with cat ears. I'm talking full on submissive mode. My mom is standing over him like a goddamn dominatrix holding a whip, a fucking whip. And then as if I'm the one in the wrong, their eyes go wide and my mom has the audacity to yell, get out and close the damn door, lady, you just.
NA

Did you know a high school senior killed her parents the night before graduation, then smiled on stage the next morning as if nothing happened? Her name was Olivia Grant. In June 2023, she walked proudly across the stage in her cap and gown, shaking hands with the principal, hugging classmates, and posing for pictures with friends. But what nobody knew was that her parents bodies were stuffed in the trunk of her car parked right outside the school the night before. Investigators say Olivia shot both her mother and father while they slept, then calmly packed her graduation outfit, rehearsed her smile in the mirror and went to bed. To everyone else, she was the picture of successa perfect student finishing her final year. At the ceremony, she laughed, clapped and tossed her cap into the air, celebrated with friends and her boyfriend filmed a TikTok of them dancing in the school parking lot. But when the video went viral, sharped viewers noticed dark stains on Olivia's white shoes. The police investigated. When they opened her trunk, they made a horrifying discovery. Olivia was arrested that same night. She told detectives chillingly, I didn't want them at my graduation pictures.

Bro, 2,025 just got way more cooked because I just realized today is September 5th. 2,025, which officially means we're 67.67% through the year. And listen, this is where shit gets weird. Mango has six letters, mustard has seven. 6 + 7 = 13. Now Kendrick Lamar, that's 13 letters. And the 13th letter in the alphabet is M. You know what m stands for? Massive. But wait, and if that wasn't enough, low taper fade has 12 letters. Now add that up, 13 + 12 = 25. What year are we in? The big 25? This is massive news for the unemployed.

Every friend group has that one person who somehow became the target for every joke. It's never announced, never official, it just happens. It's like we'll be in an argument and this person isn't even saying anything. And then they sneeze once and suddenly the entire group is united again to hate on this poor dude. And what kills me is they don't even have to do anything wrong. They'll just exist. And everyone's like, look at him breathing too hard, bro thinks he's a vacuum cleaner. And somehow they just laugh it off every single time. So there they are, sitting in the corner, taking every roast like a good boy. Basically holding the group together by sheer endurance. I wish I had that willpower. It's basically a public service. Forget therapy. Friend groups run on sarcasm and one person's ruin self esteem. That friend is basically the glue holding everyone together. Elmer's glue. Cheap and eaten by kids.
NA

Have you ever became a restaurant regular and didn't even realise it? So I'm going through this absolutely soul crushing breakup with my boyfriend of three years. You know, the kind where you can't eat, can't sleep and your friends are tired of hearing about it. I start going to this 24 hour diner at like 2:00am because I literally cannot sleep. It's one of those old school places with cracked vinyl boobs and fluorescent lights that make everyone look dead. First night I order coffee and pancakes and just sit there scrolling through my ex's Instagram like the masochist I am. The waitress, this woman in her 50s with kind eyes just keeps refilling my coffee without saying anything. Second night, same thing. Third night she finally asks, rough patch, honey? I nod and try not to cry into my syrup. By the end of week two, I'm there every single night at exactly 2:00am. Same booth, same order, same pathetic scrolling routine. That's when she sits down across from me. Alright, sweetie, you've been here 14 nights straight. Crying into pancakes. What's his name? And I just break. I tell her everything, how he cheated, how he moved in with her immediately, how all our mutual friends picked sides. She listens to every word while bringing me free pie. The next night she introduces me to the cook, Hank. This is pancake girl. She's having serious boy troubles. Hank, this massive guy with tattoo sleeves, looks at me And goes, what kind of idiot breaks a heart like that? Then he makes me these incredible chocolate chip pancakes shaped like a heart. Soon the whole night shift knows my business. There's Madison, the other waitress who gives me brutal but honest dating advice. Cameron, the dishwasher who barely speaks English but always pats my shoulder and says, no cry. Mija. Even the manager, Frederick, starts checking on me. They give me a nickname, Pancake Girl. There's actually a coffee mug behind the counter with PG written on it and Sharpie. That's mine. Now. One night I'm telling Madison about how my ex posted vacation photos with his new girlfriend and she gets this evil smile. Honey, you know what tonight's pancakes are on the house. Hank's making you the forget that loser special. It's a stack of pancakes with you deserve better written in whipped cream. Week 3, they start giving me relationship homework. Tomorrow, tomorrow night you're deleting his number, says Madison. We'll watch you do it. Week 4, they make me change my relationship status on Facebook. Right there at the table, more cheering. By week 5, they're basically running a late night therapy session. Other customers start joining our conversation. There's this trucker named Malik who shares his divorce story. A nurse coming off her shift who talks about her toxic ex. We become this weird little support group. Week 6, guess who walks in at 2:00am with his new girlfriend? My ex of all The diners in the city. He picks mine. I'm frozen. They're looking around for a table. I'm about to have a panic attack when Madison appears like some kind of guardian angel.

Bro, I can't figure out if there's 8 billion birthdays or just 365. I think about it. Every single person on earth has a birthday, but at the same time, there's only 365 days in a year. So does that mean everyone is just sharing the same 365 birthdays? Like technically, your birthday isn't even special. You're just in the queue with 20 million other people. Imagine blowing out your candles and somewhere across the world another dude is doing the exact same thing at the same time. That's not even your day. That's just the world's group project. And don't even get me started on leap year babies. They don't even exist half the time. They're just DLC characters that spawn in every four years. So is it 8 billion or 365? Shut your fucking mouth.

Why do kids try so hard in gym class? Like, bro, it's second period, you're gonna smell like wet donkey balls all day. And the gym teachers don't help. They're like, give me your best effort, sir. This is not the Olympics. It's Wednesday, 9:30 a. M. And we're playing kickball. Nobody should be breathing that hard before lunch. Then you see kids acting like dodgeball decides their whole future, sliding on the floor, dripping sweat, shirts sticking to them like duct tape. All of this just to go sit in science class leaking onto the desk. And now the whole row smells cooked. You're stuck breathing in wet donkey balls in class because someone thought he was LeBron James at 9:00am. Hard to focus on the math problems in front of me when there's a stench like that behind me. The air is actually unlivable. Every class after feels like punishment. Follow for more rants.

I'll be honest. I wasn't really a fan of Charlie Kirk. I didn't agree with most of what he said, and his politics were not mine at all. But that doesn't even matter right now. The part that actually breaks my heart is seeing people celebrate his death like he's a father. He has a wife. He has two kids who are now gonna grow up without their dad. That's not something you clap for. That's something you cry for. It doesn't matter if you hated everything he stood for. Nobody deserves that. People forget he was more than a political voice. He was a human being. He had a family, people who loved him, people who looked up to him in ways that had nothing to do with politics. Imagine being his children right now, logging online and seeing strangers cheer because your dad is gone forever. That pain is something no one deserves to carry. Disagreeing with someone's views is fine, but mocking their death? That's heartless. And honestly, it says way more about the people celebrating than it ever did about him. Rest in peace, Charlie Kirk.

My mom demanded I sign my entire inheritance to my stepbrother. I said nothing and revealed what she'd hidden for years. When I was 19, my mom remarried Richard and suddenly decided I was too spoiled living in our family home. Time to learn independence, she said, kicking me out so Richard's son Tyler could have my room. My childhood bedroom became his gaming setup overnight. I'll never forget packing my stuff while Tyler lounged on my old bed, already planning where to put his new desk. Mom stood in the doorway with her arms crossed, explaining how this would build character. The same woman who used to make me hot chocolate when I had nightmares was now treating me like a burden she couldn't wait to get rid of. I crashed on couches for months. My friend Jake's mom let me sleep in their basement, but I felt like such a charity case. I worked three jobs, morning shift at a coffee shop, afternoons at a retail store, nights doing delivery driving. I'd see families eating dinner together through restaurant windows and feel this hollow ache in my my chest. Mom would post family vacation photos with Tyler in my old spot at the dinner table. Disney World trips, beach houses, fancy restaurants. Tyler wearing my old high school Letterman jacket in one photo. Really stung like I never existed. The worst part was running into them at the grocery store. Mom would get this awkward smile and ask How I was doing out there in the real world while Tyler stood behind her wearing brand new clothes. Meanwhile, I'm calculating if I can afford name brand pasta sauce. This week, I finally saved enough to rent a tiny studio apartment above a pizza place. The walls were thin. It smelled like pepperoni constantly and the heat barely worked, but it was mine. I'd fall asleep listening to Tyler's Instagram stories about his awesome new room and best mom ever. During this time, I was the only one who visited grandma regularly. Every Sunday, I'd bring her groceries and we'd watch old movies together. She never asked why I look so tired or why my clothes were getting loose from skipping meals. She just made sure I ate a real dinner every weekend. At me home with leftovers, grandma would tell me stories about growing up during the depression, how her family stuck together no matter what. Real family doesn't abandon each other when times get tough, she'd say, patting my hand. I always wondered if she knew what mom had done to me. Five years crawled by like this. I bounced between apartments, worked my way up to assistant manager positions, slowly built a small emergency fund. Mom would occasionally text on holidays, generic thinking of you messages that felt more like obligation than love. Then grandma died suddenly, heart attack in her sleep. At the funeral, mom cried dramatically while Tyler stood there checking his phone. I Was the one who held Grandma's hand during her final hospital visit. I was the one who knew she wanted to be buried next to Grandpa wearing her blue dress. A week later, the lawyer called. Grandma had left me everything, her house, her savings, her vintage jewelry collection that I'd always admired. The reading of the will was surreal. Mom kept shooting me confused glances like there must be some mistake. But the real shock came when mom.
