She awoke from her coma and is telling her story and it's beyond comprehension. Her name is Maria Kovalchuk. She's a 21 year old Ukrainian only fans model and she nearly lost her life at the hands of extremely wealthy men. Okay, first of all, Porta potty parties are real, not some urban myth. They are real and they are horrific. If you don't know what they are, it's a party held by these very, very wealthy men who are into humiliating, degrading and abusing women and they will pay these young beautiful women sometimes hundreds of thousands of dollars for one night of torture. Mariah attended one of these parties and apparently made these already vile men mad when she refused to participate in whatever they were asking her to do. So they stole her passport and her cell phone. She was able to escape to a nearby construction site, but they found her, kidnapped her and for 10 days abused her beyond comprehension. The Dubai Police said her injuries were consistent with a fall and claim that she must have tried to end her own life by jumping off A ledge at this construction site. Her doctors, however, said her injuries were consistent with being beaten for days and then thrown out of a moving vehicle. The Dubai Police covered all of her expenses and hospital bills with the understanding that she would not speak poorly about how they handled the investigation. Oh, and the men that did this to her were released from custody and will face no charges.

Teacher gave me detention. I've been trapped in the school for two years. It started with a stupid prank. I put a fake spider on Mrs. Caldwell's desk with a note that said, Happy Halloween. She didn't think it was funny. Three hours of after school detention, she said. Clean the whiteboards, organize supplies. Think about my choices. That was October 31st, 2022. I haven't been home since. My name is Tyler, and I'm 15 years old. Or I was 15. I don't know what I am now. First day went normal. I scrubbed marker stains off whiteboards while Mrs. Caldwell graded papers. At four PM sharp, she stood up, gathered her things, and headed for the door. I'll see you tomorrow, Tyler, she said, flicking off the lights. Same time, I grabbed my backpack and followed her out. But the classroom door slammed shut behind me. The hallway was empty, silent. When I. I tried the exit doors, they were locked. Every single one. Front entrance, back exits, even the emergency doors. All sealed tight. I banged on the glass until my fists hurt. But the parking lot was empty. My phone showed no signal. The school Wi-Fi required a password I didn't have. By six PM, panic set in. My parents would be expecting me home for dinner. They'd call the school, realize something was wrong. Someone would come looking. Nobody came. As darkness fell, I heard the first sound. A low, scraping noise from somewhere deep in the building. Like fingernails dragging across concrete. Then footsteps in the hallway above me. Slow and deliberate. I hid in the bathroom until morning, listening to things moving through the school all night. Doors opening and closing. Whispered conversations in languages I couldn't understand. And once, something heavy being dragged across the floor. When sunrise came, I must have passed out from exhaustion. I woke up in a small, windowless room I'd never seen before. Grey concrete walls, a single light bulb. A mattress on the floor. A tray of food sat by the door. Cafeteria pizza that was somehow still warm. A note was tucked under the. Welcome to Extended Learning, Tyler. Your education continues. That night, the room's door unlocked automatically. I was free to roam the school. But leaving was impossible. Every exit remained sealed. The windows were too high and reinforced with metal mesh. People with unusual abilities. How does it change your daily life? I can remember every conversation I've ever had, word for word, not just the gist of it. Every pause, every stutter, every um. And, like, it's all stored in my head, like transcripts I can pull up whenever I want. Discovered this wasn't normal in third grade when I corrected my teacher about what she'd dead three months earlier. She insisted she'd never promised us extra recess for perfect attendance. I repeated her exact words from January 15th, including her coffee order she'd mentioned that morning and the phone call with her sister she'd taken during lunch. She went pale and called my parents. Testing revealed I have what researchers call phonographic memory. Like photographic, but for audio. My brain stores conversations with perfect fidelity, including tone, emotion, and background noise. I can tell you what song was playing in the grocery store during a conversation from 2,015. This gift nearly ruined my life. Friends stopped telling me secrets, knowing I'd remember every detail forever. Dating was impossible. Imagine never being able to forget a single fight, harsh word, or careless comment. I could replay every I love you, but also every lie. My freshman year roommate moved out after I accidentally repeated a private phone call she'd had with her mom about her eating disorder. I hadn't meant to eavesdrop. I just couldn't forget what I'd overheard. Therapists found me exhausting. I'd correct them about what they'd said. Six Sessions ago, making it impossible to build trust.
